headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Discover Financial Services Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's confer
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Discover Financial Services Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Bill Franklin, Head of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sabrina. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin as always with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is on the Investor Relations section of discover.com.Our discussion today contains certain for
componenttext:
Thank you, Sabrina. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin as always with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is on the Investor Relations section of discover.com.
Our discussion today contains certain forward-looking statements about the company's future financial performance and business prospects, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's earnings press release, which was provided to the SEC in an 8-K report and in our 10-K and 10-Qs, which are on our website and on file with the SEC.
In the fourth quarter 2015 earnings material, we have provided information that compares and reconciles the company's non-GAAP financial measures with the GAAP financial information, and we explain why these presentations are useful to management and investors. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's discussion.
Our call today will include formal remarks from David Nelms, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Graf, our Chief Financial Officer. After Mark complete his comments there will be time for a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
So now, it is my pleasure to turn the call over to David.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm going to review our fourth quarter and full year results and discuss our key focus areas for 2016. Then I'll hand it over to Mark to review the fourth quarter in more detail and share some
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm going to review our fourth quarter and full year results and discuss our key focus areas for 2016. Then I'll hand it over to Mark to review the fourth quarter in more detail and share some forward-looking guidance. 
Starting on Slide 3 of our earnings presentation, we reported fourth quarter net income of $500 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.14, up 31% due to some onetime charges in the prior year. We were able to drive our return on equity, up 18% for the quarter, despite higher loan loss provisions and higher nonrecurring expenses driven by the anti-money laundering look back. 
Turning to Slide 4. Discover achieved total loan growth of 3.5% over the prior year. Card receivables grew 3% this quarter, lower than we would like. However, this was partly due to lower promotional balance growth compared to the prior period. 
Total sales for the quarter increased 3% from the prior year or 5% excluding gas sales. Lower gas prices have continued to impact our sales and card loan growth more than we had anticipated. However, we believe that also somewhat helped credit results in 2015. 
Moving to our next largest asset class, private service loans grew 3%. However, excluding our acquired portfolios, we achieved 16% growth year-over-year. Personal loans increased to $5.5 billion[ph], up 10% from the prior year. 
On the right-hand side of Slide 4, we lay out Payments volume growth. Proprietary volume continued to increase in support of the card issuing business. However, our third-party Payments segment had lower volume compared to the prior year. A large part of the volume in the segment comes from PULSE where we saw a continued decline in the challenging post-Durbin environment. 
Performance was good in the other network businesses, although they represent a much smaller portion of the total Payments volume. Network Partners volume increased significantly driven by AribaPay volumes while Diners volume decreased slightly as reported, but was up nicely on a constant dollar basis. 
Now I'm going to touch on our full year financial results shown on Slide 5. In our 2015 -- in 2015, our earnings crossed the $5 per share mark for the first time. Revenue increased 3% from the prior year to $8.7 billion. Moving down this slide, provision grew roughly in line with the average loan growth. Expense growth was primarily driven by higher regulatory and compliance costs, particularly related to our AML consent order remediation. Due to the strength of our capital generation and buyback program, EPS increased 5% for the full year versus 2014. 
Moving to Slide 6, we accomplished a great deal in 2015 to move the business forward. We continued to grow our balance sheet with total loans up 3.5% from the prior year. We introduced new features and benefits throughout the year to attract and retain customers. 
In Card, we introduce the innovative Freeze It capability, which allows customers to suspend their credit card with a few clicks from their app in the event it's misplaced. I can personally attest to how well it works. And we offered a promotional 10% Cashback Bonus on in-store purchases using Apple Pay, which drove about adoption in our card base and also attracted some new cardmembers to Discover. 
At the same time, we continued to be disciplined in managing credit as our total net charge-off rate, excluding PCI loans, declined 5 basis points. Our card lost rate remains among the lowest in the industry. 
We also achieved record originations in our non-card loans. We increased brand awareness for student loans through radio advertising and the Freshman Experience, a unique partnership with NBC News. In December, we launched Fast set of systems, a free tool to help families navigate the government's [indiscernible] filings and educate prospective students about their funding options, which should continue to increase Discover's student loan awareness in 2016. 
In personal loans, we launched several new digital initiatives to help drive growth. 
In Payments, the competitive landscape in debit remains challenging. In 2015, we established new partnerships including network-to-network agreements, new Diners Club licensees and at the same time, we grew volume with existing payment partnerships like AribaPay. Perhaps most importantly, the Discover Network continues to provide significant benefits to our card issuing business as evidenced by the fact that we are accepted at more than 37 million locations worldwide, roughly 20% more than a year ago. 
As we look back on 2015, we feel good about our accomplishments. We generated a 21% return on equity for the full year and repurchased 6% of our stock. 
Now let's move to Slide 7. For 2016, our vision is unchanged. We aspire to be the leading U.S. bank and payments partner. Our key focus areas for the year will help us move forward towards accomplishing our vision. In 2016, we are targeting faster loan growth, which you will see in the guidance that Mark will go through later in the call. We expect this growth to be a balance between new accounts and our existing portfolio. 
Discover it continues to perform well in the marketplace, helped by the Double Cashback bonus offer from new cardmembers during the first year. While we anticipate the majority of our new account growth will come from our flagship Discover it Card, we expect to see additional growth from our Miles it Card and the recently launched Secured Card. 
To support the growth of the Miles it Card we introduced last year, we recently aired our first television advertising to increase awareness of the product and features. In addition, we announced the broad market launch of the Discover it Secured Card on Monday. This product will give customers who are new to credit access to the features and benefits of a Discover it product fully secured by a cash deposit. This is another opportunity for us to reach new customers and retain them as they develop a strong credit history. 
In the existing portfolio, we have a number of initiatives, some of which are already underway to support loan growth including a strategy to reengage and actives when they receive their EMV card, appropriate credit line increases for eligible customers and profitable balance transfers. Underlying all these initiatives is our commitment to a disciplined approach to credit management, which has served Discover well through previous credit cycles. 
In addition, we will continue to build-out our digital capabilities with enhanced customer features. By the end of the month, we will have completed the full rollout of our unique pay with cashback functionality online and in our app. This will offer customers the ability to pay their monthly card bill using their Cashback Bonus seamlessly. We continue to innovate in the features and benefits that drive customer satisfaction and long-term loyalty. 
Moving down the slide. In 2016, we will be very focused on operating expense leverage. Historically, we've had one of the best efficiency ratios in the industry. While our 2015 ratio was elevated due to some onetime items, we were managing the business to trend back towards our long-term target. 
In 2016, we expect to invest in growth and to see increases in ongoing compliance costs while also finding ways to optimize the core expense base. We have a unique set of payment assets, which present many long-term opportunities for us. Near term, we are focused on getting the most from our proprietary network for our card issuing business, including increased acceptance and brand differentiation. 
While Payment Services struggled with some third-party volume losses, we expect volume to stabilize prior to the end of the year, and we continue to seek opportunities to bring more volume from third parties on to our network. We were looking broadly across this segments, domestically, internationally, in business to business and in consumer payments. We have the ability to scale significantly and are committed to driving value. 
In 2016, we will be particularly focused on closing up our AML look back and continuing to enhance our compliance-related functions. Investing in compliance and risk management will enable us to meet increasing regulatory requirements while also strengthening our operations and supporting our leadership position in customer service. 
In lastly, we will optimize our capital deployment so we can consistently deliver strong returns to our shareholders while driving quality organic growth. We have big goals for 2016 and are hard at work to achieve them. We are especially working to accelerate profitable loan growth. 
Now I'll turn the call to Mark to discuss the details of our fourth quarter results and forward-looking guidance. 
Mark?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good evening, everyone. I'll start with the revenue detail on Slide 8 of our presentation. Net interest income increased $60 million or 4% over the prior year due to loan growth. Total noninterest income was up $108 million. I would r
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good evening, everyone. I'll start with the revenue detail on Slide 8 of our presentation. 
Net interest income increased $60 million or 4% over the prior year due to loan growth. Total noninterest income was up $108 million. I would remind you that the prior year period include a onetime charge of $178 million related to the elimination of the rewards forfeiture reserve. Excluding this onetime item in the prior year, noninterest income declined $70 million. 
The rewards rate was 118 basis points, up 18 basis points from prior year on an adjusted basis, largely due to the double rewards program for new cardmembers as well as fourth quarter Apple Pay promotion. Protection products revenue continues to decline, down $15 million year-over-year given our suspension of sales in late 2012. Other revenues decreased $30 million, primarily due to the loss of mortgage origination revenue as we closed our direct mortgage operation this year. 
Payment Services revenue was down $14 million primarily due to lower transaction processing revenue at PULSE. This was largely the result of the previously disclosed loss of volume from a large debit issuer. 
Turning to Slide 9. Total loan yield of 11.49% was up 9 basis points over the prior year. This higher yield was offset by higher funding costs and a larger liquidity portfolio. Combined, these drove net interest margin on receivables down 1 basis point from the prior year to 9.75%. However, on a sequential basis, NIM expanded by 13 basis points driven by higher card yield due to portfolio mix. 
Personal loans were the only asset class where the yield declined from the prior year. Shorter terms   year-over-year and a $5 million onetime adjustment to deferred loan origination cost drove the decline. As the origination cost adjustment was nonrecurring, we would expect that in the first quarter of 2016, personal loan yields will rebound to levels roughly in line with the third quarter of 2015. 
Turning to Slide 10. Total operating expense was roughly flat in part because both periods included some onetime items. In the fourth quarter of 2014, we recognized $48 million in charges in other expenses associated with 2 items. First, the $27 million impairment of goodwill related to the mortgage origination business, which we subsequently exited; and second, a $21 million mark to fair value related to Diners Club Italy classified as held for sale, which we've now sold. In the current period, we incurred $37 million in expense resulting from the anti-money laundering look back project. Adjusting for these items, expenses were $12 million or 1% higher year-over-year. 
Turning to provision for loan losses and credit on Slide 11. Provision for loan losses was higher by $27 million due primarily to higher reserve build compared to the prior year. As David mentioned earlier, prevention growth on a full year basis was essentially in-line with average loan growth. The credit card net charge-off rate was 2.18%, down 8 basis points year-over-year and up 14 basis points sequentially. The 30 plus delinquency rate was relatively flat year-over-year at 1.72% and up 7 basis points from the prior quarter. 
The private student loan net charge-off rate, excluding purchase credit impaired loans, decreased 10 basis points year-over-year to 1.3%. The 30 plus day delinquency rate increased by 11 basis points over the prior year to 1.9% as the organic book continues to enter repayment. 
Switching to personal loans. The net charge-off rate was up 8 basis points year-over-year to 2.3% due to the seasoning of newer vintages in line with expectations. And the over 30-day delinquency rate was up 10 basis points to 89 basis points. Across all of our portfolios, we remain pleased with our strong credit results. 
Next I'll touch on our capital position on Slide 12. Our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio was 13.9%. The sequential decrease in our capital ratios was driven by a combination of seasonal loan growth and capital deployment. On that latter point, we repurchased $435 million of stock in the quarter. In total, during 2015, we returned over $2 billion in capital to shareholders with a 94%[ph] payout ratio. To complete the repurchases we submitted as part of last year's CCAR capital actions, we plan to buyback over $800 million of shares in the first half of 2016. 
Moving to long-term guidance on Slide 13. The majority of these items have not changed since our last Investor Day, so I'll focus only on the 2 that have changed and are circled on the page. I would remind you that items of this page represent expected averages through the cycle and do not been serving reflect our expectations for 2016. Going forward, we'll be guiding to total loan growth as opposed to the component pieces. We expect long-term total loan growth of 4% to 6%. Consistent with this change, we've also updated the long-term guidance to reflect the total net charge-off rate, excluding PCI loans, which we expect to be 3% to 4%. 
Turning to Slide 14. We'd spend a minute on guidance that is specific to 2016. First, we expect total loan growth to be in the range of 4% to 6%, in line with our long-term target. Keep in mind that card represents roughly 80% of our portfolio. So achieving 4% to 6% of loan growth requires us to accelerate card growth from the recent trend. 
On that last point, I want to remind you of a nuance in how we report our monthly loan data. We don't process Payments for the Card business on Saturdays. So when a month ends on a Saturday, our 8-K reported receivables include Saturday sales, but no Payments from that day. This can create distortions in year-over-year comparisons. A good rule of thumb is to expect the positive bump of 50 to 60 basis points to the year-over-year growth when the current month ends on a Saturday, and to expect the drag of 50 to 60 basis points when the prior year month ends on a Saturday. Obviously, this is just the timing impact, but we're calling it out because both January and February ended on a Saturday last year. As a result, our relative year-over-year growth will be understated in our reporting for each of those months this year. 
Moving to our outlook. For net interest margin in 2016, we expect it to be what I would call relatively stable when compared to our full year 2015 NIM of 9.68%, perhaps with a bit of an upward bias. Further increases in rates would benefit us based on the modest sensitivity we've built into the balance sheet, but we may also see some offsets depending upon the level of card promotional activity and run off in higher rate in default price balances. 
With respect to rewards, we're planning to spend more on a full year basis in 2016. Specifically, we expect the full year rate around 115 basis points or roughly 7 basis points higher than 2015. A good portion of the increase is the first year double rewards program, which has delivered a lower-cost product out and brought on more engage customers, well worth the investment. 
Moving to non-interest noninterchange revenue. As we've said throughout 2015, we expect this line item to be lower this year. The primary drivers are the exit of the direct mortgage origination product, which generated roughly $74 million in revenue in 2015; continued run off in protection products revenue, which we estimate to be about $40 million lower in 2016; and a lower Payment Services revenue in part reflecting the sale of the Diners Club Italy franchise. Taking all of these into account, we expect non-interest, noninterchange revenue to decline approximately $125 million in 2016. 
Moving to the total net charge-off rate ex PCI notes, we expect it to be slightly higher than 2015. The credit environment continues to feel benign with our reserve build in the fourth quarter reflective of the seasoning of several years of card loan growth at levels above the portfolio charge-off rate, in line with our expectations. In addition, we assume a more modest outlook for improvement in the U.S. economy in 2016. 
Finally, we expect operating expense to be slightly above $3.5 billion next year. This reflects the roll off of the AML/BSA look back expenses over the course of 2016, incremental expenses for ongoing regulatory and compliance costs that are facing all participants in the industry, initiatives to accelerate loan growth as well as operating efficiency improvements. Based on this level of expense, we expect to drive positive operating leverage and decrease our efficiency ratio, which is already one of the lowest among large banks. 
To close things out, we have a business model that is generating strong returns on equity. While third-party payment volume has declined recently, we expect our Payment Services segment volume to stabilize prior to the end of the year. This should position us for growth in future years, which is why we are keeping our long-term Payments volume growth target of 10%. 
Near term, we are very focused on the remediation of our AML/BSA consent order and reducing expense in 2016. We'll be focused on accelerating total loan growth in a disciplined fashion, focusing on opportunities that are profitable for the long-term and not sacrificing credit for the sake of growth. 
Last but not least, we have a strong capital position that enables us to both invested in the business to drive growth and deliver prudently aggressive payouts to shareholders within the constraints of the CCAR process. 
That concludes our formal remarks. So now I'll turn the call back to our operator, Sabrina, to begin our Q&A session.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Don Fandetti of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Don Fandetti of Citigroup.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to confirm the reserve build this quarter was just sort of a seasonality and you're not seeing anything, at least today, that would suggest any weakening in the overall portfolio. I was wondering if you could comment on that. And i know in the
componenttext: I just want to confirm the reserve build this quarter was just sort of a seasonality and you're not seeing anything, at least today, that would suggest any weakening in the overall portfolio. I was wondering if you could comment on that. And i know in the past, you've [indiscernible] a provision average loan ratio, would you care to provide that for '16?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the fourth quarter number, Don, I would say the card reserve rate was 2.68% this quarter, I believe. And over the last 5 to 6 quarters, it's been pretty consistent in that 2.6% to 2.7% range. I would say, it's consistent, the provision really on a
componenttext: Yes, on the fourth quarter number, Don, I would say the card reserve rate was 2.68% this quarter, I believe. And over the last 5 to 6 quarters, it's been pretty consistent in that 2.6% to 2.7% range. I would say, it's consistent, the provision really on a full year basis is consistent with the loan growth on a full year basis, which is kind of, I think, what we've been saying people should be expecting. So no, we don't see any change at all in the dynamics of the portfolio. Our guidance for next year reflects what I called I think a slight increase in charge-offs. We still expect that to remain in the, clearly, in the low 2s range. I think we learned our lesson as we're trying to give provision guidance, and we are shying away from that this year and just sticking with charge-offs.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on the Rewards, obviously, going up for good reasons. But I'm just curious, would your sense be that, that's likely to sort of if you're wrong, maybe you're going to tick a little higher or are you being pretty conservative? It seems like
componenttext: Got it. And then on the Rewards, obviously, going up for good reasons. But I'm just curious, would your sense be that, that's likely to sort of if you're wrong, maybe you're going to tick a little higher or are you being pretty conservative? It seems like competition is going to remain pretty healthy into '16?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we've given guidance based on what we expect. Certainly, that can always be a little higher or a little lower than guidance, depending on because there's a lot about promotional decisions that we make along the way and so it could vary from
componenttext: Well, I think, we've given guidance based on what we expect. Certainly, that can always be a little higher or a little lower than guidance, depending on because there's a lot about promotional decisions that we make along the way and so it could vary from that. But what I would say is that it's less about competition and more about us doing test and controls and deciding what to spend in rewards versus the market in line and what has the best net present values for new accounts in stimulating in the portfolio. And that means that has led to high your spend overtime in this light.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say the big driver, Don, is the double rewards program on new accounts. And that's driving a very low CPA cost per account acquired right now and the customers who are coming on with new accounts are driving very engaged type behaviors that we exp
componenttext: I would say the big driver, Don, is the double rewards program on new accounts. And that's driving a very low CPA cost per account acquired right now and the customers who are coming on with new accounts are driving very engaged type behaviors that we expect to materialize in loan growth as we move forward throughout 2016. So I think it's a pretty potent investment right now is the bottom line based on what we see. But I would echo David's comment, it's something that we look at from time to time and could change. As always, if we update our outlook and our guidance, you'll know about it.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani of KBW.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani of KBW.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2015 was a year of a lot of surprises on the expense line. As we look towards 2016, how much execution risk is there in terms of surprises not popping up on expenses? I mean, do you guys feel like you have enough levers available to you so that i
componenttext: I guess, 2015 was a year of a lot of surprises on the expense line. As we look towards 2016, how much execution risk is there in terms of surprises not popping up on expenses? I mean, do you guys feel like you have enough levers available to you so that if there are surprises, you could still meet your expectations. And secondly, just, Mark, could you define slight in terms of increase for charge-offs?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the first point, Sanjay, what I would say is we clearly have expense levers. You make decisions from time to time on whether or not you want to pull to those levers, right? We knew that the look back project for the AML/BSA was going to be big dolla
componenttext: So on the first point, Sanjay, what I would say is we clearly have expense levers. You make decisions from time to time on whether or not you want to pull to those levers, right? We knew that the look back project for the AML/BSA was going to be big dollars. We knew it was onetime nonrecurring and cutting muscle that drives the business forewarned didn't make a lot of sense, right, in that regard. That being said, we covered an awful lot of ongoing expense increases in regulatory and compliance roll with operating efficiency gains this year. I think you should look to see us do the same next year. Candidly, I think we kind of landed right on top, more or less, of our OpEx guidance for the full year for this past year came in, I think, $15 million over something like that, but on a $3.6 billion[ph] line item, kind of feel like we did a decent job. That notwithstanding, I think at the end of the day there are clearly levers we can pull when it makes sense to pull them. With respect to what is a slight increase in charge-offs, I kind of reiterate what I said that Don maybe expanded on it a little bit, it's going to stay clearly in the low 2% range, Sanjay. We do not see any signs of a turn in the credit environment. We are operating with many years of growth seasoning in the portfolio right now and as we've said, new account season at loss rates higher than legacy portfolio, so there's a bit of an impact there. But the credit environment itself continues to feel very benign and we're not trying to signal some giant inflection points in charge-offs.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David Ho of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Ho of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question regarding your cycle guidance in terms of the loan growth versus the charge-off rates. Given that's through the cycle and then, obviously, baking in consumer conservatism, I guess, the question is, would it be possible that loan growth wo
componenttext: I had a question regarding your cycle guidance in terms of the loan growth versus the charge-off rates. Given that's through the cycle and then, obviously, baking in consumer conservatism, I guess, the question is, would it be possible that loan growth would be above kind of your 4% to 6% range at that level of charge-off rate, assuming the economy is not deteriorating in any major fashion just on the part of consumer being less conservative, is that the right way to think about that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that on loan growth, we have established a new long-term target of 4% to 6% of total loans. And we said that we are actually committed to being in that range next year, which implies some acceleration. Given that we're below that range today
componenttext: Well, I think that on loan growth, we have established a new long-term target of 4% to 6% of total loans. And we said that we are actually committed to being in that range next year, which implies some acceleration. Given that we're below that range today, I would not be looking for us to exceed it, I think we're going to work really hard to get into the range this coming year. And we think 4% to 6% would be gaining market share in prime credit cards and across our other businesses, so we think that would be a very good outcome without taking excessive credit risk. Charge-offs, you noticed that we have a long-term target and it's very disconnected with where we are and what mark said is slight increase. So clearly, we expect to be significantly below that long-term range during this coming year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what would get you through the 3% to 4%? Or what factors would drive that? Is that mostly macro or are you assuming any kind of decrease in conservatism on the part of the consumer?
componenttext: Okay. And what would get you through the 3% to 4%? Or what factors would drive that? Is that mostly macro or are you assuming any kind of decrease in conservatism on the part of the consumer?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say macro factors. And I think that we feel like we've been in an unusually benign time period from a credit perspective. On the flipside, it's been a very lack of loan growth time for the industry coming off of the shrinking period. But on charge
componenttext: I would say macro factors. And I think that we feel like we've been in an unusually benign time period from a credit perspective. On the flipside, it's been a very lack of loan growth time for the industry coming off of the shrinking period. But on charge-offs, it's been unusually benign and so we're expecting over a longer period of time for things to normalize.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I may, one more question on the seasoning of recent growth. At what point some are some of the more recent or prior vintage years start to tail off in terms of you moving down the peak of the loss curve and, hopefully, providing some tail win
componenttext: Okay. And if I may, one more question on the seasoning of recent growth. At what point some are some of the more recent or prior vintage years start to tail off in terms of you moving down the peak of the loss curve and, hopefully, providing some tail wind to reserving from here?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So cards are the biggest driver. They tend to peak at about 24 months after origination. So if you think about you have 3 years of vintages under the peak of the seasoning curve, if you will, a year ago is 12 months in and 2 years ago, it's at the peak an
componenttext: So cards are the biggest driver. They tend to peak at about 24 months after origination. So if you think about you have 3 years of vintages under the peak of the seasoning curve, if you will, a year ago is 12 months in and 2 years ago, it's at the peak and 3 years ago is coming down the peak pretty much equivalent to where a year ago was, more or less. The issue is if we are successful in increasing our loan growth, you will pick that up, right? Because if you have successfully larger vintages, the maturation of those vintages will drive provision. It's growth math and I think, candidly, I think, it's a good problem to have.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Brendler of Stifel.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Brendler of Stifel.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to focus again on the Card business and the competitive environment. You mentioned that you are only having an impact on your rewards rate, but we have seen an increase in the level of rewards and cashback in the competition. So maybe if you c
componenttext: Just wanted to focus again on the Card business and the competitive environment. You mentioned that you are only having an impact on your rewards rate, but we have seen an increase in the level of rewards and cashback in the competition. So maybe if you could dimensionalize, is that it getting any better into your outlook? And then a follow-up, surprised to see marketing investment down this quarter. I know there was sort of a lumpy quarter-to-quarter, but do you plan to increase marketing investment in 2016 and so the testing confidence that you think you're along with the target?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to handle the first one, I mean, competition is up both overall and in rewards. And I said it's particularly true in the rewards segment. But what I said before about as we have increased our rewards, it hasn't been just because we're seeing rewards
componenttext: Well, to handle the first one, I mean, competition is up both overall and in rewards. And I said it's particularly true in the rewards segment. But what I said before about as we have increased our rewards, it hasn't been just because we're seeing rewards of competitors, it's because we've tested in the programs that we think will produce better results. And certainly one of the reasons that we didn't grow marketing as much in the fourth quarter is because we chose to invest more on the rewards side, particularly promotional rewards for the new accounts, as Mark mentioned, versus cost for new account. We also have been issuing some nice savings in cost per account so the money has gone a little bit further. And Mark, I'll let you answer the second.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we look forward, I think the answer is we've been hitting and rewards are interconnected investments, so you may see some geography flips year-on-year between those 2 depending upon how we're looking to drive new account acquisition, as well as ut
componenttext: Yes. As we look forward, I think the answer is we've been hitting and rewards are interconnected investments, so you may see some geography flips year-on-year between those 2 depending upon how we're looking to drive new account acquisition, as well as utilization going forward. But I would not expect marketing expense to be flat on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. One quick follow-up, if I could. I think I know the answer to this, but I imagined you're dipping in the secured card space is not a part of your increase growth expectation in balances in '15[ph] at this point.
componenttext: Okay. One quick follow-up, if I could. I think I know the answer to this, but I imagined you're dipping in the secured card space is not a part of your increase growth expectation in balances in '15[ph] at this point.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I would say the Miles card of those 2 new products, the Miles card will probably have the greater impact. You see us that advertising on TV. Secured card, I view as a good feeder for the future. And I think as those customers in subsequent years as we
componenttext: No. I would say the Miles card of those 2 new products, the Miles card will probably have the greater impact. You see us that advertising on TV. Secured card, I view as a good feeder for the future. And I think as those customers in subsequent years as we hope a number of them will exhibit good behavior, we'll be able to eventually drop the requirement of the security to get to more normal credit lines. And so I think 2017, 2018 is when you'd start to see some of the maturing of those secured cards in the prime portfolio and that's our real objective.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, just a quick comment. I mean, I think that I would have liked to here that this is somewhat a noticeable earnings disappointment with a little more urgency as to the pulling of the levers and kind of executing on the plan. I mean, given that you di
componenttext: First, just a quick comment. I mean, I think that I would have liked to here that this is somewhat a noticeable earnings disappointment with a little more urgency as to the pulling of the levers and kind of executing on the plan. I mean, given that you did see -- you have some of your competitors see stable or improving loan growth even in industry environment, it's just kind of a an observation. But I guess, my question kind of really does relate to what, when you think about the growth really in net interest income, because that's really the driver of your revenue stream, are you expecting to see -- what is it about the new accounts? Because in other words, if you're getting record numbers of new accounts, are they not building the balances? And how should we think about the development of that to be confident to forecast 4%, 5% or 6% kind of into 2016?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first I think it's important to keep in mind the reasons growth decelerated, which a number of people that we're focused particularly in the prime segment didn't see growth, it's less than we did. But 1 driver was the slower U.S. retail sales growth
componenttext: Well, first I think it's important to keep in mind the reasons growth decelerated, which a number of people that we're focused particularly in the prime segment didn't see growth, it's less than we did. But 1 driver was the slower U.S. retail sales growth in addition to the impact of following falling gas prices, we talked about that. We also mentioned some of the actions we took to optimize the profitability of some promotional program, so that cost us some growth. Looking forward, we do have significant urgency in accelerating growth that's why we've committed to that 4% to 6% total growth range for next year, and that should come both from the new accounts side as well as the existing portfolio. And there's a whole range of activities that we have focused on getting more new accounts, activating the more leveraging balance transfer, Miles card, gaining wallet share on the portfolio side as we continue to roll out features like Freeze It. So we have a lot of range of actions because, frankly, the economy and the prime market isn't very robust. So what we have to do is to continue to gain market share as we've done for several years by differentiating our products.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jason Arnold of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jason Arnold of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I was just wondering if you could talk in a bit more detail about the potential opportunity to add third-party issuers and maybe hitting on the what you see as an opportunity as perhaps as well as challenges of getting new partners?
componenttext: David, I was just wondering if you could talk in a bit more detail about the potential opportunity to add third-party issuers and maybe hitting on the what you see as an opportunity as perhaps as well as challenges of getting new partners?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, if you look at our Payments segment, obviously, PULSE has been a challenge with [indiscernible] paid and some specific volume losses. But the other parts of Payments, we've actually seen some nice gains and particularly from Ariba, which has b
componenttext: Sure. Well, if you look at our Payments segment, obviously, PULSE has been a challenge with [indiscernible] paid and some specific volume losses. But the other parts of Payments, we've actually seen some nice gains and particularly from Ariba, which has been an important new partner. We continue to be working closely with PayPal, and I'm still remain optimistic that in the long-term, that's going to produce some of volume. We continue to make some good progress with new partners around the world. We signed the 3 largest banks in Brazil and with the network there and network-to-network partners, we've seen very nice growth out of our partners in China and in India, on Diners Club. So we are cashing a very wide net to grow our third-party payments volume and that's why we've still stuck to our 10% long-term growth target, even though we've been shrinking now. And so we're focused on turning that volume growth down to something positive.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Sherril Pi of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Sherril Pi of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow-up on sort of the loan growth on the card space and sort of understand the point on rewards cost relative to marketing spend. I guess, one more thing to add into the mix there sort, how should we think about the balance on profitab
componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on sort of the loan growth on the card space and sort of understand the point on rewards cost relative to marketing spend. I guess, one more thing to add into the mix there sort, how should we think about the balance on profitable loan balance transfers, which maybe drive growth faster than rewards might take more time to build up? Can you help us think through the dynamics there? And second I'm just wondering if you could comment on card acquisition trends this quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think I won't comment on card acquisitions this quarter, we'll wait till the next call to answer that. But on the first 2 questions, loan growth from the new accounts, we've been driving -- our Double Cashback Bonus has been driving lower cost per
componenttext: Okay. I think I won't comment on card acquisitions this quarter, we'll wait till the next call to answer that. But on the first 2 questions, loan growth from the new accounts, we've been driving -- our Double Cashback Bonus has been driving lower cost per account in a very attractive mix of cardholders. And those customers have been -- we're seeing more spend and maybe a little less balance transfer. And what that means is those new accounts we've put on in the last 2 quarters are going to continue to build their balances into next year. And so that's one of the things we're continuing to focus on is efforts that, ultimately, will result in balance growth and we're really pleased with the new accounts, but it's not as instant as balance transfer. Now balance transfer, I think, is an opportunity. We've pulled back a bit on balance transfer because we found some areas that we thought were not profitable, didn't meet our hurdles. But we are now pursuing some opportunities that we think will be more productive and more profitable. So I think we can probably do a little more balance transfer a small this year than we did last year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Sherril, on the trade-off between marketing spend and rewards spend, they're kind of in 1 regard one in the same, right? You're trying to build awareness, build utilization, you can do that by staying in front of mind in the television and elsewh
componenttext: Yes. And Sherril, on the trade-off between marketing spend and rewards spend, they're kind of in 1 regard one in the same, right? You're trying to build awareness, build utilization, you can do that by staying in front of mind in the television and elsewhere, you can also do it by providing a rewards product that's on an everyday basis engages that customer in a way that incents them to utilize the card as well. So they're both kind of have a common purpose on driving utilization spend and also in loan growth on the card. The one thing I would follow on to David's earlier remarks, which is loan growth from new accounts, from prime new accounts, emerges down the road a little bit, right? So you originate the account, the account comes on the books, you begin to see the spend behavior come on to the card. But unless you're balance transferring a big balance over, it takes time for that utilization to build those balances up. So we continue to feel good about the ultimate impact of the new accounts we're putting on, we believe we'll begin to see through 2016 that manifests itself in loan growth, but there's a line there.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Aaron of D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Aaron of D.A. Davidson.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could touch a little bit on personal loans and student loans, [indiscernible] about credit card growth. What are your thoughts on those 2 categories going forward?
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could touch a little bit on personal loans and student loans, [indiscernible] about credit card growth. What are your thoughts on those 2 categories going forward?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I mentioned, we were really pleased that we had record originations in bolstering loans and personal loans last year. We expect to do even more in both of those areas this coming year. We've -- one of the reasons that we moved to a total loans es
componenttext: Sure. As I mentioned, we were really pleased that we had record originations in bolstering loans and personal loans last year. We expect to do even more in both of those areas this coming year. We've -- one of the reasons that we moved to a total loans estimate is because those 2 businesses have become a bigger part of our total. And certainly, the fact that we expect faster growth from those 2 businesses and card helps drive our overall loans up. And I guess, the final thing I would say is that we are quite focused on some of the digital capabilities, enhancing our target marketing, we're doing more broad market in personal loans. And I mentioned a couple of the new endorsements or marketing features we have with NBC and others in student loans, which I think are helping to increase the awareness that Discover isn't just credit card, it's also student loans.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Rick Shane of JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Rick Shane of JPMorgan.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've heard you talk about something a little bit today that we haven't heard in a while, which is gaining wallet share through line limit increases. Can you just talk about that opportunity, the pluses and minuses there? And what makes you, at this point
componenttext: We've heard you talk about something a little bit today that we haven't heard in a while, which is gaining wallet share through line limit increases. Can you just talk about that opportunity, the pluses and minuses there? And what makes you, at this point, more comfortable you using that as a growth tool again?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I actually think we've been much more consistent than certain other competitors, who I think from not doing any to doing a bunch and saw a runoff and then saw big increases. We've actually been pretty steady. So I would say that we'll continue
componenttext: Well, what I actually think we've been much more consistent than certain other competitors, who I think from not doing any to doing a bunch and saw a runoff and then saw big increases. We've actually been pretty steady. So I would say that we'll continue to appropriately increase lines, but I wouldn't call that out as any dramatic change for us.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then it strikes me given that your borrowers have proven to be very responsible over time, it's a pretty kind of way to move up in wallet.
componenttext: Okay, great. And then it strikes me given that your borrowers have proven to be very responsible over time, it's a pretty kind of way to move up in wallet.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is if you're careful on how you do it. And so we are giving lines where we can, we are finding some opportunities. Certainly, the further we come into stable credit lines than the more stability many consumers have, the better their FICO scores a
componenttext: Well, it is if you're careful on how you do it. And so we are giving lines where we can, we are finding some opportunities. Certainly, the further we come into stable credit lines than the more stability many consumers have, the better their FICO scores are, the more history they have, it gives us greater confidence in being able to extend somewhat bigger line. I think both initialize lines for new accounts as well as line increases done to the right segments can be very profitable and can be done without driving up charge-offs.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Pancari of Evercore.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Pancari of Evercore.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask questions around the expectations on the AML/BSA cost for 2016, how we should think about that? It looks like it came in just shy of $100 million for '15, is that a fair level that we should assume for '16?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask questions around the expectations on the AML/BSA cost for 2016, how we should think about that? It looks like it came in just shy of $100 million for '15, is that a fair level that we should assume for '16?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, no. I would not assume that's a level for '16. The number we've been calling out for BSA AML compliance we specifically identified as a project, right? This is a look back on transactions over a period of time historically. And it's got a fin
componenttext: I would say, no. I would not assume that's a level for '16. The number we've been calling out for BSA AML compliance we specifically identified as a project, right? This is a look back on transactions over a period of time historically. And it's got a finite end date and a finite process it runs. So that definitely bleeds off as we go into 2016. And the cost of that is included in the expense guidance that we gave earlier. So we are considering the lingering effects of that as we look at the remainder of this year. What I would say is they are obviously, ongoing costs associated with the BSA AML program enhancements. Those we have largely been covering with either run rate operating efficiencies that we have found to date and we'll look to find ways to offset those expenses as we move forward. But they are fractions, very small fractions of the total number we're talking about around the project.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just to reconfirm that, expectation for the BSA AML cost, that is included in your 2016 expense projection of $3.5 billion, correct?
componenttext: Okay. Just to reconfirm that, expectation for the BSA AML cost, that is included in your 2016 expense projection of $3.5 billion, correct?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is included, correct.
componenttext: It is included, correct.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom of Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom of Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I just wanted to quickly clarify or rather maybe make sure I understood your expectations around allowance. It sounds like what you expect to pursue is that the allowance will grow roughly in line with the projected loan growth, is that correct?
componenttext: Mark, I just wanted to quickly clarify or rather maybe make sure I understood your expectations around allowance. It sounds like what you expect to pursue is that the allowance will grow roughly in line with the projected loan growth, is that correct?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the allowance will respond to what we actually see as trends in the portfolio. Based on what we see now though, we continue to believe provision increases will be largely driven by and in-line with loan portfolio growth.
componenttext: So the allowance will respond to what we actually see as trends in the portfolio. Based on what we see now though, we continue to believe provision increases will be largely driven by and in-line with loan portfolio growth.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so from that perspective, just mathematically, would be continue in that range of 2.6% to 2.7% of card loans?
componenttext: Got it. And so from that perspective, just mathematically, would be continue in that range of 2.6% to 2.7% of card loans?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would depend on the size of the new vintage, right? If you have a meteoric increase in the size of a vintage, that could impact it. But generally speaking, I think that's a reasonable proxy for looking at the stability of the credit environment.
componenttext: It would depend on the size of the new vintage, right? If you have a meteoric increase in the size of a vintage, that could impact it. But generally speaking, I think that's a reasonable proxy for looking at the stability of the credit environment.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries of Barclays.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the follow-up on that point because I think I always have some confusion on your comments, Mark. Because when you say the reserving in the kind of 2.6% to 2.7% level, I mean, it was kind of consistently in the last 4 quarters, are you referring to
componenttext: Just on the follow-up on that point because I think I always have some confusion on your comments, Mark. Because when you say the reserving in the kind of 2.6% to 2.7% level, I mean, it was kind of consistently in the last 4 quarters, are you referring to the reserves for loans as opposed to the provisions for loans? Because provisions for loans really have bounced around a lot. And if there were 2.7% this quarter, but if we look at a world where you're guiding to charge-offs in the low 2s and we're now at 2.7% on a reserve-to-loan ratio, would that imply that would absent really strong loan growth that the provision to loan should be lower in the coming quarters than they were in those quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what we're specifically calling out with that number is the reserve rate for cards that we disclosed in our financial supplement. So it's just bounced around. And looking back December of '14, it was 2.63%, 2.79% in March of '15, 2.62% in June, 2.62% i
componenttext: So what we're specifically calling out with that number is the reserve rate for cards that we disclosed in our financial supplement. So it's just bounced around. And looking back December of '14, it was 2.63%, 2.79% in March of '15, 2.62% in June, 2.62% in September, 2.68% now. So it's pretty consistently in that 2.6%, 2.7% range. I would tell you based on the seasoning of the growth we've put on the books over the course of the last couple of years, as well as the challenge that David has put in front of the team to accelerate loan growth as we go into this year as well, I would not expect the provisions to decrease. By the same token, I would very clearly state so that I'm not misunderstood, don't expect some giant increase in that card reserve rates right now based on what we currently see in our models, that obviously changes. But if you think about it, Mark, the next 6 months are pretty well known, right? So we're reserving for 12 months out. The next 6 months, we can pretty well see in the roll buckets. It's really that period of 6 to 12 months out where you've got a little bit of uncertainty, where your models get impacted to a degree by the macro variables and your assessment of the health and the strength of the economy and what that's going to do to our borrower. So there's always a little bit of uncertainty, it is a forecastle so by definition it's strong. If you try to be as right as you can with something along the bottom of the credit cycle we have been for a while, so there will be a little bit of volatility here. But I always just try to remind everybody, this is a $1.8 billion balance sheet item. So a little bit of volatility drives some moves in EPS.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris done that with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris done that with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I just wanted to ask on the secured credit card and your launch of that. You're typically very methodical about new products and I imagine this has been in development for sometime. Can you give us some color on what sort of the development process
componenttext: David, I just wanted to ask on the secured credit card and your launch of that. You're typically very methodical about new products and I imagine this has been in development for sometime. Can you give us some color on what sort of the development process you went through? And what you might have considered adding or not adding with the card? And just kind of understand when you guys launch something, I know you put a lot of investment into it, so what are you getting for?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and this has been in test for a while. So we have some -- we have experienced with some accounts and we got to a point where we had enough expense that we felt that we could make it an official launch. And I would say, we're certainly seeing in the
componenttext: Well, and this has been in test for a while. So we have some -- we have experienced with some accounts and we got to a point where we had enough expense that we felt that we could make it an official launch. And I would say, we're certainly seeing in the marketplace right now people that are in lesser credits are seeing significant growth and the prime market is really not growing hardly at all. And so we're not willing to sacrifice our credit to go into subprime. But what that this product allows us to do is to get people that might currently reconsider sub-prime to get our products from us to be protected from losses because we have the security deposit and to work with those customers, to graduate them into prime loans when they're ready. So it is our way of new to credit or blemish credit in a way that protects our losses. And so I guess the final thing I'd say, we did a lot of market research looking at competitive products, and we don't see anything in the marketplace that's like this. Most other cards are stripped-down cards, they don't have rewards, they don't have benefits, they service the cards offshore. This is a real Discover it Card with everything that comes with it. And the only thing unique is it's fully secured. And so when the credit improves, they continue that product, but it's become unsecured.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just related to that. You say you're seeing more opportunity with the sub-prime side and certainly what we see from other card issuers in pretty dramatic growth in loan balances in the sub-prime category. But are you seeing changes in consumer be
componenttext: And then just related to that. You say you're seeing more opportunity with the sub-prime side and certainly what we see from other card issuers in pretty dramatic growth in loan balances in the sub-prime category. But are you seeing changes in consumer behavior, like your anecdotes of millennials not embracing credit cards the same way, let's say, baby boomers did? Is that part of the thesis here or is that just in the background?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, because our -- it's probably a component because new to credit is part of it and which we are seeing a few more people that aren't establishing credit early on. And so they may need to start out with a secured card just because they just didn't get
componenttext: Well, because our -- it's probably a component because new to credit is part of it and which we are seeing a few more people that aren't establishing credit early on. And so they may need to start out with a secured card just because they just didn't get credit, they didn't get credit history, this helps address that need. A lot of what's happening though is the big bounce back, in my opinion, in the sub-prime market because I think that decline far more a few years ago than the prime did even and there are a very few competitors in it. And now, the very few people who are in sub-prime still, including the private labels that have high yields and lower credits, are seeing a big bounce back. But it's a smaller segment than the prime segment. I think the more important thing for us is to gain share in prime. But what we want to do is identify the people that can become prime over time and get them started before they're all the way there to the prime.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Hecht of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Hecht of Jefferies.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'll ask a question about margin. You're guiding for a flat margin, is that just, I guess, you're not anticipating many rate hikes this year? Or is there something else going on with the trajectory if rates and yields and cost of fund that we sho
componenttext: I guess, I'll ask a question about margin. You're guiding for a flat margin, is that just, I guess, you're not anticipating many rate hikes this year? Or is there something else going on with the trajectory if rates and yields and cost of fund that we should think about?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we are working off of an operative assumption of 1 or 2 rate increases this year as opposed to the 4 we were looking are in the forward curve towards at the very end of last year. I would say, we have not yet seen the benefit really of repricing in the
componenttext: So we are working off of an operative assumption of 1 or 2 rate increases this year as opposed to the 4 we were looking are in the forward curve towards at the very end of last year. I would say, we have not yet seen the benefit really of repricing in the card book fully from the Fed rate increase because we don't reprice card customers until cycle date. So you will get some lift from that coming in. So I think what we're trying to say in NIM is there's an upward bias in NIM, we're well-positioned right now. We may choose to invest some of that increase in NIM in marketing dollars, some promotional dollars and other places to really drive the growth that I think is the key thing we understand the market wants to see from us. So we may take some of that excess and reinvest it. Absent doing that, you would have a more NIM expansion than you'd likely to actually see.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And separate and distinct question, you did speak to the trajectory of your prime accounts and utilization rates. But just looking at your MasterCard study, you've had elevated payment rates for sometime. And I'm wondering if you could speak to kind
componenttext: Okay. And separate and distinct question, you did speak to the trajectory of your prime accounts and utilization rates. But just looking at your MasterCard study, you've had elevated payment rates for sometime. And I'm wondering if you could speak to kind of just generic changes you see in customer utilization or payment behaviors. Is there something that's changed? Do you think that's going to take a while to shift, I guess, that's worthy of discussion?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just say that the mix between balance transfer and sales can impact payment rates along with credit. And so certainly credit is great and so that tends to relate to a bit higher payment rates than what we otherwise have. But as we have shift
componenttext: Well, I would just say that the mix between balance transfer and sales can impact payment rates along with credit. And so certainly credit is great and so that tends to relate to a bit higher payment rates than what we otherwise have. But as we have shifted to a lower mark transaction volume turning into loans versus a little less balance transfer on new accounts, that is going to impact the payment rates. And so people will tend to pay more of their sales down than they will of their balance transfer down.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so based and I guess, the current marketing strategy, is that elevated payment stream, do you think that stays around for a while? Or would we see that shift?
componenttext: Okay. And so based and I guess, the current marketing strategy, is that elevated payment stream, do you think that stays around for a while? Or would we see that shift?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when you look at some of the onetime expense items outside of the AML/BSA spending this year and last and some of the changes, you've closed down the mortgage company and then, of course, you sold off Italy. Can you give us a sense of sort of what t
componenttext: Mark, when you look at some of the onetime expense items outside of the AML/BSA spending this year and last and some of the changes, you've closed down the mortgage company and then, of course, you sold off Italy. Can you give us a sense of sort of what the net impact of those 2 developments for? I mean, revenue goes down from those 2, but so does in cost.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Henry, some of the onetime expenses or some of the revenue reductions you see in the fee line actually are accretive to the P&L, right? For example, we called out, I think, $74 million in loss revenue next year from the mortgage business. I
componenttext: Yes. I think, Henry, some of the onetime expenses or some of the revenue reductions you see in the fee line actually are accretive to the P&L, right? For example, we called out, I think, $74 million in loss revenue next year from the mortgage business. I have to remind everybody when we exited the mortgage business, we said the reason we're doing it or one of the reasons we're doing it is it's not accretive, right? So I mean, I think that's a very good point there. If I think about that expense base generally right now, I think we are very lean, we are very efficient today as evidenced by that efficiency ratio. We are always looking to further efficiencies to get operating synergies and driving greater returns on that. As I said earlier, we do have some levers, we can put if we get there. But I think those are the kinds of levers you pull when you're in a turn in the credit cycle and you see things. Right now, we're still trying to drive growth, right? And I don't think you drive growth by kind of coming in and try to whack the heck out of expenses, especially when you're already as efficient on that as we are. So we're trying to balance prudent investments in growth, maybe investing some of this additional NIM to drive that going forward.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the Payment Services business, on the international front, Diners Card has gotten through a lot of change including the sale of Italy. What is the outlook there?
componenttext: In the Payment Services business, on the international front, Diners Card has gotten through a lot of change including the sale of Italy. What is the outlook there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I feel like we have really stabilized and positioned Diners to be able to grow from this point forward. And apart from FX rates, we saw some healthy growth, some of the best growth rates we've seen since we owned it. I think that Citi has larg
componenttext: Sure. Well, I feel like we have really stabilized and positioned Diners to be able to grow from this point forward. And apart from FX rates, we saw some healthy growth, some of the best growth rates we've seen since we owned it. I think that Citi has largely exited the franchisees that they were going to exit. We've gotten franchisees in the new hands, some very strong bank partners in China, India and Japan. And so -- and we've dramatically increased acceptance across the world. So Diners is a pretty small total volume but the trajectory, I think, it looks much better now. And certainly, selling Italy, I think, positions us much better from P&L perspective. The final thing I would add since Italy came up in the last question as well, I think we exited Italy, we took the hard decisions on the mortgage business to really position ourselves for the future. And so I feel like we are -- we had some one time last year, I think, they were relatively small to the total $3.5 billion spend compared to some other companies. But we prefer them to have even fewer and I think we've positioned ourselves, knock on wood, to half you're going forward, especially as we get through this look back. So I give you 2 answers for the price of one question.

componenttext: Yes. I think there's a little bit of elevated of cost in the fourth quarter and a little bit AMV cost. So I think as you continue to push the cards out, there's cost associated with that. On the flip side of the equation, I think, the fraud was actually up a little bit as you have the fraudsters trying to get in that, it was a last hit before while swiping was still very prevalent. So I think there's a combination of both sides of the same coin that you're seeing show up in that same line item.

componenttext: Sure. We continue to purely offer that through cross-selling. We achieve the targets that we set internally for the product last year just with the cross-sell. And it is my hope that by year end, we will finally be able to make it available more broadly. But we continue to enhance the operations, the functionality, the controls around AML/BSA in fraud and we have continued to learn a lot. And I think that one of the reasons we've taken longer to launch this one than others is because it is a very important and more complicated product than typical products out there. So we want to wait to go out until we are all buttoned down.
