componenttext: It would depend on the size of the new vintage, right? If you had a meteoric increase in the size of a vintage, that could impact it. But generally speaking, I think that's a reasonable proxy for looking at the stability of their credit environment.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries of Barclays.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up on that point because I think there's -- at least, I have some confusion on your comments, Mark. Because when you say reserving in kind of the 2.6%, 2.7% level, I mean, they've kind of consistently over for the last 4 quarters, ar
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on that point because I think there's -- at least, I have some confusion on your comments, Mark. Because when you say reserving in kind of the 2.6%, 2.7% level, I mean, they've kind of consistently over for the last 4 quarters, are you referring to the reserves for loans as opposed to the provisions for loans? Because provisions for loans really have bounced around a lot, and if -- they were 2.7% this quarter, but if we look at a world where you're guiding to charge-offs in the low 2s and we're now at 2.7% on a reserve-to-loan ratio, would that imply that with the absent really strong loan growth that the provision to loan should be lower in the coming quarters than they were this quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what we're specifically calling out with that number is the reserve rate for cards that we disclosed in our financial supplement, so it's just bounced around. I'm looking back December of '14, it was 2.63%. 2.79% in March of '15. 2.62% in June. 2.62% i
componenttext: So what we're specifically calling out with that number is the reserve rate for cards that we disclosed in our financial supplement, so it's just bounced around. I'm looking back December of '14, it was 2.63%. 2.79% in March of '15. 2.62% in June. 2.62% in September. 2.68% now. So it's pretty consistently in that 2.6%, 2.7% range. I would tell you based on the seasoning of the growth we've put on the books over the course of the last couple of years as well as the challenge that David has put in front of the team to accelerate loan growth as we go into this year as well, I would not expect the provisions to decrease. By the same token, I would very clearly state so that I'm not misunderstood, don't expect some giant increase in that card reserve rates right now based on what we currently see in our models. That obviously changes. But if you think about it, Mark, the next 6 months are pretty well known, right? So we're reserving for 12 months out. The next 6 months, we can pretty well see in the roll buckets. It's really that period of 6 to 12 months out where you've got a little bit of uncertainty, where your models get impacted to a degree by the macro variables and your assessment of the health and the strength of the economy and what that's going to do to our borrower. So there's always a little bit of uncertainty in this. It is a forecast. So by definition, it's wrong. You try and be as right as you can. We're something along the bottom of the credit cycle. We have been for a while, so there will be a little bit of volatility here. But what I always just try and remind everybody is this is a $1.8 billion balance sheet item, so a little bit of volatility drives some moves in EPS.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Donat of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Donat of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I just wanted to ask on the secured credit card and your launch of that. You're typically very methodical about new products, and I imagine this has been in development for some time. Can you give us some color on what sort of development process y
componenttext: David, I just wanted to ask on the secured credit card and your launch of that. You're typically very methodical about new products, and I imagine this has been in development for some time. Can you give us some color on what sort of development process you went through and what you might have considered adding or not adding with the card? Or just kind of understand when you guys launch something, I know you put a lot of investment into it. So what you're getting for it?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- and this has been in test for a while, so we have some -- we have experience with some accounts. And we got to the point where we had enough experience that we felt that we could make it an official launch. And I would say we're certainly seein
componenttext: Well, I -- and this has been in test for a while, so we have some -- we have experience with some accounts. And we got to the point where we had enough experience that we felt that we could make it an official launch. And I would say we're certainly seeing in the marketplace right now people that are in the lesser credits are seeing significant growth, and the prime market is really not growing hardly at all. And so we're not willing to sacrifice our credit to go into subprime, but what that this product allows us to do is to get people that might currently be considered subprime to get our product for us to be protected from losses because we have the security deposit, and to work with those customers, to graduate them into prime loans when they're ready. And so it is our way of new to credit or blemish credit in a way that protects our losses. And so I guess the final thing I'd say is we did a lot of market research, looking at competitive products. And we don't see anything in the marketplace that is like this. Most other cards are stripped-down cards. They don't have rewards. They don't have benefits. They service the cards offshore. This is a real Discover it Card with everything that comes with it, and the only thing unique is it's fully secured. And so when the credit improves, they continue that product, but it becomes unsecured.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just related to that. You say you're seeing more opportunity with the subprime side. And certainly, we see from other card issuers some pretty dramatic growth in loan balances in the subprime category. But are you seeing changes in consumer
componenttext: Okay. And then just related to that. You say you're seeing more opportunity with the subprime side. And certainly, we see from other card issuers some pretty dramatic growth in loan balances in the subprime category. But are you seeing changes in consumer behavior, like I hear anecdotes of millennials not embracing credit cards the same way that, say, baby boomers did? Is that any part of the thesis here or is that just in the background?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, because our -- it's probably a component because new to credit is part of it, and we are seeing a few more people that aren't establishing credit early on. And so they may need to start out with a secured card just because they just didn't get any c
componenttext: Well, because our -- it's probably a component because new to credit is part of it, and we are seeing a few more people that aren't establishing credit early on. And so they may need to start out with a secured card just because they just didn't get any credit, didn't get a credit history. So this helps address that need. A lot of what's happening, though, is the big bounce back, in my opinion, in the subprime market. Because I think that decline far more a few years ago than the prime did even, and there were a very few competitors in it. And now the very few people who are in subprime still, including the private labels that tend to have high yields and lower credits, are seeing a big bounce back. But it's a smaller segment than the prime segment. I think the more important thing for us is to gain share in prime, but what we want to do is identify the people that can become prime over time and get them started before they're all the way there to prime.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John Hecht of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John Hecht of Jefferies.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll ask one about margin. You're guiding for a flat margin. Is that just, I guess, you're not anticipating many rate hikes this year? Or is there something else going on with the trajectory if rates, yields and cost of fund that we should think a
componenttext: I guess I'll ask one about margin. You're guiding for a flat margin. Is that just, I guess, you're not anticipating many rate hikes this year? Or is there something else going on with the trajectory if rates, yields and cost of fund that we should think about?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we are working off of an operative assumption of 1 or 2 rate increases this year as opposed to the 4 we were looking at in the forward curve towards the very end of last year. I would say we have not yet seen the benefit really of repricing in the card
componenttext: So we are working off of an operative assumption of 1 or 2 rate increases this year as opposed to the 4 we were looking at in the forward curve towards the very end of last year. I would say we have not yet seen the benefit really of repricing in the card book fully from the Fed rate increase because we don't reprice card customers until cycle date, so you will get some lift from that coming in. So I think what we're trying to say in NIM is there's an upward bias in NIM. We're well positioned right now. We may choose to invest some of that increase in NIM in marketing dollars, some promotional dollars and other places to really drive the growth that I think is the key thing we understand the market wants to see from us. So we may take some of that excess and reinvest it. Absent doing that, you would have more NIM expansion than you're likely to actually see.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And separate and distinct question. You did speak to the typical trajectory of your prime accounts and the utilization rates. But just looking at your MasterCard study, you've had elevated payment rates for sometime. I'm wondering if you can speak t
componenttext: Okay. And separate and distinct question. You did speak to the typical trajectory of your prime accounts and the utilization rates. But just looking at your MasterCard study, you've had elevated payment rates for sometime. I'm wondering if you can speak to kind of just generic changes you see in customer utilization or payment behaviors. Is there something that's changed? You think that's going to take a while to shift or -- that, I guess, worthy of discussion?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just say that the mix between balance transfer and sales can impact payment rates along with credit. And so certainly credit is great, and so that tends to relate to a bit higher payments rates than one would otherwise have. But as we have s
componenttext: Well, I would just say that the mix between balance transfer and sales can impact payment rates along with credit. And so certainly credit is great, and so that tends to relate to a bit higher payments rates than one would otherwise have. But as we have shifted to a little more transaction volume turning into loans versus a little less balance transfer on new accounts, that is going to impact the payment rates, and so people will tend to pay more of their sales down than they will of their balance transfer down.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so based on the, I guess, the current marketing strategy, is that -- the elevated payment stream, is that -- do you think that stays around for a while? Or would we see that shift?
componenttext: And so based on the, I guess, the current marketing strategy, is that -- the elevated payment stream, is that -- do you think that stays around for a while? Or would we see that shift?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think that we're forecasting a big change in that relationship.
componenttext: I don't think that we're forecasting a big change in that relationship.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Henry Coffey of Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Henry Coffey of Sterne Agee.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when you look at some of the onetime expense items outside of the AML/BSA spending this year and last and some of the changes, you've closed down the mortgage company and then, of course, you sold off Italy. Can you give us a sense of sort of what t
componenttext: Mark, when you look at some of the onetime expense items outside of the AML/BSA spending this year and last and some of the changes, you've closed down the mortgage company and then, of course, you sold off Italy. Can you give us a sense of sort of what the net impact of those 2 developments for? I mean, I know revenue goes down from those 2 but so does in cost.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Henry, some of the onetime expenses or some of the revenue reductions you see in the fee line actually are accretive to the P&L, right? So for example, we called out, I think, $74 million in loss revenue next year from the mortgage business.
componenttext: Yes. I think, Henry, some of the onetime expenses or some of the revenue reductions you see in the fee line actually are accretive to the P&L, right? So for example, we called out, I think, $74 million in loss revenue next year from the mortgage business. I have to remind everybody when we exited the mortgage business, we said the reason we were doing it or one of the reasons we were doing it is it was not P&L accretive, right? So I mean, I think that's a very good point there. If I think about the expense base generally right now, I think we are very lean. We are very efficient today as evidenced by that efficiency ratio. We are always looking to find further efficiencies to get operating synergies and drive even greater returns on that. As I said earlier, we do have some levers we can pull if we get there. But I think those are the kinds of levers you pull when you're in a turn in the credit cycle and you see things. Right now, we're still trying to drive growth, right? And I don't think you drive growth by kind of coming in and try and to whack the heck out of expenses, especially when you're already as efficient on that as we are. So we're trying to balance prudent investments in growth, maybe investing some of this additional NIM to drive that going forward.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the Payment Services business, on the international front, what's --  Diners Card has gone through a lot of change including the sale of Italy. What is the outlook there?
componenttext: In the Payment Services business, on the international front, what's --  Diners Card has gone through a lot of change including the sale of Italy. What is the outlook there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I feel like we have really stabilized and positioned Diners to be able to grow from this point forward. And apart from FX rates, we saw some healthy growth, some of the best growth we have seen since we owned it. I think that Citi has largely
componenttext: Sure. Well, I feel like we have really stabilized and positioned Diners to be able to grow from this point forward. And apart from FX rates, we saw some healthy growth, some of the best growth we have seen since we owned it. I think that Citi has largely exited the franchisees that they were going to exit. We've gotten franchisees in the new hands, some very strong bank partners in China, India and Japan. And so -- and we've dramatically increased acceptance across the world. So Diners is a pretty small total volume. But the trajectory, I think, looks much better now. And certainly, selling the Italy, I think, positions us much better from a P&L perspective. The final thing I would add since Italy came up in the last question as well, I think we exited Italy, we took the hard decisions on the mortgage business to really position ourselves for the future. And so I feel like we are -- we had some onetimes last year. I think they were relatively small to the total $3.5 billion spend compared to some other companies. But we prefer to have even fewer, and I think we've positioned ourselves, knock on wood, to have fewer going forward, especially as we get through this look back. So I gave you 2 answers for the price of one question.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jason Harbes of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jason Harbes of Wells Fargo.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think there was little bit of elevated fraud cost to the fourth quarter.
componenttext: No, I think there was little bit of elevated fraud cost to the fourth quarter.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: And a little EMV cost.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a little bit of EMV cost, so I think as you continue to push the cards out, there's cost associated with that. On the flip side of the equation, I think the fraud was actually up a little bit as you have the fraudsters trying to get in that one last h
componenttext: And a little bit of EMV cost, so I think as you continue to push the cards out, there's cost associated with that. On the flip side of the equation, I think the fraud was actually up a little bit as you have the fraudsters trying to get in that one last hit before -- while swiping is still very prevalent. So I think there's a combination of both sides of the same coin that you're seeing show up in that line item.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Remember on EMV, the rollout for the industry is still on process. There's a lot of retailers that haven't put it in, activated it yet.
componenttext: Remember on EMV, the rollout for the industry is still on process. There's a lot of retailers that haven't put it in, activated it yet.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up, can you guys give us an update on how the Cashback Checking is progressing?
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up, can you guys give us an update on how the Cashback Checking is progressing?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We continue to purely offer that through cross-sell. We achieve the targets that we set internally for the product last year just with the cross-sell. And it is my hope that by year-end, we will finally be able to make it available more broadly. But
componenttext: Sure. We continue to purely offer that through cross-sell. We achieve the targets that we set internally for the product last year just with the cross-sell. And it is my hope that by year-end, we will finally be able to make it available more broadly. But we continue to enhance the operations, the functionality, the controls around AML/BSA and fraud. And we have continued to learn a lot, and I think that one of the reasons we've taken longer to launch this one than others is because it is a very important and more complicated product than typical products out there. So we want to wait to go broad until we are all buttoned down.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Bob Napoli of William Blair.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Bob Napoli of William Blair.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The personal loan business, I'd -- the reserve was up quite a bit in personal loans and a little bit of increase in charge-offs and delinquencies, and the growth rate also continued to slow. Was there -- is that the competitive environment in personal loa
componenttext: The personal loan business, I'd -- the reserve was up quite a bit in personal loans and a little bit of increase in charge-offs and delinquencies, and the growth rate also continued to slow. Was there -- is that the competitive environment in personal loans? Is there something are you incrementally concerned about credit in that business? And with the competitive environment with the lending gloves, do you expect that to, at some point over the next year or so, that there is going to be something that's going to derail some of those Internet -- rapidly growing Internet competitors?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll tackle the reserving question, and David can tackle the strategic element of the question. I would say, Bob, what's driving it really is seasoning of the portfolio, right? I mean, you think you've seen double-digit growth rates there over the course
componenttext: I'll tackle the reserving question, and David can tackle the strategic element of the question. I would say, Bob, what's driving it really is seasoning of the portfolio, right? I mean, you think you've seen double-digit growth rates there over the course of a number of years. Personal loans don't season radically differently than credit card loans do. There's a little bit of a change in the shape of the curve, and it's not exactly the same. But they tend to season after origination. You don't get a lot of first payment defaults when you do it prudently, thankfully. So I would say it's just seasoning. Don't expect any major deterioration of any kind to that portfolio, and the seasoning we are seeing is in line with expectations.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what I would say on the strategic side is we had record originations this year in that business even with literally hundreds of marketplace competitors, volume entering and volume per share. And I think that part of the reason is that our -- the peopl
componenttext: And what I would say on the strategic side is we had record originations this year in that business even with literally hundreds of marketplace competitors, volume entering and volume per share. And I think that part of the reason is that our -- the people that we're targeting tend to be very different than the credits that most of those are targeting. Our average FICO score is 750, 760. The figures I've seen from the leading companies in the marketplace space is sub-700 average, and that's -- when every 20 points of FICO means a doubling of credit losses, that is a very big difference in target markets. And so we think that we're still the leader in prime originations in the space. In terms of whether there will be a shake out, I'm sure there will be a shakeout. I'm sure some people will survive, but I don't think that they'll be hundreds of competitors. And it is an unproven model to the cycle, and I believe that our model of originating and holding versus just a originate and sale that relies solely on growth and that you stop originating, you don't have revenue, I believe that our relationship, owning the credits, being able to finance it on our balance sheet and not being -- not having to rely on securitization markets that we have seen can completely dry up in a crisis, I think is a more sustainable model. And so it's -- I really like our position in that business.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow-up question, just in the spirit of trying to accelerate growth, just any thoughts on the trends in the student loan business? And then if Ariba -- the -- how the Ariba partnership is going? And if that can be a material driver, h
componenttext: Great. And then my follow-up question, just in the spirit of trying to accelerate growth, just any thoughts on the trends in the student loan business? And then if Ariba -- the -- how the Ariba partnership is going? And if that can be a material driver, how long does it take? Or could that business ever be a material driver of revenue growth and earnings growth?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, answering your third question, I guess, first, we think that Ariba is going to continue to produce a lot of volume growth in the short term. It'll be a while before it becomes a material contributor, profitability-wise. We also think there may be so
componenttext: Well, answering your third question, I guess, first, we think that Ariba is going to continue to produce a lot of volume growth in the short term. It'll be a while before it becomes a material contributor, profitability-wise. We also think there may be some ancillary services that may provide some revenues that having that product, we're working on adding some additional functionality that may produce some revenue potential. On student loans, I'm not sure I fully understood your question on the student loans.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the growth rate outlook for that business, are you assuming -- do you expect to see steady trends? Or are there anything -- is there anything you're working on to accelerate growth in the student loan portfolio business? Or are there any things th
componenttext: Just on the growth rate outlook for that business, are you assuming -- do you expect to see steady trends? Or are there anything -- is there anything you're working on to accelerate growth in the student loan portfolio business? Or are there any things there concerning that would slow it down from a regulatory standpoint or otherwise?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I expect to originate more this year than we did last year, and -- but I don't expect a dramatic acceleration. But I do think the credit trends look great. The needs continue from customers, and I expect us to originate a bit more.
componenttext: No, I expect to originate more this year than we did last year, and -- but I don't expect a dramatic acceleration. But I do think the credit trends look great. The needs continue from customers, and I expect us to originate a bit more.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bob, it is helpful to look at the organic book versus the acquired book because the acquired we bought a number of years ago is essentially a runoff.
componenttext: And Bob, it is helpful to look at the organic book versus the acquired book because the acquired we bought a number of years ago is essentially a runoff.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have no further questions at this time. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Bill Franklin for final remarks.
componenttext: We have no further questions at this time. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Bill Franklin for final remarks.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. We'd like to thank everyone for joining us. If you have any other follow-up questions, feel free to call Investor Relations. Have a good night.
componenttext: Thanks. We'd like to thank everyone for joining us. If you have any other follow-up questions, feel free to call Investor Relations. Have a good night.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
