componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say with respect to tax benefit, it relates to a matter that's disclosed in our SEC filings. It's the OID treatment of Cashback Bonus. It's for an extended period from the 1999 to 2007 and it's a pretty complex matter over a number of years.
componenttext: Yes. I would say with respect to tax benefit, it relates to a matter that's disclosed in our SEC filings. It's the OID treatment of Cashback Bonus. It's for an extended period from the 1999 to 2007 and it's a pretty complex matter over a number of years. So we're still in the process of putting a fine point on it. I guess what I would say is on the tax line itself, it looks to be kind of on a mid-8-figure kind of number for the quarter -- in the quarter that we would indeed recognize. So I think that probably gives you a good triangulation for how to think about it.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question, you got a little bit better margin expansion than we expected from pricing prime rate. Is all that priced in the portfolio? Or is there some kind of a residual upside as we stretch in the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then second question, you got a little bit better margin expansion than we expected from pricing prime rate. Is all that priced in the portfolio? Or is there some kind of a residual upside as we stretch in the second quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it really relates to we talked last call about natural a upward bias in NIM in the book, and that we thought we are -- might lean more heavily in the promotional activity. We didn't end up doing that as it turned out because we saw a growth re
componenttext: No. I think it really relates to we talked last call about natural a upward bias in NIM in the book, and that we thought we are -- might lean more heavily in the promotional activity. We didn't end up doing that as it turned out because we saw a growth reaccelerating along the lines of what we are hoping for from a cadence perspective. So I think I would say as you look forward over this year, I kind of discourage you from flattening NIM out and just kind of saying, this is where it will be for the rest of the year. I think there will be relative stability in NIM, but it could be affected by promotional activity, that revolving behavior Sanjay asked about a second ago, and, obviously, any further moves to Fed mix because of that positive bias and positioning.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, appreciate the detail.
componenttext: Okay, appreciate the detail.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nash with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nash with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just a follow up from 1 of the questions that Sanjay asked. Can you just talk about how the efforts to accelerate loan growth is going? Last quarter, you laid out a handful of initiatives and just wondered if you could just share how they're going,
componenttext: David, just a follow up from 1 of the questions that Sanjay asked. Can you just talk about how the efforts to accelerate loan growth is going? Last quarter, you laid out a handful of initiatives and just wondered if you could just share how they're going, maybe any of the metrics you have account openings, activations, help us understand kind of what the pipeline could look like for the rest of the year?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think that the best indicator that our efforts are working in total is to look at actual loan growth. And so we accelerated from just over 3% to about 4% year-over-year. And as you know, we had just established a new higher 4% to 6% full yea
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think that the best indicator that our efforts are working in total is to look at actual loan growth. And so we accelerated from just over 3% to about 4% year-over-year. And as you know, we had just established a new higher 4% to 6% full year target also for total loan growth, also for long term to be in that target. So I'm pleased that all of our various actions have moved us into that lower end of the range and we're certainly taking efforts to continue to move higher in that range if we're able to later this year. And I'd say those efforts include, I mentioned more new accounts, we are continuing to look for places where we can appropriately increase credit lines or extend credit where we expect good and are achieving good results. Also some of our new features have been well-received, whether it's some of our cashback, Freeze It, continued take-up of free FICO scores. So I'd say that we have -- I don't think there's a single home run kind of initiative for loan growth, but a whole lot of singles that we are working on across the franchise.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Ryan, I'd add on to that just quickly, the loan growth continues to be close to 50-50 new accounts as well as existing accounts, which is a really healthy way to see that loan growth coming in. And if you look at the $2.2 billion in card receivables
componenttext: And, Ryan, I'd add on to that just quickly, the loan growth continues to be close to 50-50 new accounts as well as existing accounts, which is a really healthy way to see that loan growth coming in. And if you look at the $2.2 billion in card receivables growth over the course of the last year, over 80% of that is coming in what I'll call the standard merchandise bucket, right? Customers are just simply using their cards, exhibiting the behaviors that drive the kind of long-term profitability we want to see out of the book. So that it feels very, very good.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I could just ask 1 other question on credit. If I look this quarter, charge-offs were relatively stable, delinquencies are relatively stable, up a couple of basis points. I'm just wondering how do we think about the puts and takes? And, I guess, Mar
componenttext: Maybe I could just ask 1 other question on credit. If I look this quarter, charge-offs were relatively stable, delinquencies are relatively stable, up a couple of basis points. I'm just wondering how do we think about the puts and takes? And, I guess, Mark, more specifically, since last quarter, there's a wide range on outcomes for reserves in 1Q. Can you just help us how to think about the pace of reserve builds from here, given there was relief in the second quarter last year, I don't think you're anticipating reserve this time. Just wondering how we should think about reserve builds from here?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Ryan, happy to be -- I think from my perspective, the $50 million-or-so we built this quarter, I continue to describe that as essentially noise on a $1.9 billion balance sheet item. And that's never going to be exactly flat, it's going to be bumpi
componenttext: Yes. So Ryan, happy to be -- I think from my perspective, the $50 million-or-so we built this quarter, I continue to describe that as essentially noise on a $1.9 billion balance sheet item. And that's never going to be exactly flat, it's going to be bumping along with it one way or the other. I would say, provisioning from this point forward is going to be continue a factor of loan growth and the seasoning of that loan growth. I would not encourage anyone to expect a reserve release in the second quarter. By the same token, I would not encourage anyone to try and take off in provisioning in the second quarter either. It feels again it's going to be very much a function of loan growth and the seasoning of that loan growth and it feels like we're in a good general band.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Henry Coffey with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Henry Coffey with Sterne Agee.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the network side of the business obviously, Diners Club started to show some positive life and your expenses were lower. What are the next step to look forward there?
componenttext: When you look at the network side of the business obviously, Diners Club started to show some positive life and your expenses were lower. What are the next step to look forward there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, I am pleased with the growth that you acknowledged in Diners Club at some of our new partners that have come online in recent years in places like China and other areas start to grow more robustly, and same with Network Partners with the vo
componenttext: Well, I think, I am pleased with the growth that you acknowledged in Diners Club at some of our new partners that have come online in recent years in places like China and other areas start to grow more robustly, and same with Network Partners with the volume appearing very nicely networks around the world increasingly coming online and using our network for global acceptance. And I'd say the headwind has been quite severe in the larger segment, which is PULSE. And as I mentioned in my comments, after several years of a down draft following the [indiscernible] and pave actions that Visa took as well as loss of 1 major customer, it feels like we have reached a plateau with PULSE. And I think after this year, what we're looking to do is to go back to growing PULSE. And we had a bunch of years of very robust growth in market share and volume in PULSE, up until the actions shortly after Durbin. And then we went in and we're working to have that grow as well while maintaining those newer areas like Diners and Network Partners and AribaPay where we're seeing very nice growth, add on as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the overhead side of the equation, Mark, when does the AML/BSA, when do those extra expenses sort of dwindle away?
componenttext: Great. And then on the overhead side of the equation, Mark, when does the AML/BSA, when do those extra expenses sort of dwindle away?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Henry, I'd put it in 2 buckets. The look back project that we continue to call out specifically, I think we see that in terms of dollars and spend largely drawing to a close next quarter at this point in time. So I think we can see that pieces kind of
componenttext: So Henry, I'd put it in 2 buckets. The look back project that we continue to call out specifically, I think we see that in terms of dollars and spend largely drawing to a close next quarter at this point in time. So I think we can see that pieces kind of close to being done with the casework. I think the other piece of AML/BSA is really what I would call building out the AML/BSA process within the organization, we're largely covered a lot of that increased expense through funding[ph] efficiencies elsewhere in the business model. So I'll just take you back to a second in my prepared remarks where I said roughly a 40% efficiency ratio all in. But if you exclude that look back that we expect to be bleed off to the next quarter, we're printing about a 38.5% efficiency ratio this quarter. Now I think expenses are never flat. I think next quarter they maybe inflated a little bit as we bring somethings across the line and all. But I would stand by the expense guidance we gave at the beginning of the year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Donat with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Donat with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to explore of the personal loans business because we've seen that the deceleration of the growth there over the last couple of years and some of that's coincided with that entrance of the marketplace lenders, the peer-to-peer lenders. Are you seein
componenttext: I want to explore of the personal loans business because we've seen that the deceleration of the growth there over the last couple of years and some of that's coincided with that entrance of the marketplace lenders, the peer-to-peer lenders. Are you seeing any changes in the competitive landscape there? And would you have any hopes of getting the loan growth back up into the double digits in the coming year or so?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would encourage you to look at the dollars of loan growth, which last year was an all-time record for growth in our personal loans business, and we continue to grow that very nicely and there was -- the only thing that really changed is the denomi
componenttext: Well, I would encourage you to look at the dollars of loan growth, which last year was an all-time record for growth in our personal loans business, and we continue to grow that very nicely and there was -- the only thing that really changed is the denominator is getting bigger. So percentage is dropping because the denominator, even as the dollars of originations have gotten bigger. So I wouldn't cite market entrants or competition as being a slow down. I think going forward, we do think our model is more sustainable. Since it's going on our balance sheet, we are not -- we have long-term customer relationships, we are profitable, in contrast to some of the competitors who are printing some more difficult headlines right now. And so I think we have a very sustainable business model that we continue to grow. We think well and appropriately.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the marketing side, I guess, there are some timing issues that Mark had commented on. Is there -- so it's down 11% year-over-year. Would you expect, Mark, to be more flat year-on-year going forward or even up? Or is it just -- I was hopi
componenttext: Okay. And just on the marketing side, I guess, there are some timing issues that Mark had commented on. Is there -- so it's down 11% year-over-year. Would you expect, Mark, to be more flat year-on-year going forward or even up? Or is it just -- I was hoping for a ballpark in terms of year-on-year comparisons from here?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, what I would savor is we're continuing to really manage the interplay between marketing spend as well as rewards rate, right? And as we're leaning a little bit more in the rewards rate with our double new account promotion and some other thing
componenttext: So I guess, what I would savor is we're continuing to really manage the interplay between marketing spend as well as rewards rate, right? And as we're leaning a little bit more in the rewards rate with our double new account promotion and some other things we're doing, I think we're viewing that as interchangeable with the marketing spend. So to some degree, some of the decline in marketing spend you see is related to that. The other thing I would say is there's, obviously, some timing of spend, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, that occurs throughout the course of the year. The first quarter was not a particularly high point from a marketing standpoint. And then the other thing I would just point out is in the year-over-year comparison, we did have the mortgage marketing spend in their last year, which I would remind you kind of have to peel back out for comparability. So those are really kind of the bits and pieces, puts and takes. I mean, I think, ultimately, we continue to have a very disciplined approach to marketing spend, we want to make sure we're getting the results we see for it. Again when we saw we weren't getting some of the results through some of the listing sites and other channels last year, in the middle of the year, we pulled back on this because we want to make sure we're driving to kind of growth that's going to drive the right kind of long-term profitability.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Don Fandetti with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Don Fandetti with Citigroup.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, can you talk a little bit about the rewards being so low this quarter and how you're thinking about that in context of the full year guidance? And then maybe provide a little bit of color on your thoughts about the industry in general on rewards, we
componenttext: Mark, can you talk a little bit about the rewards being so low this quarter and how you're thinking about that in context of the full year guidance? And then maybe provide a little bit of color on your thoughts about the industry in general on rewards, we're starting to see some pretty high offers in the 5% range. I wanted to get your updated thoughts there.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll tackle the rate and dollar questions and I'll let David talk about the industry trend. I guess, what I would say is we're still very comfortable with the full year rewards rate at 115 basis points. A couple of things to think about there. Number 1
componenttext: So I'll tackle the rate and dollar questions and I'll let David talk about the industry trend. I guess, what I would say is we're still very comfortable with the full year rewards rate at 115 basis points. A couple of things to think about there. Number 1, we're going to continue running our double rewards programs for new accounts at least for the next quarter and maybe beyond. And I would say, from the standpoint of the rewards perspective, it is down a little bit from where we were in the fourth quarter, but there's generally a peak seasonality effect in the fourth quarter. And in addition, the fourth quarter was elevated because of Apple Pay and the special promotion we ran in most recent fourth quarter. So I think we're up about 4 basis points year-over-year in terms of rewards rate. So that 115 at a full year basis feels like a good rate to triangulate.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just say that it's no surprise that competitors are aggressively offering cash rewards programs because it's what consumers most want and it is just very attractive to consumers. And I think that we are in a -- we've been at this game for 30 y
componenttext: And I would just say that it's no surprise that competitors are aggressively offering cash rewards programs because it's what consumers most want and it is just very attractive to consumers. And I think that we are in a -- we've been at this game for 30 years now. And I think that our combination of 1% cashback, 5% rotating categories, additional value coming from our Network Partners who add value that doesn't hit our expense line, the elimination of breakage in the back-end that we've put in place a year ago, the consumers still tell us that regardless of top line, headline numbers, most consumers we think really like our program. And we think we have the right balance between sustainable cost and great value to consumers.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, you don't see, you're not sensing sort of a big step forward in terms of accelerated or reward offers. It's more of just a continued, steady, competitive environment?
componenttext: So David, you don't see, you're not sensing sort of a big step forward in terms of accelerated or reward offers. It's more of just a continued, steady, competitive environment?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. I think it accelerated a few years back. Since that time, the competitors have swapped between years. 2 years ago, there was 1 competitor was heavy, they kind of pulled back and another 1 came in. And so I think we're at a fairly steady state,
componenttext: I think so. I think it accelerated a few years back. Since that time, the competitors have swapped between years. 2 years ago, there was 1 competitor was heavy, they kind of pulled back and another 1 came in. And so I think we're at a fairly steady state, which is in an intense environment, but I don't really see it getting worse from here. And the history of the industry has been when people have something that is sustainable, they eventually peel it back. So my guess is when some of those competitors pell back, someone else will hit into the frame. So we're kind of competing as if this is going to be, we think it's in the steady state, there's a lot of competition and we have to win this game from value perspective and profit perspective.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Ho with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Ho with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on credit. Have you seen any, on the margin credit deterioration, related to energy or even some of your lower FICO customers? And a follow-up on that would be is, with credit deterioration potentially come from some of your compe
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on credit. Have you seen any, on the margin credit deterioration, related to energy or even some of your lower FICO customers? And a follow-up on that would be is, with credit deterioration potentially come from some of your competitors, increasing credit lines or just loosening that up over time?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Mark, I'll take the first stab and David can pile on. I would say with respect to the energy related part of the question, we have seen some deterioration in the energy-related states. But I would describe it really as prior to the significant
componenttext: David, it's Mark, I'll take the first stab and David can pile on. I would say with respect to the energy related part of the question, we have seen some deterioration in the energy-related states. But I would describe it really as prior to the significant drop in oil prices, all those markets were performing better than the national average for our portfolio. They basically come down to the national average for our portfolio. So it's something we're watching very closely, but it's not something that currently gives us significant pause or concern. All the credit metrics we're watching in the portfolio really speak to a continued benign environment, with, again as I said earlier, reserving from here really a more a function of loan growth. David, I don't know if there's anything you want to add to that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I agree. I think in general, I think about energy exposure as being the business kind of loan related, which we're not in. And I think on the consumer side, it certainly has an impact any time there's loss of jobs or income in the industry, it affects
componenttext: No, I agree. I think in general, I think about energy exposure as being the business kind of loan related, which we're not in. And I think on the consumer side, it certainly has an impact any time there's loss of jobs or income in the industry, it affects consumers, but it's even with the high percentage reductions in employment in that industry, it's just not that huge of a number on a national level since we're completely national in scope. It's not going to be as an example like the mortgage that hit lots of consumers nationally. It's pretty localized impact.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then are you seeing or potentially expecting any pressure from more credit lines being offered by competitors? I mean, that servicing ratios have kind of, say, flat mortgage that has been replaced by a little bit on the consumer side in terms of
componenttext: Okay. And then are you seeing or potentially expecting any pressure from more credit lines being offered by competitors? I mean, that servicing ratios have kind of, say, flat mortgage that has been replaced by a little bit on the consumer side in terms of leverage. So any thoughts there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that -- I think there maybe less if rates slowly rise, there's probably a little bit less refinancing that will go on particularly in first mortgages. And but I don't see a big impact in the near term. I think we're in a fairly steady state
componenttext: Well, I think that -- I think there maybe less if rates slowly rise, there's probably a little bit less refinancing that will go on particularly in first mortgages. And but I don't see a big impact in the near term. I think we're in a fairly steady state in terms of the credit card industry growing at a slow rate.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And consumer balance sheet, it still seemed like they're in pretty good shape, David. When you just look at the obligation ratios and when you look at the debt burden that they're carrying, it's a very different scenario now than it was the last time
componenttext: Yes. And consumer balance sheet, it still seemed like they're in pretty good shape, David. When you just look at the obligation ratios and when you look at the debt burden that they're carrying, it's a very different scenario now than it was the last time we were at this point in the cycle. So not dissuading you from your belief that we are a cyclical business, we are. But it just feels like that consumer, that burden, is still fairly manageable at this point.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, 1 more question on the interchange relative to volumes. Interchange fees, it looked like they rose 5% versus volumes closer to 4%, flying[ph] a little bit of a higher margin there. Is that just one time? Or is that a mix shift? Or how do you see tha
componenttext: Mark, 1 more question on the interchange relative to volumes. Interchange fees, it looked like they rose 5% versus volumes closer to 4%, flying[ph] a little bit of a higher margin there. Is that just one time? Or is that a mix shift? Or how do you see that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really more a function of spend mix and the fourth quarter tends to see a lot of big bulk spending around the holiday period. And in the first quarter, you tend to see a higher percentage of the mix being smaller merchants. So it's really more mix dr
componenttext: It's really more a function of spend mix and the fourth quarter tends to see a lot of big bulk spending around the holiday period. And in the first quarter, you tend to see a higher percentage of the mix being smaller merchants. So it's really more mix driven than anything else, David.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just ask on expenses. The other expense line was going to really came in later than expected, down quite a bit. Just want to get color around that line item.
componenttext: I wanted to just ask on expenses. The other expense line was going to really came in later than expected, down quite a bit. Just want to get color around that line item.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The real big driver in other expenses and the similar quarter last year, we had about a $20 million addition to the legal reserve, that was absent this quarter. Beyond that, I would say, it's just generally back to what I said earlier that focus on -
componenttext: Yes. The real big driver in other expenses and the similar quarter last year, we had about a $20 million addition to the legal reserve, that was absent this quarter. Beyond that, I would say, it's just generally back to what I said earlier that focus on -- if you exclude the AML/BSA look back really trying to find ways to look at the expenses that are creeping into the model from a regulatory and compliance standpoint, making sure we're finding efficiencies and ways to cover those. So I think it reflects the discipline on that front, coupled with the lack of a $20 million addition to the legal reserve.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So therefore, the -- getting noise on my line here, I'm sorry. So basically, that $100 million -- that $107 million that appears sustainable at this level?
componenttext: Right. So therefore, the -- getting noise on my line here, I'm sorry. So basically, that $100 million -- that $107 million that appears sustainable at this level?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I would say, expenses do tend to balance around quarter-over-quarter. So I wouldn't specifically encourage you to cycle to the $107 million. I think what I would say is as we've given guidance for total expenses, we really being slightly north
componenttext: Yes. Again, I would say, expenses do tend to balance around quarter-over-quarter. So I wouldn't specifically encourage you to cycle to the $107 million. I think what I would say is as we've given guidance for total expenses, we really being slightly north of 3.5 build for the year anything is how I would describe it back on the fourth quarter call and we'll stand by that guidance. And I think I'll stand by the earlier comments on the other line as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then 1 more. On the card yield, I mean, up quite a bit. Year-over-year, 37 bps, up 22 link quarter. I know, it's a function of both higher rates in terms of Fed move, but also the mix. Can you just talk to us how we should think about that going
componenttext: Okay. And then 1 more. On the card yield, I mean, up quite a bit. Year-over-year, 37 bps, up 22 link quarter. I know, it's a function of both higher rates in terms of Fed move, but also the mix. Can you just talk to us how we should think about that going forward in terms of the magnitude of incremental upside that we could see that as the mix evolves?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what I would say is you now have the prime rate increases already priced into the portfolio, right? I'd say that's there. Obviously, further prime rate increases would potentially have a bearing on it. But assuming the prime rate stays where
componenttext: Yes. I think what I would say is you now have the prime rate increases already priced into the portfolio, right? I'd say that's there. Obviously, further prime rate increases would potentially have a bearing on it. But assuming the prime rate stays where the prime rate is, I think that is baked in. The other part of it is a much higher component of revolving balances in the portfolio, right, due to that real strong focus on revolving consumer. And the success we've had there, I would say given what's happened with the revolve rate, I wouldn't expect any significant increases in revolve rates from here. So from that perspective, I would go back and just generally say, if you think about it in a NIM card perspective as a posted specifically, a card yield perspective, it feels like you did have -- I'll call it again a relatively stable NIM from this level of but you have some diminishing over the course of the year in a stable environment. But again, I would just point out that could be impacted by we still make a decision to that would have on muting impact there. Of all great would have an impact and again, further prime rate increases would have an impact as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bill Carcache with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bill Carcache with Nomura.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions on CCAR. First, relating to last year's, is it reasonable to assume that you guys would seek to max out? I think it was the $2.2 billion authorization that you received last year, which I think would imply about $480 million o
componenttext: I have a couple of questions on CCAR. First, relating to last year's, is it reasonable to assume that you guys would seek to max out? I think it was the $2.2 billion authorization that you received last year, which I think would imply about $480 million of buyback in the next quarter. And then separately, relating to the upcoming CCAR, broadly speaking and certainly at a high level. Is it reasonable to expect that you guys are continuing to accrue capital to customers in good health? We've got unemployment rate at the same level, although the starting point is a little bit lower. So the delta is higher, but you put all the pieces together. And would it be reasonable to assume that you kind of continue to prime closer to 100% payout ratio rather than farther away from it?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I think about CCAR, I'll parse out there's a bunch of questions embedded there. So I'll kind of try and touch on them and if I miss one, I'll just come back with the follow-up. I think with respect to repurchased gains, we've never given any specifi
componenttext: So if I think about CCAR, I'll parse out there's a bunch of questions embedded there. So I'll kind of try and touch on them and if I miss one, I'll just come back with the follow-up. I think with respect to repurchased gains, we've never given any specific guidance on that front. But I would just kind of say, I wouldn't see any reason to expect a radically dissimilar cadence in 2Q to kind of what you've seen would be the way I would think about it. In terms of the overall approach to how we think about CCAR, I would say, over the course of the last couple of years, we've continued to make what I described as prudently aggressive asks. And every year, they've been slightly more aggressive. I would assume that a reasonable person should assume that we don't see any reason to change that. We recognize we have excess capital today, and we are working diligently within the confines of CCAR process to be able to return as much of that as prudently possible.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might just add on, I think typically, we've seen the last few years the Fed scenario's getting tougher, not easier, which impacts not also as our processes have mature and have greater comfort. We have continued to move into our position that have actua
componenttext: I might just add on, I think typically, we've seen the last few years the Fed scenario's getting tougher, not easier, which impacts not also as our processes have mature and have greater comfort. We have continued to move into our position that have actually been working towards our targeted levels. And you've seen our capital, you easy our capital ratios today a bit lower than they were last year. We bought back almost 8% of our stock in the last year. And every year, we'd love to move it a little more quickly towards the target levels and every year, we're trying to take steps to do that. But we also we just can't -- we can't get to the target, we won't get approval to get to the target in one fell swoop.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Think about it like a constrained optimization. I mean, it drove the total yield last year something on the order of 10% between dividends and buybacks. So we feel like we are -- we're being respectful of our shareholders capital and appropriately be
componenttext: Yes. Think about it like a constrained optimization. I mean, it drove the total yield last year something on the order of 10% between dividends and buybacks. So we feel like we are -- we're being respectful of our shareholders capital and appropriately being prudently aggressive in our asks. Again the cadence having been more aggressive every year, I think a reasonable person would assume we wouldn't see a meaningful reason to change that cadence.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, extremely helpful. If I may squeeze one more in on expenses. Just a clarification, Mark, I believe you said earlier that the look back project was drawing to a close next quarter. Should we interpret that to mean that there will be 1 more quar
componenttext: Understood, extremely helpful. If I may squeeze one more in on expenses. Just a clarification, Mark, I believe you said earlier that the look back project was drawing to a close next quarter. Should we interpret that to mean that there will be 1 more quarter with the other non, I guess, nonrecurring BSA AML cost that would result in a differential between the operating efficiency and the adjusted operating efficiency ratio before they converge? Or will they converge starting next quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think you're thinking about it right, I'll go with your former characterization. There will be 1 more quarter where those costs are in there. And the good news is, I think we are comfortable that we're approaching the end of the case review portion
componenttext: No. I think you're thinking about it right, I'll go with your former characterization. There will be 1 more quarter where those costs are in there. And the good news is, I think we are comfortable that we're approaching the end of the case review portion of it, which is the big dollar portion of the project itself. So I would expect to see those yet and that's why I alluded to the fact that while we're standing buy our expense guidance for the year, I think we don't expect expenses to be linear across the remaining 3 quarters and 2Q may actually prove to be the high point quite honestly.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Howlett of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Howlett of UBS.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just go on the funding side, with the [indiscernible]. Can you just go over a little bit on the deposits, how far out you went? And then on the 2 ABS securitizations, was there any impact on the costs and with the [indiscernible]? And what's the o
componenttext: Can you just go on the funding side, with the [indiscernible]. Can you just go over a little bit on the deposits, how far out you went? And then on the 2 ABS securitizations, was there any impact on the costs and with the [indiscernible]? And what's the outlook if we do [indiscernible] to get to [indiscernible] if you can just comment on that in terms of funding?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say the vast majority of the growth in the deposit book has come in the savings product to lesser degree, the money market in the CD books. So we're very focused on the indeterminate maturities, those proved to have the lowest betas overtime an
componenttext: So I would say the vast majority of the growth in the deposit book has come in the savings product to lesser degree, the money market in the CD books. So we're very focused on the indeterminate maturities, those proved to have the lowest betas overtime and also the stickiest customer retention characteristics. So that's why we're focusing in that particular area and why it has driven it. With respect to ABS transactions, I would say the answer is, yes, there has been some impact obviously with respect to what's happened in the marketplace in terms of credit spreads. Overall, I would say our credit spreads are up roughly call it 30 basis points year-over-year in addition to the just the base rate changes, if you will, the index rate changes that have taken place over the course of last year. That being said, it's still a very robust market. We were in the market last week, did something on the order of $1 billion, give or take. And actually we're able to walk price again. So it still feels like a very accessible, very effective channel. Pricing, a little more expensive than it was but, clearly, still very attractive funding.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just remind us and again going forward, we do get sort of a tightening cycle, would you -- what's the target in terms of deposits again versus sort of securitization? And is there one sort of angle that you'd lean on more than others, more than an
componenttext: Can you just remind us and again going forward, we do get sort of a tightening cycle, would you -- what's the target in terms of deposits again versus sort of securitization? And is there one sort of angle that you'd lean on more than others, more than another if we do get a tightening cycle?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we haven't decided bias for deposits. There's a couple reasons for that. The first of which is as we've talked, we've worked really hard over the last several years to really have across sold the book deposit base and we always like to use our balance
componenttext: So we haven't decided bias for deposits. There's a couple reasons for that. The first of which is as we've talked, we've worked really hard over the last several years to really have across sold the book deposit base and we always like to use our balance sheet to support our customers. So I think that's 1 reason. The other reason is because of the betas, right? I mean, deposits do not reprice at the same rate as any of the capital market fundings do. We have would have a decided bias to continue leaning into deposit growth, I would say. That being said, it takes time to grow deposits, especially relationship wherein a deposits you can grow, you are really fast by hanging out the highest rate in town, but that's also got a beta of 1. We're trying to do it the old-fashioned way where it adds real value. So I'd look for us to continue leaning into the deposits, but I'm not so sure, 9% to 12% growth rates the way we would be thinking about it, but mid to high single-digit growth rates sound good.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch with Credit Suisse.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just on the rewards cost. I mean, you had talked, Mark you'd said that you intended to keep the bonus into the second quarter. I guess, what would make you change that in the second half? And does the 1 15 guidance included for the full year? Sho
componenttext: I guess, just on the rewards cost. I mean, you had talked, Mark you'd said that you intended to keep the bonus into the second quarter. I guess, what would make you change that in the second half? And does the 1 15 guidance included for the full year? Should we think about rewards costs relative to that guidance? And how it might relate to your plans to grow the business?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I sit here right now, I still feel very good, Moshe, about the 115 basis points on the full year. I think our double program has been very effective. I think it's driving a big chunk of that revolve behavior that you're seeing out there, and it's so
componenttext: So as I sit here right now, I still feel very good, Moshe, about the 115 basis points on the full year. I think our double program has been very effective. I think it's driving a big chunk of that revolve behavior that you're seeing out there, and it's something that we would be probably predisposed to continue. And I wouldn't change the guidance we put out there in light of anything happening with respect to that.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. Just a second question. I mean, I recognized and applaud the fact that you bought back 8%[ph] of the stock. But the constraint is it's actually as a percentage of the stock that you bought back, it's the dollar amount, right? So that's basical
componenttext: Okay, good. Just a second question. I mean, I recognized and applaud the fact that you bought back 8%[ph] of the stock. But the constraint is it's actually as a percentage of the stock that you bought back, it's the dollar amount, right? So that's basically saying that the share price fell and you were able to take advantage of that which is wonderful. But the question is, are you able to kind of push the dollar amount of buybacks a little harder? And I didn't notice any mention of going after the de minimis exemption that some of your peers have done. And I'm wondering if you can kind of talk about that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, a lot embedded in there I'll try and tackle all the pieces. I would say, first and foremost again, I think we've been driven the highest yield to investors between dividends and buybacks if any at the financials out there. So I think we've been very
componenttext: Sure, a lot embedded in there I'll try and tackle all the pieces. I would say, first and foremost again, I think we've been driven the highest yield to investors between dividends and buybacks if any at the financials out there. So I think we've been very focused on it and every year, we've gotten more aggressive with that ask. So from that perspective, I would not dissuade you, Moshe, from again thinking and again we would continue to as we have comfort with the process and as the Fed has comfort with us, continue to be more aggressive there. In terms of the 1% de minimis ask, I think it is tended to be utilized by people, primarily around what I would call unexpected events that weren't contemplated in capital plans. Compensation dilution being 1 that comes to mind that I've seen a few folks do and a number of other things as well. We would not be hesitant to use something like that if we had a like-type event or a similar event of some kind come along. But I would say, it's clearly the 1% in our minds anyways clearly not designed to be in your CCAR approval, that's 1% every year. That's really not why it's out there.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I guess, if you were to see perhaps that asset growth was at the lower end or lower end of expectations, couldn't that be a reason to think about it?
componenttext: But I guess, if you were to see perhaps that asset growth was at the lower end or lower end of expectations, couldn't that be a reason to think about it?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there could be a lot of reasons to think about it. The question is, in what context do the people who allow you to do it, think about it, right? So I'm not so sure, again I think it's really designed to cover situations that weren't contemplated i
componenttext: I think there could be a lot of reasons to think about it. The question is, in what context do the people who allow you to do it, think about it, right? So I'm not so sure, again I think it's really designed to cover situations that weren't contemplated in a capital plan as opposed to simply business trajectory issues. And again I will just point back, we're in a CCAR submission cycle right now, we're going to be more aggressive and we are driving by far and away, the highest total yields of any of the financials with that 10% yield last year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think the exception process is going to move the dollar as much as what happens in CCAR itself.
componenttext: I don't think the exception process is going to move the dollar as much as what happens in CCAR itself.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: If You think about it, 1% of our Tier 1 common will be a little bit north of $100 million. So it's not exactly going to redefine our earnings stream.
componenttext: If You think about it, 1% of our Tier 1 common will be a little bit north of $100 million. So it's not exactly going to redefine our earnings stream.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Shane with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Shane with JPMorgan.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, we've seen the loan growth start to accelerate back into the target range. And I think that, that's to some extent a function of optimizing the investments in growth, and you talked about shifting from marketing to rewards and I think laid out the p
componenttext: Look, we've seen the loan growth start to accelerate back into the target range. And I think that, that's to some extent a function of optimizing the investments in growth, and you talked about shifting from marketing to rewards and I think laid out the potential that, that will continue into the second half of the year. When I think about investment and growth, marketing is spending in advance, reward in spreading concurrently. And then the last way, you can invest growth and it sounds a little bit strange, but it's on a credit side. And that's basically, investing in growth down the road, paying work down the road. Given your outlook in terms of the benign credit, does it make sense at this point to sort of make some of that investment down the road and potentially open up the credit bucket a little bit?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we would -- I would agree that those are good 3 levers and we are putting where we think appropriate all 3. And in response to 1 of the earlier question about what the various causes of us getting back in increases accelerating our loan
componenttext: Well, I think that we would -- I would agree that those are good 3 levers and we are putting where we think appropriate all 3. And in response to 1 of the earlier question about what the various causes of us getting back in increases accelerating our loan growth, I did cite credit as 1 of the actions we've taken in line increases, who we're approving, how we're authorizing. We are working to optimize all of the levers that you just cited. And the 1 I would probably add because I think it's not just about money, the execution, things like new features that may not cost that much money, but may move behavior, is a fourth lever that I would add. And I think if you look at what we've produced in terms of innovation the last couple of years compared to others, like Freeze It and free FICO and on and on, I think that innovation is one of the best place to move the dial.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. Look, I think one of the facets of your business is that you have very strong customer loyalty. And I'm that necessarily sure how you market that, but it certainly impacts the attrition within the portfolio in an environment where things
componenttext: That makes sense. Look, I think one of the facets of your business is that you have very strong customer loyalty. And I'm that necessarily sure how you market that, but it certainly impacts the attrition within the portfolio in an environment where things are really competitive.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think by not having the leaky bucket, we end up with 2 things. You don't have to put on as many new accounts to grow a certain rate, if you're not losing at the back end, but it also helps us from a credit perspective because with our average dura
componenttext: Well, I think by not having the leaky bucket, we end up with 2 things. You don't have to put on as many new accounts to grow a certain rate, if you're not losing at the back end, but it also helps us from a credit perspective because with our average duration of 12 months -- excuse me, 12-year of customer relationship compared with industry average around 8 years, we don't have as many as high of a percentage in those early years that have much higher credit risk. And that has helped explain some of our better credit performance than most of our competitors in the industry.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Napoli from William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Napoli from William Blair.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just some thoughts, David, on industry loan growth if you could. We've seen a ramp-up industry loan growth over the last year from 3% to around 6%. Do you think that is -- I mean, we've seen that in a consumer that's still kind of sleepy. And is this esse
componenttext: Just some thoughts, David, on industry loan growth if you could. We've seen a ramp-up industry loan growth over the last year from 3% to around 6%. Do you think that is -- I mean, we've seen that in a consumer that's still kind of sleepy. And is this essentially just the industry itself looking at the profitability of this product and tweaking the credit levers and the incentive levers to drive that growth such that we're setting the seats for the next credit cycle, if you would? Some thoughts around that would be helpful.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would bifurcate the industry loan growth between lower credits versus higher credit, call it the sub-prime business versus the prime business. We really haven't seen, I haven't seen much acceleration on the prime space, I mean, it stops shrinking. But m
componenttext: I would bifurcate the industry loan growth between lower credits versus higher credit, call it the sub-prime business versus the prime business. We really haven't seen, I haven't seen much acceleration on the prime space, I mean, it stops shrinking. But my best guess is it's growing 2% to 3% in prime credit scores today. If you see where the acceleration has come, it's come in the issuers who are in the sub-prime space, including private label, which obviously, a lot of people get there new to credit. So there's a high correlation between the high yield competitors and the higher growth competitors at the moment. If you look at -- if you just isolate the prime competitors, some are still shrinking a little bit. And so I think it's been and so how that plays out is and we're not a sub-prime player, but how does the sub-prime credit play out and impact those competitors over time, I'm not an expert on that. But I'm comfortable that loan growth in prime probably is -- it's hard to grow in that space, but it's probably good from credit performance perspective.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just follow up on your deposit quality. You've seen a nice pick up in growth, there's steady growth in the direct-to-consumer. The affinity products as a percentage of total funding, I guess, 44% up from 42% a year ago. Where would you like that
componenttext: Okay. And just follow up on your deposit quality. You've seen a nice pick up in growth, there's steady growth in the direct-to-consumer. The affinity products as a percentage of total funding, I guess, 44% up from 42% a year ago. Where would you like that to be? Where can that go over the next 5 years in an efficient manner, if you would? Do you have some targets for that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we like the fact that it's our largest single funding source and I'm very comfortable with where it's at. If it grows a little bit more, I think that would be even better. I was really pleased this quarter that we really didn't take our rates up, bu
componenttext: Well, we like the fact that it's our largest single funding source and I'm very comfortable with where it's at. If it grows a little bit more, I think that would be even better. I was really pleased this quarter that we really didn't take our rates up, but we saw a really nice inflow of deposits. And so that's helpful from a funding perspective, we have a customer relationship perspective. And I think over time, we'd like to add more checking accounts to the mix, we'd like to continue to grow in determining in general on savings and money markets, as Mark mentioned earlier. So if that's a little higher over time, I think that would be even better. But we feel like it's at a good level right now.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Scharf with JP securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Scharf with JP securities.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: My questions are largely answered. But I did want to get a sense for you back to the consumer spending patterns. This kind of even rough mix of 50-50 from both new accounts as well as dormant accounts driving that increase of revolving balances. Could you
componenttext: My questions are largely answered. But I did want to get a sense for you back to the consumer spending patterns. This kind of even rough mix of 50-50 from both new accounts as well as dormant accounts driving that increase of revolving balances. Could you give us a sense for how that mix sort of measures up to what your expectations were earlier in the year? I'm trying to get a sense for whether 50% of the growth coming from dormant accounts is potentially a bit of a positive surprise from what you would normally expect to see?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say, we've been -- our growth over the last several years has been roughly 50-50 base and new accounts. And so I think that's more of a continuation of a trend. I think if you think about sales, that probably comes a little bit higher from new a
componenttext: Well, I'd say, we've been -- our growth over the last several years has been roughly 50-50 base and new accounts. And so I think that's more of a continuation of a trend. I think if you think about sales, that probably comes a little bit higher from new accounts. And I would say generally, loans are performed about at what we expected for the year and targeted. We have a lot of programs to go into play, so we're happy they worked and produced the results we expected. Sales, on the other hand, continue to disappoint. And while I'm pleased that it was 4%, it matched the 4% loan growth, I would like to see the consumer become a little more, given the strong balance sheet that they have and their capacity to spend, I'd love to see the consumer in general spend a little more, which would allow us to grow sales a little faster.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I guess, the 2 percentage differential in card sales attributable to gas. Just given the upward trajectory since your Q4 call and in prices at the pump, should we expect that to narrow considerably this quarter?
componenttext: Got it. And I guess, the 2 percentage differential in card sales attributable to gas. Just given the upward trajectory since your Q4 call and in prices at the pump, should we expect that to narrow considerably this quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say considerably because remember, it's the year-over-year change. So unless we got a dramatic increase in gas prices, it's going to probably be lower than the same quarter last year all year long. Now I mean, narrow each quarter, if it kind of
componenttext: I wouldn't say considerably because remember, it's the year-over-year change. So unless we got a dramatic increase in gas prices, it's going to probably be lower than the same quarter last year all year long. Now I mean, narrow each quarter, if it kind of stabilizes. And it's certainly not as big as a downdraft as last year. But the gas prices, we're over 10% of our sales 18 months ago. Now they're 5% or 6% and so they're becoming less of an impact. But it's not going -- the 2% isn't going to go to 0 next quarter because of the year-over-year nature.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries of Barclays.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to drill down on some of the comments around the guidance in the NIM in particular. Going into the year, you guided a relatively stable NIM, not that somewhat vague. But it you're up 25 bps year-over-year and you're certainly higher based on
componenttext: I just wanted to drill down on some of the comments around the guidance in the NIM in particular. Going into the year, you guided a relatively stable NIM, not that somewhat vague. But it you're up 25 bps year-over-year and you're certainly higher based on the average for 2015. It sounds like, Mark, what you're saying is that's kind of bias flat, it could go a little bit lower if you lean in into some more promotional balance opportunities. But is it right to say that, that guidance no longer holds, that we're looking at higher NIM year-over-year than what we had in 2015?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you think back in the fourth quarter, I think what we say said was there's a natural upward bias in NIM, but we were calling, call it relative stability because we anticipated we might be doing some more promotional related activities. The good ne
componenttext: Yes. If you think back in the fourth quarter, I think what we say said was there's a natural upward bias in NIM, but we were calling, call it relative stability because we anticipated we might be doing some more promotional related activities. The good news is, we saw the reacceleration in growth we're looking for based on some of the things we did back in the middle of last year and it was coming in the form of good old-fashioned utilization of the card, both in the hands of the existing cardmember base and the legacy cardmember base. So I think we are definitely, Mark, saying, we have not taken the right for lack of a better term to increase promotional activities off the table, which is why I'm saying and I wouldn't just put a flat NIM in from here for the remainder of the year, but I think it's a very safe to say a full year basis, the NIM is not going to approximate the full year basis of last year. I think that's a safe bet at this point in time just on the current trajectory of growth we're seeing.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The success you've had with the loan growth without the promotional, is it right to assume that if we take our NIM down a little bit because you do more promotional that's somewhat additive, that maybe we should expect when will accelerate more from
componenttext: Okay. The success you've had with the loan growth without the promotional, is it right to assume that if we take our NIM down a little bit because you do more promotional that's somewhat additive, that maybe we should expect when will accelerate more from here?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are not calling out that we're going to do any increased promotional activity nor are we giving out guidance for what we expect the trajectory of loan growth to be from here. Just to be clear, all we're saying is at this point in time, to this point, w
componenttext: We are not calling out that we're going to do any increased promotional activity nor are we giving out guidance for what we expect the trajectory of loan growth to be from here. Just to be clear, all we're saying is at this point in time, to this point, we have seen the growth trajectory reaccelerate into our target range, and we feel good that we're getting it in a very constructive way that drives great returns through times. We haven't taken off the table the ability to invest more heavily in promotional activities, but we're not calling that we're going to do it either, just to be clear.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm just trying to clarify some of these promotional things I think that you indicated that you feel good about the rewards rate. So you still would love to be doing, I think, presumably a lot of the Double Cashback promotion. And if you were to lea
componenttext: Okay. I'm just trying to clarify some of these promotional things I think that you indicated that you feel good about the rewards rate. So you still would love to be doing, I think, presumably a lot of the Double Cashback promotion. And if you were to lean into promotional, I'm just thinking about as potentially additive to you growth. Is that at least a fair way to think about it?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one way to think about is we're at the bottom end of our range and we might want to take some actions to move it further in the range.
componenttext: Well, one way to think about is we're at the bottom end of our range and we might want to take some actions to move it further in the range.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: And I'll clarify, Mark, you understand promotional comment could be on the balance side in terms of balance transfer or promotion, not just on...

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes, absolutely.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. We have no further questions at this time. At this time, I'd like to turn the call back over to Bill Franklin for final remarks.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
