componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Discover Financial Services First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Bill Franklin, Head of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Connor. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin, as always, with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is in the Investor Relations section of discover.com.Our discussion today contains certain fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Connor. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin, as always, with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is in the Investor Relations section of discover.com.
Our discussion today contains certain forward-looking statements about the company's future financial performance and business prospects, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's earnings press release, which was provided to the SEC today in an 8-K report and in our 10-K and 10-Qs, which are on our website and on file with the SEC.
In the first quarter 2016 earnings materials, we have provided information that compares and reconciles the company's non-GAAP financial measures with the GAAP financial information, and we explained why these presentations are useful to management and investors. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's discussion.
Our call today will include formal remarks from David Nelms, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Graf, our Chief Financial Officer. After Mark completes his comments, there will be time for a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
So now, it is my pleasure to turn the call over to David.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and welcome all of you to our call.For the first quarter, we delivered net income of $575 million, earnings per share of $1.35 and a return on equity of 21%. Our Direct Banking business continues to deliver solid results. Discover achieved
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and welcome all of you to our call.
For the first quarter, we delivered net income of $575 million, earnings per share of $1.35 and a return on equity of 21%. Our Direct Banking business continues to deliver solid results. Discover achieved total loan growth of 4% over the prior year, which now brings us into the lower end of our targeted range for 2016. Specifically, we grew card receivables by 4%, accelerating year-over-year growth versus the fourth quarter. This receivables growth was the result of more new accounts and slightly higher customer spending and borrowing on cards as our overall revolver mix for the portfolio increased.
Our brand, rewards and overall value proposition remained focused on the prime revolver segment, which we believe is the most profitable part of the card market.
Card sales grew by 4% over the prior year. Excluding the impact of gas prices, sales were up approximately 6%, which shows that the lower gas prices at the pump remain a drag on card sales. Also, I'll point out that leap year in the first quarter added roughly 1% to sales growth.
Last quarter, we were recognized as highest in customer loyalty in the annual Brand Keys survey. This marks the 20th consecutive year that we've earned the top spot. I believe our focus on the customer has allowed us to have some of the lowest attrition rates in the industry and will continue to allow us to grow loans profitably.
Our other lending products are performing well. The organic student loan portfolio increased 15% and personal loans grew 9% over the prior year. The strong organic student loan growth was driven by disbursements related to students going back to school for the second semester and our continued focus on increasing awareness of Discover student loans.
On the funding side, I'm very pleased with the 6% sequential increase in direct-to-consumer deposits. Our consumer deposits grew approximately $2 billion and made up 45% of funding at the quarter end. We captured the growth as investments in marketing over the last several months delivered positive results, specifically in savings accounts and balances.
Moving to our Payments business. Total volume for the segment declined as increases in Network Partners and Diners Club volume were offset by year-over-year declines in debit volume at PULSE. We believe PULSE volumes will stabilize at approximately current levels for the remainder of the year.
Lastly, in Payments, we continue to leverage our proprietary network to deliver great returns in our card issuing business and are pleased with increasing domestic and global acceptance.
Overall, it was a good quarter and we're making progress against our key focus areas for the year. Now I'll turn the call over to Mark and he'll walk you through the details of our first quarter financial results.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll start by going through the revenue detail on Slide 5 of our earnings presentation.Net interest income increased $121 million or 7% over the prior year, driven by continued loan growth and a higher net in
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll start by going through the revenue detail on Slide 5 of our earnings presentation.
Net interest income increased $121 million or 7% over the prior year, driven by continued loan growth and a higher net interest margin. Total noninterest income decreased to $68 million to $474 million. The prior year's results included $42 million in mortgage origination revenue, a category that is absent this year as we subsequently exited the business.
Net discount interchange revenue was up 2%, driven by increased sales partially offset by a higher rewards rate year-over-year. Our rewards rate for the quarter was 106 basis points, up 4 basis points over the prior year due to higher promotional and standard rewards. Sequentially, the rewards rate was down 12 basis points. The fourth quarter typically represents a seasonal high and also included the Apple Pay rewards bonus.
Protection products revenue declined $10 million as new product sales remain suspended. Sequentially, protection products revenue was relatively flat. However, we continue to expect some runoff this year.
Moving to Payment Services. Revenue decreased $6 million from the prior year, mainly due to the previously announced loss of volume from a third-party issuer. Overall, we grew total company net revenues by 2% for the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6. Total loan yield of 11.69% was 32 basis points higher than the prior year, primarily driven by a 37 basis point increase in card yield. The year-over-year increase in yield was primarily due to a higher percentage of revolving card receivables in the portfolio as well as the impact of the prime rate increase in December.
On the funding side, we grew average direct-to-consumer deposits 9% and we've contemplate -- we've completed 2 ABS deals year-to-date. Funding costs increased only 8 basis points, partly as a result of fixed-rate debt issuances in the last year muting the impact of rising rates.
Overall, net interest margin expanded 25 basis points from the prior year to 9.94%. We achieved good acceleration in card loan growth through stronger sales and an increased revolve rate, so we did not feel a need to increase our promotional mix during the quarter. However, looking forward, we may yet choose to invest some of this NIM benefit to drive continued loan growth.
Turning to Slide 7. Operating expenses were up $13 million over the prior year. Last year's results included $37 million in expense associated with the direct mortgage origination business, more than half of which was reflected in employee compensation. The $14 million year-over-year increase in total employee compensation you see in the table was driven primarily by higher headcount to support compliance activities as well as annual merit increases.
Marketing expenses decreased $20 million due in part to the timing of card marketing as well as the elimination of mortgage marketing activities. Professional fees increased $33 million to $160 million as expenses associated with the AML/BSA look-back project totaled approximately $30 million for the quarter. We expect the look-back project cost to be largely complete in the first half of this year. And finally, other expense was lower as the prior year included a $20 million addition to the legal reserve.
For the quarter, our total company efficiency ratio was about 40%. However, if you exclude the $30 million look-back project expense I mentioned a moment ago, total company efficiency ratio was roughly 38.5%. 
Turning to provision for loan losses and credit on Slide 8. Provision for loan losses was higher by $34 million compared to the prior year due to higher reserves and charge-offs, primarily driven by loan growth. This quarter, we increased reserves $52 million, while last year we had a $30 million reserve build. The credit card net charge-off rate of 2.34% decreased by 6 basis points year-over-year and increased 16 basis points sequentially. The 30-plus day delinquency rate of 1.68% increased 4 basis points year-over-year and was down 4 basis points sequentially.
On balance, the credit backdrop continues to remain benign and reserving continues to be driven primarily by the compounding effect of several years of consistent loan growth, a meaningful portion of which has come from new accounts.
Moving to private student loans. The net charge-off rate, excluding acquired loans, decreased 18 basis points from the prior year, benefiting from the benign credit environment as well as a couple of items that we've discussed in the past, specifically more effective collection strategies as well as the introduction of several new payment plans over the last year.
Student loan delinquencies, once again excluding acquired loans, increased 26 basis points to 1.92% as a larger portion of the portfolio continues to come in to repayments. Overall, the student loan portfolio continues to season generally in line with our expectations.
Switching to personal loans. The net charge-off rate was up 23 basis points from the prior year and the over 30-day delinquency rate was up 21 basis points to 97 basis points. The year-over-year increases in the personal loan charge-off and delinquency rates were primarily driven by the expected seasoning of recent loan growth.
Next I'll touch on our capital position on Slide 9. Our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio increased sequentially by 30 basis points to 14.2% due to the seasonal decline in loan balances from the fourth quarter. This ratio declined 50 basis points from the prior year due to capital deployment in the form of loan growth, buybacks and dividends. In the quarter, we again repurchased nearly 2% of our common stock.
Lastly, while we did not recognize any material tax benefits this period, there will be a favorable resolution to an outstanding tax matter which will have the onetime effect of lowering the effective tax rate for the second quarter.
In summary, it feels like a good start to the year with a strong margin and good loan growth and a continued benign credit environment. We expect to see provisioning driven by loan growth and we'll continue to work diligently to manage the core expense base as we absorb increasing regulatory and compliance costs.
That concludes our formal remarks. So now, I'll turn the call back to our operator, Connor, to open the line up for Q&A. Connor?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had a question on the revolve rate. I was wondering if you could just talk about kind of what drove that higher? Was it something that you guys were doing? Or was it just a broader consumer trend? Obviously, kind of in this market, people are jittery
componenttext: Just had a question on the revolve rate. I was wondering if you could just talk about kind of what drove that higher? Was it something that you guys were doing? Or was it just a broader consumer trend? Obviously, kind of in this market, people are jittery about the macro. Any comments on the macro would be helpful as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Sanjay, it's Mark. I'll let David pile on as well here. But I think the revolve rate was really driven by a continued focus on the revolver in our book. And I think as we telegraphed on the last -- on the call last quarter, over the course of last year
componenttext: So Sanjay, it's Mark. I'll let David pile on as well here. But I think the revolve rate was really driven by a continued focus on the revolver in our book. And I think as we telegraphed on the last -- on the call last quarter, over the course of last year, we pulled back a number of activities that weren't driving the kinds of behavior that we wanted to see in the book and had refocused our efforts really along some of the more traditional areas, where we had emphasized growth in the portfolio, and that's paid very significant dividends over the course of the last quarter. I would say, it's paid dividends not only in the form of growth in -- from balances from new accounts, but also growth in formerly dormant accounts that have reactivated, also showed good contribution to growth in that regard.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I would add is we have been talking about the continued impact of gas prices on sales, and that has much less of an impact on loans and has the effect of helping the revolve rate a bit.
componenttext: And the only thing I would add is we have been talking about the continued impact of gas prices on sales, and that has much less of an impact on loans and has the effect of helping the revolve rate a bit.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any comments, David, on just the state of the consumer or on the macro?
componenttext: Okay. And any comments, David, on just the state of the consumer or on the macro?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it continues to be steady but slow growth. And we're seeing sales continue to kind of bump along, increasing from last year, but the consumers are continuing to be cautious. And that is -- that makes it tough on the sales line, but it's certainly
componenttext: I think it continues to be steady but slow growth. And we're seeing sales continue to kind of bump along, increasing from last year, but the consumers are continuing to be cautious. And that is -- that makes it tough on the sales line, but it's certainly benefiting the credit line, where the caution is showing up in continued great credit results.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Hecht with Jefferies.

componenttext: Real quick, Mark, can you quantify the tax benefit in Q2 that just -- so we have a fair amount of perspective?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I would say with respect to tax benefit, it relates to a matter that's disclosed in our SEC filings. It's the OID treatment of Cashback Bonus. It's for an extended period from the 1999 to 2007 and it's a pretty complex matter over a number of years. So we are still in the process of putting a fine point on it. I guess, what I would say is on the tax line itself, it looks to be kind of a mid-8-figure kind of number for the quarter -- in the quarter that we would indeed recognize. So I think that probably gives you a good triangulation for how to think about it.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question, you got a little bit better margin expansion than we expected from pricing prime rate. Is all that priced in the portfolio? Or is there some kind of a residual upside as we stretch into the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then second question, you got a little bit better margin expansion than we expected from pricing prime rate. Is all that priced in the portfolio? Or is there some kind of a residual upside as we stretch into the second quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it really relates to -- we talked in the last call about a natural upward bias in NIM in the book and that we thought we were going to -- might lean more heavily into promotional activity. We didn't end up doing that as it turned out because w
componenttext: No, I think it really relates to -- we talked in the last call about a natural upward bias in NIM in the book and that we thought we were going to -- might lean more heavily into promotional activity. We didn't end up doing that as it turned out because we saw a growth reaccelerating along the lines of what we are hoping for from a cadence perspective. So I think I would say as you look forward over this year, I'd kind of discourage you from flattening NIM out and just kind of saying, this is where it will be for the rest of the year. I think there would be relative stability in NIM, but it could be affected by promotional activity, that revolving behavior Sanjay asked about a second ago and, obviously, any further moves the Fed makes because of that positive bias in positioning.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just a follow-up from one of the questions that Sanjay asked. Can you maybe just talk about how the efforts to accelerate loan growth are going? Last quarter, you laid out a handful of initiatives. I was just wondering if you could just share how t
componenttext: David, just a follow-up from one of the questions that Sanjay asked. Can you maybe just talk about how the efforts to accelerate loan growth are going? Last quarter, you laid out a handful of initiatives. I was just wondering if you could just share how they're going, maybe any other metrics. You have account openings, activations. Help us understand like what the pipeline could look like for loan growth the rest of the year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think that the best indicator that our efforts are working in total is just to look at actual loan growth. And so we accelerated from just over 3% to about 4% year-over-year. And as you know, we had just established a new longer -- higher 4%
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think that the best indicator that our efforts are working in total is just to look at actual loan growth. And so we accelerated from just over 3% to about 4% year-over-year. And as you know, we had just established a new longer -- higher 4% to 6% full year target also for total loan growth, also for long term to be in that target. So I'm pleased that all of our various actions have moved us into that lower end of the range and we're certainly taking efforts to continue to move higher in that range if we're able to later this year. And I'd say those efforts include, I mentioned more new accounts, we are continuing to look for places where we can appropriately increase credit lines or extend credit where we're going to -- where we expect good and are achieving good results. Also some of our new features have been well-received, whether it's some of our Cashback, Freeze It, continued great take-up of free FICO scores. So I'd say that we have -- I don't think there's a single home run kind of initiative for loan growth, but a whole lot of singles that we are working on across the franchise.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Ryan, I'd add onto that just quickly, the loan growth continues to be close to 50-50, new accounts as well as existing accounts, which is a really healthy way to see that loan growth coming in. And if you look at the $2.2 billion in card receivables
componenttext: And, Ryan, I'd add onto that just quickly, the loan growth continues to be close to 50-50, new accounts as well as existing accounts, which is a really healthy way to see that loan growth coming in. And if you look at the $2.2 billion in card receivables growth over the course of the last year, over 80% of that is coming in what I'll call the standard merchandise bucket, right? Customers just simply using their cards, exhibiting the behaviors that drive the kind of long-term profitability we want to see out of the book. So it feels very, very good.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I could just ask 1 other question just on credit. If I look this quarter, charge-offs were relatively stable, delinquencies are relatively stable, up a couple of basis points. I was just wondering how do we think about the puts and takes? And I gues
componenttext: Maybe I could just ask 1 other question just on credit. If I look this quarter, charge-offs were relatively stable, delinquencies are relatively stable, up a couple of basis points. I was just wondering how do we think about the puts and takes? And I guess, Mark, more specifically since last quarter, there was a wide range on outcomes for reserves in 1Q. Can you just help us how to think about the pace of reserve builds from here, just given there was relief in the second quarter last year. I don't think you're anticipating a reserve at least this time. Just want to understand how we should think about reserve builds from here?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Ryan, happy to be -- I think from my perspective, the $50 million-or-so we built this quarter, I continue to describe that as essentially noise on a $1.9 billion balance sheet item. It's never going to be exactly flat. It's always going to be bump
componenttext: Yes. So Ryan, happy to be -- I think from my perspective, the $50 million-or-so we built this quarter, I continue to describe that as essentially noise on a $1.9 billion balance sheet item. It's never going to be exactly flat. It's always going to be bumping along a little bit one way or the other. I would say provisioning from this point forward is going to be -- continue to be a factor of loan growth and the seasoning of that loan growth. I would not encourage anyone to expect a reserve release in the second quarter. By the same token, I would not encourage anyone to assume there's going to be some giant takeoff in provisioning in the second quarter either. It feels, again, it's going to be very much a function of loan growth and the seasoning of that loan growth and it feels like we're in a good general bend.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Henry Coffey with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Henry Coffey with Sterne Agee.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the network side of the business obviously, Diners Club just started to show some positive life and your expenses were lower. What are the next steps forward there?
componenttext: When you look at the network side of the business obviously, Diners Club just started to show some positive life and your expenses were lower. What are the next steps forward there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I am pleased with the growth that you acknowledged in Diners Club at some of our new partners that have come online in recent years in places like China and other areas start to grow more robustly, and same with Network Partners with the vol
componenttext: Well, I think I am pleased with the growth that you acknowledged in Diners Club at some of our new partners that have come online in recent years in places like China and other areas start to grow more robustly, and same with Network Partners with the volume appearing very nicely networks around the world increasingly coming online and using our network for global acceptance. And I'd say the headwind has been quite severe in the larger segment, which is PULSE. And as I mentioned in my comments, after several years of a downdraft following the [indiscernible] actions that Visa took as well as loss of 1 major customer, it feels like we have reached a plateau with PULSE. And I think after this year, what we're looking to do is to go back to growing PULSE. And we had a bunch of years of very robust growth in market share and volume in PULSE, up until the actions shortly after Durbin. And then we went in and I'm -- we're working to have that grow as well while maintaining those newer areas like Diners and Network Partners and AribaPay, where we're seeing very nice growth add on as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the overhead side of the equation, Mark. When does the AML/BSA, when do those extra expenses sort of dwindle away?
componenttext: Great. And then on the overhead side of the equation, Mark. When does the AML/BSA, when do those extra expenses sort of dwindle away?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Henry, I'd put it in 2 buckets. The look-back project that we continue to call out specifically, I think we see that in terms of dollars of spend largely drawing to a close next quarter at this point in time. So I think we can see that pieces kind of c
componenttext: So Henry, I'd put it in 2 buckets. The look-back project that we continue to call out specifically, I think we see that in terms of dollars of spend largely drawing to a close next quarter at this point in time. So I think we can see that pieces kind of close to being done with the casework. I think the other piece of AML/BSA is really what I would call building out the AML/BSA process within the organization. We're largely covering a lot of that increased expense through finding efficiencies elsewhere in the business model. So just -- I'd take you back to a second in my prepared remarks where I said roughly a 40% efficiency ratio all-in, but if you exclude that look-back that we expect to bleed off after next quarter, we're printing about a 38.5% efficiency ratio this quarter. Now I think expenses are never flat. I think next quarter they may be inflated a little bit as we bring some things across the goal line and all, but I would stand by the expense guidance we gave at the beginning of the year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Donat with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Donat with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to explore on the personal loans business because we've seen that the deceleration of the growth there over the last couple of years and some of that's coincided with the entrance of the marketplace lenders or peer-to-peer lenders. Are you seeing a
componenttext: I want to explore on the personal loans business because we've seen that the deceleration of the growth there over the last couple of years and some of that's coincided with the entrance of the marketplace lenders or peer-to-peer lenders. Are you seeing any changes in the competitive landscape there? And would you have any hopes of getting the loan growth back up into the double digits in the coming year or so?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would encourage you to look at the dollars of loan growth, which last year was an all-time record for growth in our personal loans business. And we continue to grow that very nicely and there was -- the only thing that's really changed is the deno
componenttext: Well, I would encourage you to look at the dollars of loan growth, which last year was an all-time record for growth in our personal loans business. And we continue to grow that very nicely and there was -- the only thing that's really changed is the denominator is getting bigger. So percentage is dropping because of the denominator, even as the dollars of originations have gotten bigger. So I wouldn't cite market entrants or competition as being a slowdown. I think going forward, we do think our model is more sustainable. Since it's going on our balance sheet, we're not -- we have long-term customer relationships, we are profitable in contrast to some of the competitors who are printing some more difficult headlines right now. And so I think we have a very sustainable business model that we continue to grow. We think well and appropriately.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the marketing side, I -- yes, so I guess that there are some timing issues that Mark had commented on. Is there -- so it's down 11% year-on-year. Would you expect, Mark, it to be more flat year-on-year going forward or even up? Or is it
componenttext: Okay. And just on the marketing side, I -- yes, so I guess that there are some timing issues that Mark had commented on. Is there -- so it's down 11% year-on-year. Would you expect, Mark, it to be more flat year-on-year going forward or even up? Or is it just -- are we sort of in a ballpark in terms of the year-on-year comparisons from here?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, what I would say is we're continuing to really manage the interplay between marketing spend as well as rewards rate, right? And as we're leaning a little bit more in the rewards rate with our double new account promotion and some of the other
componenttext: So I guess, what I would say is we're continuing to really manage the interplay between marketing spend as well as rewards rate, right? And as we're leaning a little bit more in the rewards rate with our double new account promotion and some of the other things we're doing, I think we're viewing that as interchangeable with the marketing spend. So to some degree, some of the decline in marketing spend you see is related to that. The other thing I would say is there's obviously some timing of spend, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, that occurs throughout the course of the year. The first quarter was not a particularly high point from a marketing spend standpoint. And then the other thing I would just point out is in the year-over-year comparison, we did have the mortgage marketing spend in their last year, which I would remind you, you kind of have to peel back out for comparability. So those are really kind of the bits and pieces, puts and takes. I mean, I think ultimately we continue to have a very disciplined approach to marketing spend. We want to make sure we're getting the results we see for it. Again, when we saw we weren't getting some of the results we were looking for through some of the listing sites and other channels last year, in the middle of the year, we pulled back on those because we want to make sure we're driving the kind of growth that's going to drive the right kind of long-term profitability.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Don Fandetti with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Don Fandetti with Citigroup.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, can you talk a little bit about the rewards being so low this quarter and how you're thinking about that in context of the full year guidance? And then maybe provide a little bit of color on your thoughts about the industry in general on reward
componenttext: Yes, Mark, can you talk a little bit about the rewards being so low this quarter and how you're thinking about that in context of the full year guidance? And then maybe provide a little bit of color on your thoughts about the industry in general on rewards. We're starting to see some pretty high offers in the 5% range. I want to get your updated thoughts there.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll tackle the rate and dollar questions and I'll let David talk about the industry trend. I guess, what I would say is we're still very comfortable with the full year rewards rate at 115 basis points. A couple of things to think about there. Number o
componenttext: So I'll tackle the rate and dollar questions and I'll let David talk about the industry trend. I guess, what I would say is we're still very comfortable with the full year rewards rate at 115 basis points. A couple of things to think about there. Number one, we are going to continue running our double rewards program for new accounts at least for the next quarter and maybe beyond. And I would say, from the standpoint of the rewards perspective, it is down a little bit from where we were in the fourth quarter, but there's generally a peak seasonality effect in the fourth quarter. And in addition, the fourth quarter was elevated because of Apple Pay and the special promotion we ran in most recent fourth quarter. So I think we're up about 4 basis points year-over-year in terms of rewards rate. So that 115 on a full year basis still feels like a good place to triangulate.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just say that it's no surprise that competitors are aggressively offering cash rewards programs because it's what consumers most want and it's just very attractive to consumers. And I think that we are in a -- we've been at this game for 30 ye
componenttext: And I would just say that it's no surprise that competitors are aggressively offering cash rewards programs because it's what consumers most want and it's just very attractive to consumers. And I think that we are in a -- we've been at this game for 30 years now and I think that our combination of 1% cashback, 5% rotating categories, additional value coming from our Network Partners, who add value that doesn't hit our expense line, the elimination of breakage on the back-end that we've put in place a year ago, it -- consumers still tell us that regardless of top line, headline numbers, many -- most consumers, we think, really like our program. And we think we're -- have the right balance between sustainable cost and great value to consumers.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, you don't see -- you're not sensing sort of a big step forward in terms of accelerated or reward offers. It's more of just a continued, steady, competitive environment?
componenttext: So David, you don't see -- you're not sensing sort of a big step forward in terms of accelerated or reward offers. It's more of just a continued, steady, competitive environment?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. I think it accelerated a few years back. Since that time, the competitors have swapped between years. Two years ago, there was -- 1 competitor was heavy. They kind of pulled back and another one came in. And so I think we're at a fairly steady
componenttext: I think so. I think it accelerated a few years back. Since that time, the competitors have swapped between years. Two years ago, there was -- 1 competitor was heavy. They kind of pulled back and another one came in. And so I think we're at a fairly steady state, which is an intense environment, but I don't really see it getting worse from here. And the history of the industry has been when people have something that seems unsustainable, they eventually peel it back. So -- but my guess is when some of those competitors peel back, someone else will enter the fray. So we're kind of competing as if this is going to be the -- we think it's a steady state. There are a lot of competition and we have to win this game from a value perspective and profit perspective.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Ho with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Ho with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on credit. Have you seen any, on the margin credit deterioration, related to energy or even some of your lower FICO customers? And a follow-up on that would be is, would credit deterioration potentially come from some of your co
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on credit. Have you seen any, on the margin credit deterioration, related to energy or even some of your lower FICO customers? And a follow-up on that would be is, would credit deterioration potentially come from some of your competitors, increasing credit lines or just loosening that up over time?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Mark. I'll take the first stab and David can pile on. I would say with respect to the energy-related part of the question, we have seen some deterioration in the energy-related states. But I would describe it really as prior to the significant
componenttext: David, it's Mark. I'll take the first stab and David can pile on. I would say with respect to the energy-related part of the question, we have seen some deterioration in the energy-related states. But I would describe it really as prior to the significant drop in oil prices, all those markets were performing better than the national average for our portfolio. They basically come down to the national average for our portfolio. So it's something we're watching very closely, but it's not something that currently gives us significant pause or concern. All the credit metrics we're watching in the portfolio really speak to a continued benign environment with, again, as I said earlier, reserving from here really a more a function of loan growth. David, I don't know if there's anything you want to add to that or...

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I agree. I think in general, I think about energy exposure as being a business kind of loan related, which we're not in. And I think on the consumer side, it certainly has to have an impact. Any time there's loss of jobs or income in the industry, it
componenttext: No, I agree. I think in general, I think about energy exposure as being a business kind of loan related, which we're not in. And I think on the consumer side, it certainly has to have an impact. Any time there's loss of jobs or income in the industry, it can -- it affects consumers, but it's -- even with the high percentage reductions in employment in that industry, it's just not that huge of a number on a national level since we're completely national in scope. It's not going to be, as an example, like the mortgage that hit lots of consumers nationally. This is a pretty localized impact.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then are you seeing or potentially expecting any pressure from more credit lines being offered by competitors? I mean, that servicing ratios have kind of, say, flat mortgage that has been replaced by a little bit on the consumer side in terms of
componenttext: Okay. And then are you seeing or potentially expecting any pressure from more credit lines being offered by competitors? I mean, that servicing ratios have kind of, say, flat mortgage that has been replaced by a little bit on the consumer side in terms of leverage. So any thoughts there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that -- I think in a -- there may be less if rates slowly rise, there's probably a little bit less refinancing that will go on, particularly in first mortgages, and I -- but I don't see a big impact in the near term. I think we're in a fairl
componenttext: Well, I think that -- I think in a -- there may be less if rates slowly rise, there's probably a little bit less refinancing that will go on, particularly in first mortgages, and I -- but I don't see a big impact in the near term. I think we're in a fairly steady state in terms of the credit card industry growing at a slow rate.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And consumer balance sheet still seemed like they're in pretty good shape, David. When you just look at the obligation ratios and when you look at the debt burden that they're carrying, it's just a very different scenario now than it was the last time we
componenttext: And consumer balance sheet still seemed like they're in pretty good shape, David. When you just look at the obligation ratios and when you look at the debt burden that they're carrying, it's just a very different scenario now than it was the last time we were at this point in the cycle. So not dissuading you from your belief that we are a cyclical business, we are. But it just feels like the consumer debt burden is still fairly -- is still really manageable at this point.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Mark, one more question on the interchange relative to volumes. Interchange fees, it looked like they rose 5% versus volumes closer to 4%, flying a little bit of a higher margin there. Is that just one time or is that a mix shift? Or how do you see
componenttext: Okay. Mark, one more question on the interchange relative to volumes. Interchange fees, it looked like they rose 5% versus volumes closer to 4%, flying a little bit of a higher margin there. Is that just one time or is that a mix shift? Or how do you see that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really more a function of spend mix. The fourth quarter tends to see a lot of big-box spending around the holiday period. And in the first quarter, you tend to see a higher percentage of the mix being smaller merchants. So it's really more mix driven
componenttext: It's really more a function of spend mix. The fourth quarter tends to see a lot of big-box spending around the holiday period. And in the first quarter, you tend to see a higher percentage of the mix being smaller merchants. So it's really more mix driven than anything else, David.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just ask on expenses. The other expense line was -- came in later than expected. It's down quite a bit. Just want to get a color around that line item.
componenttext: I wanted to just ask on expenses. The other expense line was -- came in later than expected. It's down quite a bit. Just want to get a color around that line item.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The real big driver in other expenses in the similar quarter last year, we had about a $20 million addition to the legal reserve. That was absent this quarter. Beyond that, I would say, it's just generally back to what I said earlier that focused on
componenttext: Yes. The real big driver in other expenses in the similar quarter last year, we had about a $20 million addition to the legal reserve. That was absent this quarter. Beyond that, I would say, it's just generally back to what I said earlier that focused on -- if you exclude the AML/BSA look back, really trying to find ways to look at the expenses that are creeping into the model from a regulatory and compliance standpoint, making sure we're finding efficiencies and ways to cover those. So I think it reflects the discipline on that front, coupled with the lack of the $20 million addition to the legal reserve.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So therefore, the -- I'm getting noise on my line here, sorry. So basically, that $100 million -- or that $107 million appears sustainable at this level?
componenttext: Right. So therefore, the -- I'm getting noise on my line here, sorry. So basically, that $100 million -- or that $107 million appears sustainable at this level?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I would say, expenses do tend to bounce around quarter-over-quarter. So I wouldn't specifically encourage you to cycle to the $107 million. I think what I would say is we've given guidance for total expenses. Really being slightly north of $3.
componenttext: Yes. Again, I would say, expenses do tend to bounce around quarter-over-quarter. So I wouldn't specifically encourage you to cycle to the $107 million. I think what I would say is we've given guidance for total expenses. Really being slightly north of $3.5 billion for the year I think is how we described it back on the fourth quarter call, and we'll stand by that guidance. And I think I'll stand by the earlier comments on the other line as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one more. On the card yield, I mean, up quite a bit, year-over-year, 37 bps, up 22 link quarter. I know it's a function of both higher rates in terms of Fed move, but also the mix. Could you just talk to us about how we should think about t
componenttext: Okay. And then one more. On the card yield, I mean, up quite a bit, year-over-year, 37 bps, up 22 link quarter. I know it's a function of both higher rates in terms of Fed move, but also the mix. Could you just talk to us about how we should think about that going forward in terms of the magnitude of incremental upside we could see there as the mix evolves?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what I would say is you now have the prime rate increases already priced into the portfolio, right? So I'd say that's there. Obviously, further prime rate increases would potentially have a bearing on it. But assuming the prime rate stays whe
componenttext: Yes. I think what I would say is you now have the prime rate increases already priced into the portfolio, right? So I'd say that's there. Obviously, further prime rate increases would potentially have a bearing on it. But assuming the prime rate stays where the prime rate is, I think that whole benefit is baked in. The other part of it is a much higher component of revolving balances in the portfolio, right, due to that real strong focus on the revolving consumer. And the success we've had there, I would say, given what's happened to revolve rate, I wouldn't expect really significant increases in revolve rates from here. So from that perspective, I would go back and just generally say, if you think about it in a NIM perspective as opposed to specifically a card yield perspective, it feels like you'd have, I'll call it, again, a relatively stable NIM from this level, but you'd have some diminution over the course of the year in a stable environment. But again, I would just point out that it could be impacted by we still may make a decision to do a little bit of promotional investment that would have a muting impact there. The revolve rate would have an impact. And again, further prime rate increases would have an impact as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bill Carcache with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bill Carcache with Nomura.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions on CCAR. First, relating to last year's, is it reasonable to assume that you guys would seek to max out I think it was the $2.2 billion authorization that you received last year, which I think would imply about $480 million of
componenttext: I had a couple of questions on CCAR. First, relating to last year's, is it reasonable to assume that you guys would seek to max out I think it was the $2.2 billion authorization that you received last year, which I think would imply about $480 million of buyback in the next quarter. And then separately, relating to the upcoming CCAR. Broadly speaking and certainly at a high level, is it reasonable to expect that you guys are continuing to accrue capital to customers in good health? We've got unemployment rate at the same level, although the starting point is a little bit lower so the delta is higher, but you put all the pieces together. And would it be reasonable to assume that you kind of continue to grind closer to 100% payout ratio rather than move farther away from it?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I think about CCAR, I'll parse it because there's a bunch of questions embedded there. So I'll kind of try and touch on them all, and if I miss one, just come back with your follow-up. I think with respect to repurchased gains, we've never given any
componenttext: So if I think about CCAR, I'll parse it because there's a bunch of questions embedded there. So I'll kind of try and touch on them all, and if I miss one, just come back with your follow-up. I think with respect to repurchased gains, we've never given any specific guidance on that front. But I would just kind of say, I'd expect -- I wouldn't see any reason to expect a radically dissimilar cadence in 2Q to kind of what you've seen would be the way I would think about it. In terms of the overall approach to how we think about CCAR, I would say, over the course of the last couple of years, we've continued to make what I've described as prudently aggressive asks. And every year, they have been slightly more aggressive. I would assume that -- a reasonable person should assume that we don't see any reason to change that. We recognize we have excess capital today, and we are working diligently within the confines of the CCAR process to be able to return as much of that as prudently possible.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might just add on, I think typically, we've seen the last few years the Fed scenarios getting tougher, not easier, which impacts. But also as our processes have matured and has greater comfort, we have continued to move into our position of actually wor
componenttext: I might just add on, I think typically, we've seen the last few years the Fed scenarios getting tougher, not easier, which impacts. But also as our processes have matured and has greater comfort, we have continued to move into our position of actually working towards our targeted levels. And you've seen our capital -- you see our capital ratios today a bit lower than they were last year, and we bought back almost 8% of our stock in the last year. And every year, we would -- we'd love it to move a little more quickly towards the target levels. And every year, we're trying to take steps to do that. But we also -- now we just can't -- we can't get to the target. We won't get approval to get to the target in one fell swoop.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's -- think about it like a constrained optimization. I mean, drove a total yield last year something on the order of 10% between dividends and buybacks. So we feel like we are -- we're being respectful of our shareholder's capital and appr
componenttext: Yes. I think it's -- think about it like a constrained optimization. I mean, drove a total yield last year something on the order of 10% between dividends and buybacks. So we feel like we are -- we're being respectful of our shareholder's capital and appropriately being prudently aggressive in our asks. Again, the cadence having been more aggressive every year, I think a reasonable person would assume we wouldn't see a meaningful reason to change that cadence.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, extremely helpful. If I may squeeze one more in on expenses. Just for clarification, Mark, I believe that you had said earlier that the look back project was drawing to a close next quarter. Should we interpret that to mean that we're -- there
componenttext: Understood, extremely helpful. If I may squeeze one more in on expenses. Just for clarification, Mark, I believe that you had said earlier that the look back project was drawing to a close next quarter. Should we interpret that to mean that we're -- there will be one more quarter with the other non -- I guess, nonrecurring BSA/AML cost that would result in a differential between the operating efficiency and the adjusted operating efficiency ratio before they converge? Or will they converge starting next quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think you're thinking about it right. I'd go with your former characterization. There will be one more quarter, where those costs are in there. And the good news is I think we are comfortable that we're approaching the end of the case review portion
componenttext: No. I think you're thinking about it right. I'd go with your former characterization. There will be one more quarter, where those costs are in there. And the good news is I think we are comfortable that we're approaching the end of the case review portion of it, which is the big dollar portion of the project itself. So I would expect to see those yet, and that's why I alluded to the fact I -- while we're standing by our expense guidance for the year, I think -- we don't expect expenses to be linear across the remaining 3 quarters, and 2Q may actually prove to be the high point quite honestly.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Howlett with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Howlett with UBS.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the funding side, the -- with the mission [ph].  Can you just maybe go on a little more detail what you did with the deposits, how far out you went? And then on the 2 ABS securitizations, was there any impact on the costs and with the wedding [ph]
componenttext: Just on the funding side, the -- with the mission [ph].  Can you just maybe go on a little more detail what you did with the deposits, how far out you went? And then on the 2 ABS securitizations, was there any impact on the costs and with the wedding [ph] that went on? And what's the outlook if we do obviously get 2 hikes this year? Maybe you just could comment on that in terms of funding.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say the vast majority of the growth in the deposit book has come in the savings product, to a lesser degree, the money market and the CD books. So it's -- we're very focused on the indeterminate maturities, those proved to have the lowest betas
componenttext: So I would say the vast majority of the growth in the deposit book has come in the savings product, to a lesser degree, the money market and the CD books. So it's -- we're very focused on the indeterminate maturities, those proved to have the lowest betas over time and also the stickiest customer retention characteristics. So that's why we're focusing in that particular area and why it has driven it. With respect to ABS transactions, I would say the answer is, yes, there has been some impact obviously with respect to what's happened in the marketplace in terms of credit spreads. Overall, I would say our credit spreads are up roughly call it 30 basis points year-over-year in addition to the -- just the base rate changes, if you will, the index rate changes that have taken place over the course of the last year. That being said, it's still a very robust market. We were in market last week, did something on the order of $1 billion, give or take. And actually, we're able to walk price in. So it still feels like a very accessible, very effective channel. Pricing, a little more expensive than it was, but clearly, still very attractive funding.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just remind us again, going forward, if we do get a start of a tightening cycle, would you -- what's the target in terms of deposits again versus sort of securitization? And is there one sort of angle that you'd lean on more than others -- more th
componenttext: Can you just remind us again, going forward, if we do get a start of a tightening cycle, would you -- what's the target in terms of deposits again versus sort of securitization? And is there one sort of angle that you'd lean on more than others -- more than another if we do get the start of a tightening cycle?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have a decided bias for deposits. There's a couple reasons for that. The first of which is as we've talked, we've worked really hard over the last several years to really have a cross sold deposit base and we always like to use our balance sheet to
componenttext: So we have a decided bias for deposits. There's a couple reasons for that. The first of which is as we've talked, we've worked really hard over the last several years to really have a cross sold deposit base and we always like to use our balance sheet to support our customers. So I think that's one reason. The other reason is because of the betas, right? I mean, deposits do not reprice at the same rate as any of the capital market fundings do. So we would have a decided bias to continue leaning into deposit growth, I would say. That being said, it takes time to grow deposits, especially relationship-oriented deposits. You can grow them really fast by hanging out the highest rate in town, but that's also got a beta of 1. So -- and we're trying to do it the old-fashioned way where it adds real value. So I'd look for us to continue leaning into deposits, but I'm not so sure, 9% to 12% growth rate is the way to be thinking about it, but mid- to high single-digit growth rates sure sound good.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch with Credit Suisse.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just on the rewards cost. I mean, you had talked -- Mark you had said that you intended to keep the bonus into the second quarter. I guess, what would make you change it in the second half? And does the 115 guidance include it for the full year?
componenttext: I guess, just on the rewards cost. I mean, you had talked -- Mark you had said that you intended to keep the bonus into the second quarter. I guess, what would make you change it in the second half? And does the 115 guidance include it for the full year? How should we think about rewards costs relative to that guidance? And how it might relate to your plans to grow the business?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I sit here right now, I still feel very good, Moshe, about the 115 basis points on the full year. I think our double program has been very effective. I think it's driving a big chunk of that revolve behavior that you're seeing out there, and it's so
componenttext: So as I sit here right now, I still feel very good, Moshe, about the 115 basis points on the full year. I think our double program has been very effective. I think it's driving a big chunk of that revolve behavior that you're seeing out there, and it's something that we would be probably predisposed to continue. And I wouldn't change the guidance we've put out there in light of anything happening with respect to that.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And just a second question, I mean, I recognize and applaud the fact that you bought back 8% of the stock. But the constraint isn't actually the percentage of the stock that you bought back. It's the dollar amount, right? So that's basically s
componenttext: Okay, good. And just a second question, I mean, I recognize and applaud the fact that you bought back 8% of the stock. But the constraint isn't actually the percentage of the stock that you bought back. It's the dollar amount, right? So that's basically saying that the share price fell and you were able to take advantage of that which is wonderful. But the question is, are you able to kind of push the dollar amount of buybacks a little harder? And I didn't notice any mention of going after the de minimis exemption that some of your peers have done. And I'm wondering if you can kind of talk about that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, a lot embedded in there. I'll try and tackle all the pieces. I would say, first and foremost again, I think we've been -- driven the highest yield to investors between dividends and buybacks of any of the financials out there. So I think we've been
componenttext: Sure, a lot embedded in there. I'll try and tackle all the pieces. I would say, first and foremost again, I think we've been -- driven the highest yield to investors between dividends and buybacks of any of the financials out there. So I think we've been very focused on it, and every year, we've gotten more aggressive with that ask. So from that perspective, I wouldn't dissuade you, Moshe, from again thinking we would continue to -- as we have comfort with the process and as the Fed has comfort with us, continue to be more aggressive there. In terms of the 1% de minimis ask, I think it is tended to be utilized by people, primarily around what I would call unexpected events that weren't contemplated in capital plans, compensation dilution being one that comes to mind that I've seen a few folks do and a number of other things as well. We would not be hesitant to use something like that if we had a like-type event or a similar event of some kind come along. But I would say, it's clearly, the 1% in our minds anyway is clearly not designed to be your CCAR approval plus 1% every year. That's really not why it's out there.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I guess, if you were to see perhaps that asset growth was at the lower end -- or lower end of expectations, couldn't that be a reason to think about it?
componenttext: But I guess, if you were to see perhaps that asset growth was at the lower end -- or lower end of expectations, couldn't that be a reason to think about it?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there could be a lot of reasons to think about it. The question is, in what contexts do the people who allow you to do it, think about it, right? So I'm not so sure. Again, I think it's really designed to cover situations that weren't contemplated
componenttext: I think there could be a lot of reasons to think about it. The question is, in what contexts do the people who allow you to do it, think about it, right? So I'm not so sure. Again, I think it's really designed to cover situations that weren't contemplated in a capital plan as opposed to simply business trajectory issues. And again, I'd just point you back, we're in a CCAR submission cycle right now. We're going to be more aggressive and we are driving by far and away, the highest total yields of any of the financials with that 10% total yield last year.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I don't think the exception process is going to move the dollar as much as what happens in CCAR itself.
componenttext: And I don't think the exception process is going to move the dollar as much as what happens in CCAR itself.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about it, 1% of our Tier 1 common would be a little north of $100 million. So it's not exactly going to redefine our earning stream.
componenttext: If you think about it, 1% of our Tier 1 common would be a little north of $100 million. So it's not exactly going to redefine our earning stream.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Shane with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Shane with JPMorgan.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, we've seen the loan growth start to accelerate back into the target range. And I think that that's to some extent a function of optimizing the investments in growth, and you talked about shifting from marketing to rewards and I think laid out the po
componenttext: Look, we've seen the loan growth start to accelerate back into the target range. And I think that that's to some extent a function of optimizing the investments in growth, and you talked about shifting from marketing to rewards and I think laid out the potential that, that will continue into the second half of the year. When I think about investment and growth, marketing is spending in advance, reward is spreading concurrently. And then the last way you can invest in growth, and this sounds a little bit strange, but is on a credit side. And that's basically, investing in growth down the road -- pain's worth down the road. Given your outlook in terms of benign credit, does it make sense at this point to sort of make some of that investment down the road and potentially open up the credit bucket a little bit?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we would -- I would agree that those are all 3 good levers, and we are pulling where we think appropriate all 3. And in response to one of the earlier questions about what the various causes of us getting back increasing -- accelerating
componenttext: Well, I think that we would -- I would agree that those are all 3 good levers, and we are pulling where we think appropriate all 3. And in response to one of the earlier questions about what the various causes of us getting back increasing -- accelerating our loan growth, I did cite credit as one of the actions we've taken in line increases, who we're approving, how we're authorizing. We are working to optimize all of the levers that you just cited. And the one I would probably add because I think it's not just about money, the execution, things like new features that may not cost that much money, but may move behavior, is a fourth lever that I would add. And I think if you look at what we've produced in terms of innovation the last couple of years compared to others, like Freeze It and free FICO and on and on, I think that innovation is one of the best ways to move the dial.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that makes sense. I mean, look, I think one of the facets of your business is that you have very strong customer loyalty. And I'm not necessarily sure how you market that, but it certainly impacts the attrition of the -- within the portfolio in an env
componenttext: No, that makes sense. I mean, look, I think one of the facets of your business is that you have very strong customer loyalty. And I'm not necessarily sure how you market that, but it certainly impacts the attrition of the -- within the portfolio in an environment where things are really competitive.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think by not having a leaky bucket, we end up 2 -- with 2 things. You don't have to put on as many new accounts to grow a certain rate if you're not losing out the back end, but it also helps us from a credit perspective because with our average d
componenttext: Well, I think by not having a leaky bucket, we end up 2 -- with 2 things. You don't have to put on as many new accounts to grow a certain rate if you're not losing out the back end, but it also helps us from a credit perspective because with our average duration of 12 months -- or excuse me, 12 years of customer relationship compared to industry average around 8 years, we don't have as many as high of a percentage in those early years that have much higher credit risk. And that has -- helps explain some of our better credit performance than most of the competitors in our industry.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Napoli with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Napoli with William Blair.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just some thoughts, David, on industry loan growth if you could. I mean, you've seen -- we've seen a ramp-up industry loan growth over the last year from 3% to around 6%. Do you think that is -- I mean, and we've seen that with a consumer that's still kin
componenttext: Just some thoughts, David, on industry loan growth if you could. I mean, you've seen -- we've seen a ramp-up industry loan growth over the last year from 3% to around 6%. Do you think that is -- I mean, and we've seen that with a consumer that's still kind of sleepy. Is this essentially just the industry itself looking at the profitability of this product and tweaking the credit levers and the incentive levers to drive that growth such that we're seeding the -- we're setting the seeds for the next credit cycle, if you would? Some thoughts around that would be helpful.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would bifurcate the industry loan growth between lower credits versus higher credit, call it, the sub-prime business versus the prime business. We really haven't seen -- I haven't seen much acceleration on the prime space. I mean, it stops shrinking. Bu
componenttext: I would bifurcate the industry loan growth between lower credits versus higher credit, call it, the sub-prime business versus the prime business. We really haven't seen -- I haven't seen much acceleration on the prime space. I mean, it stops shrinking. But my best guess is it's growing at 2% to 3% in prime credit scores today. If you see where the acceleration has come, it's come in the issuers who are in the sub-prime space, including private label, which obviously, a lot of people get. They're new to credit. So there's a high correlation between the high yield competitors and the higher growth competitors at the moment. If you look at -- if you just isolate the prime competitors, some are still shrinking a little bit. And so I think it's been -- and so how that plays out is we're not a sub-prime player, but how does the sub-prime credit play out and impact those competitors over time, I'm not an expert on that. But I'm comfortable that loan growth in prime probably is a good -- it's hard to grow in that space, but it's probably good from credit performance perspective.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on your deposit quality. You've seen a nice pickup in growth. There's steady growth in the direct-to-consumer. And affinity products as a percentage of total funding, I guess, 44% up from 42% a year ago. Where would you like tha
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on your deposit quality. You've seen a nice pickup in growth. There's steady growth in the direct-to-consumer. And affinity products as a percentage of total funding, I guess, 44% up from 42% a year ago. Where would you like that to be? Where can that go over the next 5 years in an efficient manner, if you would? Do you have some targets for that?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we like the fact that it's our largest single funding source, and I am very comfortable with where it's at. If it grows a little bit more, I think that would be even better. I was really pleased this quarter that we really didn't take our rates up,
componenttext: Well, we like the fact that it's our largest single funding source, and I am very comfortable with where it's at. If it grows a little bit more, I think that would be even better. I was really pleased this quarter that we really didn't take our rates up, but we saw a very nice inflow of deposits. And so that's helpful from a funding perspective, a customer relationship perspective. And I think over time, we'd like to add more checking accounts to the mix. We'd like to continue to grow the indeterminants in general on savings and money markets as Mark mentioned earlier. So if it's a little higher over time, I think that would be even better. But it's -- we feel like it's at a good level right now.

componenttext: My questions are largely answered. But I did want to get a sense for you back to the consumer spending patterns. This kind of even rough mix of 50-50 from both new accounts as well as dormant accounts that's been driving the increase in revolving balances, could you give us a sense for how that mix sort of measures up to both what your expectations were earlier in the year? I'm trying to get a sense for whether 50% of the growth coming from dormant accounts is potentially a bit of a positive surprise from what you would normally expect to see?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say, we've been -- our growth over the last several years has been roughly 50-50 base and new accounts. And so I think that's more of a continuation of a trend. I think if you think about sales, that probably comes a little bit higher from new a
componenttext: Well, I'd say, we've been -- our growth over the last several years has been roughly 50-50 base and new accounts. And so I think that's more of a continuation of a trend. I think if you think about sales, that probably comes a little bit higher from new accounts. And I would say generally, loans have performed about at what we expected for the year and targeted. We had a lot of programs to go into play, and we're happy they worked and they've produced the result we expected. Sales on the other hand has continued to disappoint. And while I'm pleased that it was 4%, so it's matched the 4% loan growth, I would like to see the consumer become a little more -- given the strong balance sheet that they have and their capacity to spend, I'd love to see the consumer in general spend a little more, which would allow us to grow sales a little faster.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And the -- I guess, the 2 percentage differential in card sales attributable to gas, just given the sort of upward trajectory, really, since your Q4 call and in prices at the pump, should we expect that to narrow considerably this quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say considerably because remember, it's the year-over-year change. And so unless we got a, like, dramatic increase in gas prices, it's going to probably be lower than the same quarter last year all year long. Now, it may narrow each quarter if
componenttext: I wouldn't say considerably because remember, it's the year-over-year change. And so unless we got a, like, dramatic increase in gas prices, it's going to probably be lower than the same quarter last year all year long. Now, it may narrow each quarter if it kind of stabilizes. And it's certainly not as big of a downdraft as it was last year. But gas prices were over 10% of our sales 18 months ago. Now, they're 5% or 6%, and so they're becoming less of an impact. But it's not going -- the 2% isn't going to go to 0 next quarter because of the year-over-year nature.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
