headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Discover Financial Services Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conferen
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Discover Financial Services Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Bill Franklin, Head of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin, as always, with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is in the Investor Relations section of discover.com.Our discussion today contains certain forw
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin, as always, with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is in the Investor Relations section of discover.com.
Our discussion today contains certain forward-looking statements about the company's future financial performance and business prospects, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's earnings press release, which was provided to the SEC and an 8-K report and in our 10-K and 10-Q, which are on our website and on file with the SEC.
In the second quarter 2016 earnings materials, we have provided information that compares and reconciles the company's non-GAAP financial measures with the GAAP financial information, and we explained why these presentations are useful to management and investors. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's discussion.
Our call today will include formal remarks from David Nelms, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Graf, our Chief Financial Officer. After Mark completes his comments, there will be time for a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
Now it is my pleasure to turn the call over to David.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good afternoon, everyone. For the second quarter, we reported net income of $616 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.47, up 11% year-over-year. These results included a nonrecurring tax benefit of $44 million, which contributed
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good afternoon, everyone. For the second quarter, we reported net income of $616 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.47, up 11% year-over-year. These results included a nonrecurring tax benefit of $44 million, which contributed $0.11 to diluted earnings per share.
Our direct banking business continues to deliver solid results. Discover achieved total loan growth of 4% over the prior year, with a healthy net interest margin. In the Card business, we also grew receivables by 4%. This receivables growth was the result of more new accounts and slightly higher customer spending and borrowing on their cards as our overall revolver mix for the portfolio increased. Card sales grew by 2% over the prior year, a bit lower than we would like. 
Our sales growth was outpaced by the growth in rewards. However, we're seeing benefits from the double rewards campaign in new accounts, sales from new accounts and in the cost to acquire these accounts. Along those lines, we set a post-recession record for new account -- new card accounts during the quarter, demonstrating that our brand rewards and overall value proposition continue to resonate with our target customers.
We believe these new accounts will contribute to future sales and loan growth. And to leverage our brand and increase consideration, we launched credit scorecard, which provides both current and prospective customers with access to their FICO score as well as a summary of the data that is helping and hurting their score. 
Our other direct banking products also performed well. The organic student loan portfolio increased 15%, driven by our continued focus on increasing awareness of Discover Student Loans. Personal loans grew 10% over the prior year, driven by digital investments and increased marketing, which have allowed us to drive growth while still maintaining an average FICO on new accounts of around 750. Both student and personal loans are on track for record originations again in 2016.
On the funding side of direct banking, I'm very pleased with the 16% growth in direct-to-consumer deposits. These deposits made up 47% of funding at quarter end. Our investments in marketing have continued to pay off, driving strong growth, specifically in savings accounts and balances.
Moving to our Payments business. PULSE volume declined 9% year-over-year. We expect PULSE volumes will stabilize around the end of the year. At the same time, Network Partners and Diners Club volume increased over the prior year, with Diners Club volume increasing 6%, driven by strong growth in the Asia-Pacific region.
During the quarter, we received a lot of positive recognition from third parties. Two I'll highlight are that Fortune ranked us on its list of 100 Best Workplaces for Millennials. And Computerworld ranked us as one of the Top 100 Places to Work for IT professionals. We believe our commitment to treating our employees well translates into delivering the best products and services to our customers and superior returns to our shareholders.
Overall, it was a good quarter. We are making progress against our key focus areas for the year, and we were pleased with how we lined up versus other banks in the CCAR stress test results as well as overall capital returns planned for the year ahead.
Now I'll turn the call over to Mark and he'll walk through the details of our second quarter financial results. Mark?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll start by going through the revenue detail on Slide 5 of our earnings presentation.Net interest income increased $115 million or 7% over the prior year, driven by continued loan growth and a higher net in
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll start by going through the revenue detail on Slide 5 of our earnings presentation.
Net interest income increased $115 million or 7% over the prior year, driven by continued loan growth and a higher net interest margin. Total noninterest income decreased $74 million to $465 million. The prior year's results included $28 million in mortgage origination revenue, a category that's absent this year as we are no longer in that business.
Net discount interchange revenue was down 11%, driven by a higher rewards rate year-over-year. Our rewards rate for the quarter was 121 basis points, up 16 basis points over the prior year due to higher promotional and standard rewards, which David noted are helping attract new accounts. Sequentially, the rewards rate was up 15 basis points, driven by higher enrollment and spending in the quarter's rotating 5% category.
Moving to Payment Services. Revenue decreased $2 million from the prior year, mainly due to the previously announced loss of volume from a third-party debit issuer. Overall, we grew total company net revenue by 2% for the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6. Total loan yield of 11.72% was 37 basis points higher than the prior year, primarily driven by a 38 basis point increase in card yield. The year-over-year increase in yield was primarily due to the higher percentage of revolving card receivables in the portfolio as well as the impact of last December's prime rate increase. 
On the funding side, we grew average direct-to-consumer deposits by $4 billion. Total funding costs increased only 8 basis points despite higher market rates as their impact was muted by last year's fixed-rate debt issuances and our growing direct-to-consumer deposit base.
Overall, net interest margin expanded 31 basis points from the prior year to 9.94%. For the remainder of the year, we currently expect a relatively stable margin. But it will, of course, be impacted by any changes in our planned level of promotional activity, revolving behavior in the card portfolio and any future Fed actions.
Turning to Slide 7. Operating expenses were down $21 million over the prior year. Last year's results had $62 million in expense associated with the operation and closure of the direct mortgage origination business, about 1/3 of which was reflected in employee compensation. The $14 million year-over-year increase in total employee compensation you see in the table was driven primarily by higher headcount to support compliance activities as well as annual merit increases.
Marketing expenses were flat as savings from the elimination of mortgage marketing activities were reinvested in other areas of the business. Professional fees fell $3 million. The workstreams underlying the AML/BSA lookback project were as expected, completed during the quarter at a cost of $12 million as compared to $19 million in the second quarter of last year. While the completion of these workstreams represents a milestone, I would remind you that we are continuing to enhance our compliance program to meet the terms of our consent orders.
Other expense was lower as the prior year included $23 million in one-time charges associated with the exit of the home loan business.
Turning to provision for loan losses and credit on Slide 8. Provision for loan losses was higher by $106 million compared to the prior year due to higher reserves and charge-offs, primarily driven by loan growth. This quarter, we increased reserves $28 million, while last year, we had a $41 million reserve release. The credit card net charge-off rate of 2.39% increased by 11 basis points year-over-year and increased 5 basis points sequentially. The 30-day delinquency rate of 1.63% increased 8 basis points year-over-year and was down 5 basis points sequentially.
On balance, the credit backdrop remains benign, and reserving continues to be driven primarily by the compounding effect of several years of consistent loan growth, a meaningful portion of which has come from new accounts.
Looking at student loans. The net charge-off rate, excluding acquired loans, increased 8 basis points from the prior year due to continued seasoning of the organic book. Sequentially, the rate increased 25 basis points due primarily to seasonality. 
Student loan delinquencies, once again excluding acquired loans, increased 10 basis points to 1.88% as a larger portion of the portfolio continues to come into repayments and decreased 4 basis points sequentially. Overall, the student loan portfolio continues to season generally in line with our expectations.
Switching to personal loans. The net charge-off rate was up 28 basis points from the prior year and down 7 basis points sequentially. The 30-day delinquency rate was up 31 basis points from the prior year and up 5 basis points from the prior quarter. The year-over-year increases in the personal loan charge-off and delinquency rates were primarily driven by the seasoning of recent loan growth, which was consistent with our expectations.
Next, I'll touch on our capital position on Slide 9. Our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio was flat sequentially. This ratio declined 20 basis points from the prior year due to capital deployment in the form of loan growth, buybacks and dividends. In the quarter, we again repurchased approximately 2% of our common stock.
As David mentioned, we're pleased with how we lined up versus other banks in terms of our stress capital ratios in the Federal Reserve's CCAR process. We received a non-objection from the Fed with respect to our propose capital actions for the 4 quarters ending June 30, 2017. As a result, we plan to repurchase almost $2 billion of our common stock over the next 12 months. And last week, our board increased our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.28 to $0.30 per share. At current share prices, this results in one of the highest total yields among CCAR participants.
In summary, we delivered strong net interest income by growing loans and NIM, saw increased rewards expense, primarily due to our double promotion, which drove more new and engaged accounts, grew the proportion of funding we get from deposits and achieved a favorable outcome from the 2016 CCAR process. 
That concludes our formal remarks and now I'll turn the call back to the operator, Mike, to open the line up for Q&A.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, last quarter, you discussed that you had not made the decision to accelerate growth or use some of the stronger margins to try to drive more growth. I'm wondering if you've had a change of heart around that particular issue? Or if this is just a
componenttext: I guess, last quarter, you discussed that you had not made the decision to accelerate growth or use some of the stronger margins to try to drive more growth. I'm wondering if you've had a change of heart around that particular issue? Or if this is just a situation where you want to essentially just capitalize on these high margins and let the portfolio roll up on higher yields.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think the way I think about it, Ken, is really and David comment as well too, but I think about it as a constrained optimization, right? There's a combination of rewards -- of returns and growth that you'd like to see. I think we are continuing to re
componenttext: So I think the way I think about it, Ken, is really and David comment as well too, but I think about it as a constrained optimization, right? There's a combination of rewards -- of returns and growth that you'd like to see. I think we are continuing to reserve the right to invest some of that margin strength we're seeing over the back half of the year. We currently haven't found any ways of doing it but from an NPV perspective really made sense for us. That's why we're continuing to guide to a relatively stable margin at this point in time. But giving ourselves the ability, I guess, to change that if we see a need to going forward. One of the things we did do is we did go ahead and reinvest the marketing spend from last year that we had in the direct mortgage business into some of the other businesses. You might see us lean into marketing expense a little bit as we go forward into the back half of the year relative to what you've seen from us lately. But we're pleased with the revolver sales growth we're seeing right now and pleased with the trajectory of NIM and loan growth.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, the only thing I would add is we really haven't changed from last quarter, where our focus both on growth of loans us well as maintaining a strong profitability.
componenttext: And Ken, the only thing I would add is we really haven't changed from last quarter, where our focus both on growth of loans us well as maintaining a strong profitability.

componenttext: Well, I would say we are certainly hoping that the strong new account growth, along with other actions, will help increase our loan growth fit further into our range. We're -- as you know, we're looking for 4% to 6% in total, and so we're within that range, but we are hoping to go further into the range as the quarters go by in the future.

componenttext: No, I think in terms of rewards guidance, we've been speaking to something in that 115 basis point area as you discussed. I think what you saw in the quarter was really more an impact of what that quarter's -- what last quarter's rotating 5% cashback category was, that drove pretty significant engagement and that really drove the biggest sequential increase in rewards. On a full year basis, we're still looking for something in that 115 basis point range, maybe 1 basis point or 2 higher but nothing of any significant difference from the guidance.

componenttext: You may have touched upon this a little with the mix, but can you provide a little more color on perhaps the 2% sales volume growth, which looks like it came in a little below expectations and certainly, it's not coming from over the last 3 months from gas price trends. Any color on what you may be seeing there?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, our primary focus is on loan growth, which continues to be strong. It actually moved up just a slight amount to just over 4% from just under 4% last quarter. And we don't aspire to have the same sales growth as peers. We focus more in t
componenttext: Well, as you know, our primary focus is on loan growth, which continues to be strong. It actually moved up just a slight amount to just over 4% from just under 4% last quarter. And we don't aspire to have the same sales growth as peers. We focus more in the transactor space. However, we would like to be a bit higher than what we saw in the second quarter. And so we are hopeful that the number of the actions that we've been taking, whether it's more new accounts, focusing on engagement with our cash rewards program and other actions to help stimulate some sales volume, will move the sales volume up a bit over the coming quarters as well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I was going to say the only thing I would add to that is there's several folks with some very high rewards rates that are out there. And I think we're just kind of said it doesn't seem to make economic sense to us in a lot of cases. And those clearly
componenttext: No, I was going to say the only thing I would add to that is there's several folks with some very high rewards rates that are out there. And I think we're just kind of said it doesn't seem to make economic sense to us in a lot of cases. And those clearly are going to be the most appealing to the transactor who tends to drive the majority of the sales growth. So with a very lens-centric model in this environment, I would expect us to lag on the sales growth front. But as David noted, we'd like to see it be somewhat higher than where it sits right now.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, helpful. And then just as a follow-up, looks like in the personal loan side, looks like it's a first time in 4 quarters you're back up to double-digit year-over-year growth. Did you feel you're benefiting at all from some of the pullback like perh
componenttext: Got it, helpful. And then just as a follow-up, looks like in the personal loan side, looks like it's a first time in 4 quarters you're back up to double-digit year-over-year growth. Did you feel you're benefiting at all from some of the pullback like perhaps marketplace lenders? Are there other financing products out there or was there anything on the promotional side on your end that may have given the performance?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've produced record originations each year in the last few years, and we expect to do the same this year with actions we've taken. So I think most of the growth is our actions in marketing. And it's not really promotional in terms of promotional rates b
componenttext: We've produced record originations each year in the last few years, and we expect to do the same this year with actions we've taken. So I think most of the growth is our actions in marketing. And it's not really promotional in terms of promotional rates but increased marketing and increased effectiveness of that marketing, yes. At the margins, I'm sure we're benefiting a bit from the pullback of some of the formerly P2P kind of companies. But a lot of -- as we've talked before, a lot of what they place in the lower credits where we don't play. So I think to the extent that they also did pick up some prime originates, some prime loans and originating fewer, that should help us a little bit and certainly doesn't -- it doesn't hurt.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the reserving and the seasoning that you were talking about, since you are generating some incremental loan growth, some nice loan growth some nice one versus trajecting here throughout the rest of the year or at least we're expecting.
componenttext: Just a question on the reserving and the seasoning that you were talking about, since you are generating some incremental loan growth, some nice loan growth some nice one versus trajecting here throughout the rest of the year or at least we're expecting. Do you see that seasoning continuing to track up at the same peak that you've been experiencing over the last 1.5 years or so? Or is there a point at which you'd feel that sufficient portfolio have been reserve build start to fit?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Betsy, I think at this point in time, what you're really dealing with is the compounding effect of the loan growth as opposed to just the last quarter or 2's loan growth that's really driving that reserving. The cards and personal loans both tend to
componenttext: Yes, Betsy, I think at this point in time, what you're really dealing with is the compounding effect of the loan growth as opposed to just the last quarter or 2's loan growth that's really driving that reserving. The cards and personal loans both tend to peak charge-offs about 24 months after your originate them. If you think about it, limit the vintage from 2 years ago is right at that peak the minutes from last year's climbing the hill and the from 3 years ago is still pretty high under the curve but dropping off. So as we've continued to originate more new accounts every year successively since the crisis, the area under that curve grows because the vintage falling out of that peak is a smaller than the one that's climbing the help. So I think it's really the compounding effect that's the driver. I wouldn't expect, as long as we're able to continue driving loan growth the levels we are right now and keep solid new account production across the products, I wouldn't expect to see us flip to a situation where we fall into a reserve release or a and net neutral reserve position at least not any for length of time.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only 2 things I would add to that, Betsy, is one is even if there wasn't [indiscernible] it was absolutely stable credit. When you're growing loans, you'd obviously have to set aside some loan-loss reserves to cover those new loans. And secondly,
componenttext: And the only 2 things I would add to that, Betsy, is one is even if there wasn't [indiscernible] it was absolutely stable credit. When you're growing loans, you'd obviously have to set aside some loan-loss reserves to cover those new loans. And secondly, there's also obviously going to continue to be some volatility between quarters, given the large size of the reserve balance.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then just how the portfolios trend a from a credit perspective relative to what you were expecting when you underwrote them? Just on a vintage curve basis, had there been much change at all over the past several quarters or not really?
componenttext: Sure. And then just how the portfolios trend a from a credit perspective relative to what you were expecting when you underwrote them? Just on a vintage curve basis, had there been much change at all over the past several quarters or not really?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say they tracked generally to our expectations. If you're talking about a little bit longer term, they've tracked somewhat better because this credit environment and normalization has remained benign and normalization than we expected. And so we a
componenttext: I would say they tracked generally to our expectations. If you're talking about a little bit longer term, they've tracked somewhat better because this credit environment and normalization has remained benign and normalization than we expected. And so we are possible we've tried to find places that we could do incremental line increase or approve someone that may be in this -- going forward might actually be expected to have prime credit behavior.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from John Pancari from Evercore.
componenttext: Next question is from John Pancari from Evercore.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to see if you can just give us your thoughts on the targeted efficiency ratio expectation, I guess, for full year '16 and how that may roll into 2017. And then as part of that, I'm just -- see how we should think about the elevated limited marketin
componenttext: Wanted to see if you can just give us your thoughts on the targeted efficiency ratio expectation, I guess, for full year '16 and how that may roll into 2017. And then as part of that, I'm just -- see how we should think about the elevated limited marketing expense for this quarter if we should expect that it off of this level or perhaps grow from the 198.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we've guided to lower expenses in 2016 than we saw in 2015. But we haven't given any efficiency guidance other than to say we expect to keep trending back down toward that 38% level over the course of this year. I don't think we'll achieve
componenttext: Yes. So I think we've guided to lower expenses in 2016 than we saw in 2015. But we haven't given any efficiency guidance other than to say we expect to keep trending back down toward that 38% level over the course of this year. I don't think we'll achieve it for the full year this year, and just to be clear on that front, given where the year started with some of these increased compliance and AML/BSA look back cost. We're starting with such a low efficiency ratio relative to peers to begin with. Some of the onetime costs we saw just we're not going to cut muscle in order to cover those so want to keep the engine running and keep the customer experience what it's been. Still feel comfortable that operating expenses in 2016 will be lower than 2015. They may be a tad bit higher than the guidance we called out at the beginning of the year but not materially so that would cause immediate change to guidance for you at this point in time.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You mentioned a lookback cost. You expect that to still go down from the $12 million that you saw this quarter?
componenttext: Okay. You mentioned a lookback cost. You expect that to still go down from the $12 million that you saw this quarter?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we actually completed all the work streams related to the look back itself this quarter, so that expense is no -- we'll no longer deal with us going forward. But we will have other expenses related to enhancements to the compliance program to comply
componenttext: Yes, we actually completed all the work streams related to the look back itself this quarter, so that expense is no -- we'll no longer deal with us going forward. But we will have other expenses related to enhancements to the compliance program to comply with the consent orders we have on that front.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark DeVries from Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from Mark DeVries from Barclays.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you think about your levers for growing car loans, are you still getting enough traction from your cashback match? In other words, categories that we should expect you to rely more on that than on kind of does your percent balance transfer offers? An
componenttext: When you think about your levers for growing car loans, are you still getting enough traction from your cashback match? In other words, categories that we should expect you to rely more on that than on kind of does your percent balance transfer offers? And if so, just talk about the implications of that for where NIM could end up in the range of your guidance of relatively flat?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start and then hand it to Mark. I'd say generally yes, the pivot that we made towards match and away from quite as aggressive on the balance transfer promotional offers, really started about a year ago, has continued to perform well and is one of the
componenttext: I'll start and then hand it to Mark. I'd say generally yes, the pivot that we made towards match and away from quite as aggressive on the balance transfer promotional offers, really started about a year ago, has continued to perform well and is one of the reasons you're seeing elevated Cashback Bonus expenses with a healthy net interest margin and modest marketing spend as we get lower cost per account. So where we continue at this point to be feel good about that trade-off. The only thing I would add is that we are continuously looking at our rewards programs, our marketing mix, testing different things. And so I would expect at some point, we'll test into other variations.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as NIM goes, Mark, the outlook would basically assume that a fairly consistent percentage of the growth we're seeing is coming from the balance transfer activities that we don't lean into any more or any less candidly than we are right now tha
componenttext: Yes. As far as NIM goes, Mark, the outlook would basically assume that a fairly consistent percentage of the growth we're seeing is coming from the balance transfer activities that we don't lean into any more or any less candidly than we are right now that's in that stable margin guidance for the remainder of the year. As I alluded to earlier, I think we're probably more prone to invest some of that excess margin a little bit of incremental marketing expense in the back half of the year as opposed to activity. But we are reserving the ability to do it if we can find a way from an NPV standpoint to have it make sense.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ryan Nash from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Ryan Nash from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can ask somewhat of a follow-up question to David. David, just relating to rewards, I mean, it seems apparent that rates are going to stay lower for a longer period of time. And I guess, what do you think this means for the overall competitive dyn
componenttext: Maybe I can ask somewhat of a follow-up question to David. David, just relating to rewards, I mean, it seems apparent that rates are going to stay lower for a longer period of time. And I guess, what do you think this means for the overall competitive dynamic in both in the rewards space and the competition for incremental loan growth?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're asking me if we're going to continue to see an elevated competition in rewards? Is that...
componenttext: So you're asking me if we're going to continue to see an elevated competition in rewards? Is that...

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What do you think the fact that we're going to be in a further low rate environment does to the competitive dynamics in both rewards and loan growth?
componenttext: What do you think the fact that we're going to be in a further low rate environment does to the competitive dynamics in both rewards and loan growth?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I would say in a low rate environment, transactors aren't as costly as in a higher rate environment. And I think that's why you're seeing some of the competitors chase the transactors very aggressively with rewards. And it's one of the reasons
componenttext: Okay. Well, I would say in a low rate environment, transactors aren't as costly as in a higher rate environment. And I think that's why you're seeing some of the competitors chase the transactors very aggressively with rewards. And it's one of the reasons we're not chasing them quite so aggressively because they're breakeven now and float goes up, they start losing money again if rewards get that rich. I would say also that the low rate environment and the low return environment in banking is part of what I believe is causing greater competition in cards and specifically in rewards. And I think post-CARD Act, the issuers may be a little careful on how much they want to reduce their credit standards or how much of they want to reduce their APRs. But they may feel like they can, at least for now, go with some high rewards rates and maybe in the future, they have to adjust them down. And our focus -- so I think the low rate environment is driving kind of of some of that competition. And it's why we tried to keep our disciplined by having a sustainable rewards rate and be disciplined on maintaining profitability, not just go for really high growth but less profitable growth.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ryan, I'd just add on to that. While it may result in sales growth being a little bit lower than we'd like to see in the near term, I think it's a real validation of the profit pool in the businesses, in the lens-centric element of the business, which
componenttext: And Ryan, I'd just add on to that. While it may result in sales growth being a little bit lower than we'd like to see in the near term, I think it's a real validation of the profit pool in the businesses, in the lens-centric element of the business, which is where we intend to remain focused.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. If I could ask one other question for Mark. Just related to the guidance for relatively stable net interest margin. When I think about a couple of different components, first on loan yields, you talked about remixing the books towards more -- less
componenttext: Got it. If I could ask one other question for Mark. Just related to the guidance for relatively stable net interest margin. When I think about a couple of different components, first on loan yields, you talked about remixing the books towards more -- less transactor-oriented. Do you think, one, do you think there's more to go there? Second, what is the impact of the fact that we may not see another interest rate rise this year? And then third, does lower rate change the way at all you think about the duration of the funding base 2 years ago. I think you guys termed out some of the funding. Does that change at all given the fact where rates are today?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A bunch in there. I'll try and tackle it. I would say with respect to the latter question, I think we may let the asset sensitivity of the balance sheet drift a little lower naturally over the coming quarters just based on the revised outlook post-Brexit
componenttext: A bunch in there. I'll try and tackle it. I would say with respect to the latter question, I think we may let the asset sensitivity of the balance sheet drift a little lower naturally over the coming quarters just based on the revised outlook post-Brexit and the impact on Europe and how that's kind of trickling through the outlook for the global economy. So I wouldn't be surprised to see I think we will continue to maintain an asset-sensitive position. We think it's the right place for us, and it don't think you'll see us do anything test relational evolutionary over time. With respect to the mix in the portfolio, I would say I think you might see a little bit more skewing towards revolvers and away from transactors as the year goes on. But I wouldn't say it would be so meaningful as to change your modeling for us radically from where we sit right now. And there was a third piece to your question, Ryan that I forgot, and I'm sorry.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the impact of lower short-term rates.
componenttext: Just the impact of lower short-term rates.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of lower short rate, yes, I would say the current rate curve -- current rate environment doesn't concern me at all. I think we do well in the current environment. We do well on a flatter curve. I think we're positioned really well.
componenttext: Of lower short rate, yes, I would say the current rate curve -- current rate environment doesn't concern me at all. I think we do well in the current environment. We do well on a flatter curve. I think we're positioned really well.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Don Fandetti from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is from Don Fandetti from Citigroup.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, given your capital position remaining very strong, I was just curious what your thoughts are in acquisitions, if you're seeing more deals that are of interest to you these days or if prices are still high and payments and other areas.
componenttext: Mark, given your capital position remaining very strong, I was just curious what your thoughts are in acquisitions, if you're seeing more deals that are of interest to you these days or if prices are still high and payments and other areas.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say with the AML/BSA consent orders we have from the Fed and the FDIC, I think we're kind of out of the acquisition space right now. Those really are red lights with respect to acquisitions. So we continue to look in the marketplace, stay plu
componenttext: Yes, I would say with the AML/BSA consent orders we have from the Fed and the FDIC, I think we're kind of out of the acquisition space right now. Those really are red lights with respect to acquisitions. So we continue to look in the marketplace, stay plugged into the marketplace, make sure we're aware of flow. But I think our ability to act on anything that would touch or impact the bank charter right now is probably nonexistent. I would say with respect to the payment side of the equation, I think I'll let David address that because that doesn't specifically play into the bank charter.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that I'm not seeing a lot more growth in M&A. I mean, [indiscernible] talk in the market but I'm not seeing as much. Actually changing. And the one thing I would say is that even into the consent order, it could allow us to do certain po
componenttext: Well, I would say that I'm not seeing a lot more growth in M&A. I mean, [indiscernible] talk in the market but I'm not seeing as much. Actually changing. And the one thing I would say is that even into the consent order, it could allow us to do certain portfolio kind of things. And I don't think that M&A is the first thing that we focus on as a tool anyway. We look at organic growth. We have strong capital returns to shareholders. But I guess I would just moderate a little bit. I'm not sure, we would 100% be totally out of that even in this period.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you could do the portfolio [indiscernible]. That's fair.
componenttext: Yes, I think you could do the portfolio [indiscernible]. That's fair.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then a follow-up. David, obviously, there have been a lot of mixed signals in terms of the consumer. I'm not sensing that you're seeing any type of deceleration it sounds like it's more steady as she goes from your standpoint.
componenttext: Got it. And then a follow-up. David, obviously, there have been a lot of mixed signals in terms of the consumer. I'm not sensing that you're seeing any type of deceleration it sounds like it's more steady as she goes from your standpoint.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, was it consumer credit or more and just consumer sales are leveraging?
componenttext: Don, was it consumer credit or more and just consumer sales are leveraging?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, more on consumer sales and willingness to take on debt in confidence.
componenttext: Yes, more on consumer sales and willingness to take on debt in confidence.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we're the big action is in 2 places. I've certainly seen some growth from -- in transactors and; and in some co-brand deals and there seems to be action there. There also seems to be a lot more loan growth in the subprime kind of space. And c
componenttext: I think that we're the big action is in 2 places. I've certainly seen some growth from -- in transactors and; and in some co-brand deals and there seems to be action there. There also seems to be a lot more loan growth in the subprime kind of space. And certainly we're seeing competitors -- where I think it was more credit availability issue there that after the crisis, everyone pulled back, and right now, you've got a couple competitors who are really making a lot more credit available. And so we're seeing loan growth there. In the prime space that we focus on, I'm seeing generally slow sales growth, slow but now positive loan growth as an industry, and there's gradual increases in confidence and -- of the consumer since they're in a really healthy place from a personal balance sheet perspective, healthy as we've seen in many, many years.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.
componenttext: The next question is from Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my first question is just trying to reconcile some of the comments you've made about strong account growth and the fact that we're not releasing a pickup in sales growth nor the loan growth numbers, could you just reconcile that for us? I mean, a
componenttext: I guess, my first question is just trying to reconcile some of the comments you've made about strong account growth and the fact that we're not releasing a pickup in sales growth nor the loan growth numbers, could you just reconcile that for us? I mean, are these new accounts coming on and not really doing much or is this something else?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would say is we're actually seeing strong sales growth of the new accounts. And probably if I had to pinpoint where we're softest, it's in some of our oldest transactors. And in some cases, some of them are getting picked up by offers they just can
componenttext: What I would say is we're actually seeing strong sales growth of the new accounts. And probably if I had to pinpoint where we're softest, it's in some of our oldest transactors. And in some cases, some of them are getting picked up by offers they just can't turn down. And so that's why you're seeing our loans and profits do fine. And I guess, that's how I would reconcile that.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And as far as these new -- the new trends that are coming on, they're just not revolving as much?
componenttext: I see. And as far as these new -- the new trends that are coming on, they're just not revolving as much?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that. I mean, both loans and sales from new accounts look good. And you're seeing with us a little bit continued pickup on loan growth. We are getting -- we're getting the results that is -- are most important, which is loan growth. And
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that. I mean, both loans and sales from new accounts look good. And you're seeing with us a little bit continued pickup on loan growth. We are getting -- we're getting the results that is -- are most important, which is loan growth. And so it's a secondary concern, but we still would love to also see a little more sales growth as well, and we're hoping to achieve that more over time. I mean, there's a couple of specific things going on. Obviously, gas prices continue to be about a 1% drag year-over-year. I think we'll have another quarter of that and then hopefully that should at least finally stabilize. You saw a -- one of the warehouse clubs started accepting more cards, and then that's going pull some of our warehouse sales away as we have to kind of -- as consumers have more choices than they did. And so we've got a couple of things like that. But overall, I think the big picture is a few of our competitors are just incredibly aggressive at the moment with transactors.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a follow-up question to your commentary on the BSA/AML stuff. I guess, how long are you constrained at the bank as far as M&A is concerned after you're done? Should we expect this impact to be over the course of the next year or so?
componenttext: Got it. And then just a follow-up question to your commentary on the BSA/AML stuff. I guess, how long are you constrained at the bank as far as M&A is concerned after you're done? Should we expect this impact to be over the course of the next year or so? And then have there been any missed opportunities because of that or has it been that neutral?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not -- the good news is I'm not sure there have been missed opportunities. And if you look over the time before we got into any of this, we didn't have a huge M&A part of our business. We've been mainly in organic growth story. But I think the key thi
componenttext: I'm not -- the good news is I'm not sure there have been missed opportunities. And if you look over the time before we got into any of this, we didn't have a huge M&A part of our business. We've been mainly in organic growth story. But I think the key thing that we'd like to do at some point is we need to get the consent orders lifted. And 2 things have to happen. First, we need to finish the work. And then a test be burnt in long enough and regulators have to come in and actually left the consent orders. And so we're focused right now on that first part. That's in our control, and it is -- there is no higher priority at the company than doing that. And as soon as to that place, we'll turn our attention to find move along the process of getting the orders themselves with it.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from James Friedman from Susquehanna.
componenttext: The next question is from James Friedman from Susquehanna.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask about the 2.39% Anzio on courts. Mark, how should we be thinking about that trending for the remainder of the year?
componenttext: I just want to ask about the 2.39% Anzio on courts. Mark, how should we be thinking about that trending for the remainder of the year?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we give charge-off guidance specifically, Jamie. What I would say is it's up I think 11 basis points on a year-over-year basis, and I think that really reflects that continued seasoning. I think there's 2 things going on: number one, we
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we give charge-off guidance specifically, Jamie. What I would say is it's up I think 11 basis points on a year-over-year basis, and I think that really reflects that continued seasoning. I think there's 2 things going on: number one, we're just coming off of an exceptionally low level for charge-offs across the consumer finance industry more broadly. So I do think there's call it just a gradual normalization element of this that is taking place. But then you also have the seasoning of those multiple years of loan growth and the way that they mature and come to peak losses 24 months out that are driving that as well. What I'd say is, I mean, just as a backdrop, I would really underscore, we see the credit environment as extremely benign right now. And I do think that the trends in the credit line are going to be more a function of growth in the portfolio and the seasoning of that growth and not really reflective of any deterioration that we see in the environment.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And my follow-up, so Diners, not to be overlooked, had one of its better quarters in a while, 6% growth. Any commentary there? I don't remember if the comp was easy or is there something more structural in the execution that's improved?
componenttext: Got it. And my follow-up, so Diners, not to be overlooked, had one of its better quarters in a while, 6% growth. Any commentary there? I don't remember if the comp was easy or is there something more structural in the execution that's improved?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we're -- 2 things have happened. One is there's been a fair number of transitions away from Citibank franchises into other hands and other people that may be were a little more focused on growing in some of those markets. And I'd say that tra
componenttext: I think that we're -- 2 things have happened. One is there's been a fair number of transitions away from Citibank franchises into other hands and other people that may be were a little more focused on growing in some of those markets. And I'd say that transition has now run its course. But the second thing is we've got -- we've had some good important new signings that we talked about in recent years, the largest issuer in China is issuing [indiscernible], the largest issuer of credit card issuer in India is our Diners Club franchise there. And so players like that tend to -- is what really help drive some of the volume by putting a lot of new cards, growing sales and certainly by far, the growth is coming out of the Asia area more than anywhere else in the world right now.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Hecht from Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from John Hecht from Jefferies.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just back a little bit more details in some of the growth and new customer acquisitions in the quarter. Number one, can you tell us what are the characteristics of the new customers? Any characteristic sort of by credit type or channel, customer
componenttext: I guess, just back a little bit more details in some of the growth and new customer acquisitions in the quarter. Number one, can you tell us what are the characteristics of the new customers? Any characteristic sort of by credit type or channel, customer acquisition? And then follow on would be I'll wait for the follow on after I get the answer to that one.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say there's not a big change on -- we -- credit is pretty stable. The average FICO is slightly down over the last few years, just as we found that this new environment appears to be more here to stay. And so at the margin, we could lean a little more
componenttext: I'd say there's not a big change on -- we -- credit is pretty stable. The average FICO is slightly down over the last few years, just as we found that this new environment appears to be more here to stay. And so at the margin, we could lean a little more into FICO scores. But generally, the quality of the composition of the customers is very consistent with what we pursued in the past. We're probably slightly heavier in students than we used to be because that's a really important source of ongoing new accounts and relationships. We've got some new products like our secure card that allows us to approve people that can't be approved without the security. And so we also have our Miles card that appeals to a little higher spending customer generally, but both of those portfolios are so small but at this point, they're not really moving the needle. So overall consistent.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just with respect to kind of the ramp of a new revolving -- revolver customer. What's the utilization rate in the early months? And when does the typical revolver customer kind of reached peak utilization? And has that changed over the past
componenttext: Okay. And then just with respect to kind of the ramp of a new revolving -- revolver customer. What's the utilization rate in the early months? And when does the typical revolver customer kind of reached peak utilization? And has that changed over the past year or 2?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that as we shifted from being a bit more balance transfer-focused to more cash rewards-focused, we're seeing actually a little faster sales growth and a little slower immediate loan growth out of the blocks. But what we are expecting is that t
componenttext: I would say that as we shifted from being a bit more balance transfer-focused to more cash rewards-focused, we're seeing actually a little faster sales growth and a little slower immediate loan growth out of the blocks. But what we are expecting is that the balance transfers expired in the past, and we usually saw some paydown at that point and we have a few of those to expire. So the loan build we think will kind of continue and continue to build. And so we tend to get to pretty high -- to our fairly typical maturity around year 1, at the 12-month mark and generally our loan average balances continue to grow from that point but more modestly.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bob Napoli from William Blair.
componenttext: The next question is from Bob Napoli from William Blair.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the student loan business, any thoughts that you can give us, updated thoughts on the opportunities that you have in that business? We're obviously going through a political season. Thoughts on risks to being able to grow that business. And then how do
componenttext: On the student loan business, any thoughts that you can give us, updated thoughts on the opportunities that you have in that business? We're obviously going through a political season. Thoughts on risks to being able to grow that business. And then how do you feel about the business today versus in the past? And want to get that to contribute to your 4% to 6% growth.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I continue to feel good about it. One of the things that will be a bit helpful is that the organic business is becoming a higher and higher part of the mix. And so when we bought those 2 portfolios through Citi, they were large portfolios, and they c
componenttext: Yes, I continue to feel good about it. One of the things that will be a bit helpful is that the organic business is becoming a higher and higher part of the mix. And so when we bought those 2 portfolios through Citi, they were large portfolios, and they continue to pay down as you'd expect. But as they become a smaller and smaller part of the mix, the overall loan growth within the student loan business, I believe, can accelerate a little bit. I'd say overall, there are certainly risks, as you say. It is a bit of a hot button. Politically, there tends to be confusion between the large federal student loan program, which is most of the lending and, if not, underwritten and not publicized credit issues versus the private loans, which are continuing to perform well. But sometimes people in the press will mix up those 2 things. And so I still believe that there's opportunity, the private student loans only make up about 6% of new student loan originations. And if the government ever pulls back at all, that could be an opportunity for accelerated growth. I don't think we're at that point right now, but someday, that may happen, I believe. But there are also -- there's also plenty of scrutiny around that business because it's very important. But as long as tuition continues to grow faster, I think there's a need for it. Our loans performed well so I am still quite bullish on the business.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up question. Just another credit question if you would, credit cycle. Every time somebody in the industry announces slightly higher credit losses, the market gets really nervous. If you look back over the last 30 years of credit cycles, I mea
componenttext: And a follow-up question. Just another credit question if you would, credit cycle. Every time somebody in the industry announces slightly higher credit losses, the market gets really nervous. If you look back over the last 30 years of credit cycles, I mean, we're going to have another credit cycle, you guys are clearly saying that through seeing benign credit. If we stay in this low growth economic environment without an economic shocks, what -- I mean, under this type of a scenario, what do you feel -- sounds like the industry is losing its credit box a little bit. Your FICOs are down a little bit. JPMorgan talked about expanding the credit box. Where do you think the credit cycle? Is there a credit cycle? Or do you think credit losses will stay around the current range? And just any thoughts what are normal -- what is normalized credit for Discover? Is it lower than it used to be?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, there's still a credit cycle. It's a cyclical business. The new normal, I don't think we're going to know for quite some time. It's lower than it used to be, but we're going to have to actually go through a cycle or 2 to fully understand it. An
componenttext: Well, yes, there's still a credit cycle. It's a cyclical business. The new normal, I don't think we're going to know for quite some time. It's lower than it used to be, but we're going to have to actually go through a cycle or 2 to fully understand it. And that's why -- and I would just say that our management team has been through a bunch of cycles. And it's one of the reasons that we still are keeping very disciplined. We'll make some changes to the margin, but I think you're not hearing us say that there's some big opportunity. We're going to loosen up because we think the credit cycle is over -- credit cycles are over. So I generally people that grow really fast in loans for a short period of time comes back in provide. That's one reason we have a top end to our loan growth projections. We don't think growing more than about 6% at the high end can be done today without taking too much credit risk.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just follow on to that just to make sure we're calibrating correctly. When David talks about a modest expansion of the credit box, I really utilize that modest word. I think historically, what we've told folks is line-weighted FICO in the car
componenttext: Yes, I would just follow on to that just to make sure we're calibrating correctly. When David talks about a modest expansion of the credit box, I really utilize that modest word. I think historically, what we've told folks is line-weighted FICO in the card business is around 732, something like that for the portfolio. If you drill bull's eye, I would say 7 or 8 basis points around that number. That's aligned originations this year would be. So I mean, you're not talking about a significant expansion of the credit box by any stretch of the imagination.

And with the engagement -- and the engaged behavior we're seeing out of those accounts as they're coming on the books, they are comprising a greater portion of the sales growth right now.

And I'm wondering if that increase in the traditional rewards is a cyclical or secular dynamic? In other words, is it just a function of the current competitive environment? Or is it the new cost of doing business over the long term?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh I see. Well, I do think in part, it's a new cost of doing business but it's because it works. I mean, I think you can go to an unsustainably high level which we're not prepared to do. But it has fantastic appeal to [indiscernible] card customers. And s
componenttext: Oh I see. Well, I do think in part, it's a new cost of doing business but it's because it works. I mean, I think you can go to an unsustainably high level which we're not prepared to do. But it has fantastic appeal to [indiscernible] card customers. And so people have been copying what we've been doing for -- since we started and in some cases, they may be taking it to an extreme. If you look at the -- what's driving our rewards costs, there's a certain sort of more permanent shift as we move from what used to be up to 1% to a flat 1%. And then there are quarterly changes based on the 5% program, the double match on new accounts and those can go up or down over time.

componenttext: So you paid out essentially all of your earnings during the last CCAR cycle and yet the capital ratio remained essentially stable at about 14%. headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I would say it's hard to say, Jason, is the honest answer to the question. I think we are comfortable with loan growth in the range you are seeing right now would like to see a little bit higher into the range obviously as David noted. But I think loan growth consuming a chunk of that. I feel really good about north of the CCAR process and producing one of the highest yields among all the participants buying back close to 8% of shares on an annualized basis if you look at last quarter. I'm most hard-pressed to see how to craft the path for you for how long it's going to take to get there. I think the one thing we've said over and over again and will commit to is we're not going to do anything crazy with it just because we haven't. We recognize our investors' capital and not ours, and we will treat it appropriately. We continue to look for ways to return more of it. Every year, we've gotten more aggressive and that CCAR Over the year prior, I think a reasonable person could assume that, that process doesn't -- wouldn't deviate you current thoughts as we look forward either. But exactly how long that's going to take to get there, just don't know how to answer that question.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Discover Financial Services Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Bill Franklin, Head of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin, as always, with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is in the Investor Relations section of discover.com.Our discussion today contains certain forw
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate all of you for joining us. Let me begin, as always, with Slide 2 of our earnings presentation, which is in the Investor Relations section of discover.com.
Our discussion today contains certain forward-looking statements about the company's future financial performance and business prospects, which are subject to risks and uncertainties and speak only as of today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are set forth within today's earnings press release, which was provided to the SEC and an 8-K report and in our 10-K and 10-Q, which are on our website and on file with the SEC.
In the second quarter 2016 earnings materials, we have provided information that compares and reconciles the company's non-GAAP financial measures with the GAAP financial information, and we explained why these presentations are useful to management and investors. We urge you to review that information in conjunction with today's discussion.
Our call today will include formal remarks from David Nelms, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Graf, our Chief Financial Officer. After Mark completes his comments, there will be time for a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]
Now it is my pleasure to turn the call over to David.

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good afternoon, everyone. For the second quarter, we reported net income of $616 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.47, up 11% year-over-year. These results included a nonrecurring tax benefit of $44 million, which contributed
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good afternoon, everyone. For the second quarter, we reported net income of $616 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.47, up 11% year-over-year. These results included a nonrecurring tax benefit of $44 million, which contributed $0.11 to diluted earnings per share.
Our Direct Banking business continues to deliver solid results. Discover achieved total loan growth of 4% over the prior year with a healthy net interest margin.
In the card business, we also grew receivables by 4%. This receivables growth was the result of more new accounts and slightly higher customer spending and borrowing on their cards as our overall revolver mix for the portfolio increased. Card sales grew by 2% over the prior year, a bit lower than we would like.
Our sales growth was outpaced by the growth in rewards. However, we're seeing benefits from the double rewards campaign on new accounts, sales from new accounts and in the cost to acquire these accounts. Along those lines, we set a post-recession record for new account -- new card accounts during the quarter, demonstrating that our brand, rewards and overall value proposition continue to resonate with our target customers.
We believe these new accounts will contribute to future sales and loan growth. And to leverage our brand and increase consideration, we launched Credit Scorecard, which provides both current and prospective customers with access to their FICO score as well as a summary of the data that is helping and hurting their score.
Our other direct banking products also performed well. The organic student loan portfolio increased 15%, driven by our continued focus on increasing awareness of Discover Student Loans. Personal loans grew 10% over the prior year, driven by digital investments and increased marketing, which have allowed us to drive growth while still maintaining an average FICO on new accounts of around 750. Both student and personal loans are on track for record originations again in 2016.
On the funding side of direct banking, I'm very pleased with the 16% growth in direct-to-consumer deposits. These deposits made up 47% of funding at quarter end. Our investments in marketing have continued to pay off, driving strong growth specifically in savings accounts and balances.
Moving to our payments business. PULSE volume declined 9% year-over-year. We expect PULSE volumes will stabilize around the end of the year. At the same time, Network Partners and Diners Club volume increased over the prior year with Diners Club volume increasing 6%, driven by strong growth in the Asia-Pacific region.
During the quarter, we received a lot of positive recognition from third parties. Two I'll highlight are that Fortune ranked us on its list of 100 Best Workplaces for Millennials and Computerworld ranked us as 1 of the top 100 places to work for IT professionals. We believe our commitment to treating our employees well translates into delivering the best products and services to our customers and superior returns to our shareholders.
Overall, it was a good quarter. We are making progress against our key focus areas for the year, and we were pleased with how we lined up versus other banks in the CCAR stress test results as well as overall capital returns planned for the year ahead.
Now I'll turn the call over to Mark, and he'll walk through the details of our second quarter financial results. Mark?

headline: Discover Financial Services, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll start by going through the revenue detail on Slide 5 of our earnings presentation.Net interest income increased $115 million or 7% over the prior year, driven by continued loan growth and a higher net in
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll start by going through the revenue detail on Slide 5 of our earnings presentation.
Net interest income increased $115 million or 7% over the prior year, driven by continued loan growth and a higher net interest margin. Total noninterest income decreased $74 million to $465 million. The prior year's results included $28 million in mortgage origination revenue, a category that's absent this year as we are no longer in that business.
Net discount and interchange revenue was down 11%, driven by a higher rewards rate year-over-year. Our rewards rate for the quarter was 121 basis points, up 16 basis points over the prior year due to higher promotional and standard rewards, which David noted are helping attract new accounts. Sequentially, the rewards rate was up 15 basis points driven by higher enrollment in spending in the quarter's rotating 5% category.
Moving to Payment Services. Revenue decreased $2 million from the prior year mainly due to the previously announced loss of volume from a third-party debit issuer. Overall, we grew total company net revenue by 2% for the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6. Total loan yield of 11.72% was 37 basis points higher than the prior year, primarily driven by a 38 basis point increase in card yield. The year-over-year increase in yield was primarily due to the higher percentage of revolving card receivables in the portfolio as well as the impact of last December's prime rate increase.
On the funding side, we grew average direct-to-consumer deposits by $4 billion. Total funding costs increased only 8 basis points despite higher market rates as their impact was muted by last year's fixed-rate debt issuances and our growing direct-to-consumer deposit base.
Overall, net interest margin expanded 31 basis points from the prior year to 9.94%. For the remainder of the year, we currently expect a relatively stable margin, but it will, of course, be impacted by any changes in our planned level of promotional activity, revolving behavior in the card portfolio and any future Fed actions.
Turning to Slide 7. Operating expenses were down $21 million over the prior year. Last year's results had $62 million in expense associated with the operation and closure of the direct mortgage origination business, about 1/3 of which was reflected in employee compensation. The $14 million year-over-year increase in total employee compensation you see in the table was driven primarily by higher headcount to support compliance activities as well as annual merit increases.
Marketing expenses were flat as savings from the elimination of mortgage marketing activities were reinvested in other areas of the business. Professional fees fell $3 million. The workstreams underlying the AML/BSA look-back project were, as expected, completed during the quarter at a cost of $12 million as compared to $19 million in the second quarter of last year. While the completion of these workstreams represents a milestone, I would remind you that we are continuing to enhance our compliance program to meet the terms of our consent orders. Other expense was lower as the prior year included $23 million in onetime charges associated with the exit of the home loan business.
Turning to provision for loan losses and credit on Slide 8. Provision for loan losses was higher by $106 million compared to the prior year due to higher reserves and charge-offs primarily driven by loan growth. This quarter, we increased reserves $28 million, while last year, we had a $41 million reserve release. The credit card net charge-off rate of 2.39% increased by 11 basis points year-over-year and increased 5 basis points sequentially. The 30-day delinquency rate of 1.63% increased 8 basis points year-over-year and was down 5 basis points sequentially. On balance, the credit backdrop remains benign, and reserving continues to be driven primarily by the compounding effect of several years of consistent loan growth, a meaningful portion of which has come from new accounts.
Looking at student loans. The net charge-off rate, excluding acquired loans, increased 8 basis points from the prior year due to continued seasoning of the organic book. Sequentially, the rate increased 25 basis points due primarily to seasonality.
Student loan delinquencies, once again excluding acquired loans, increased 10 basis points to 1.88% as a larger portion of the portfolio continues to come into repayment and decreased 4 basis points sequentially. Overall, the student loan portfolio continues to season generally in line with our expectations.
Switching to personal loans. The net charge-off rate was up 28 basis points from the prior year and down 7 basis points sequentially. The 30-day delinquency rate was up 31 basis points from the prior year and up 5 basis points from the prior quarter. The year-over-year increases in the personal loan charge-off and delinquency rates were primarily driven by the seasoning of recent loan growth, which was consistent with our expectations.
Next, I'll touch on our capital position on Slide 9. Our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio was flat sequentially. This ratio declined 20 basis points from the prior year due to capital deployment in the form of loan growth, buybacks and dividends. In the quarter, we again repurchased approximately 2% of our common stock.
As David mentioned, we're pleased with how we lined up versus other banks in terms of our stress capital ratios in the Federal Reserve's CCAR process. We received a non-objection from the Fed with respect to our propose capital actions for the 4 quarters ending June 30, 2017. As result, we plan to repurchase almost $2 billion of our common stock over the next 12 months. And last week, our board increased our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.28 to $0.30 per share. At current share prices, this results in one of the highest total yields among CCAR participants.
In summary, we delivered strong net interest income by growing loans and NIM; saw increased rewards expense primarily due to our double promotion, which drove more new and engaged accounts; grew the proportion of funding we get from deposits; and achieved a favorable outcome from the 2016 CCAR process.
That concludes our formal remarks, and now I'll turn the call back to the operator, Mike, to open the line up for Q&A.
